abstract: Diversity and inclusion programs for elites are tokens. A large wage increase that would most benefit the Black working class is far better.
lead_paragraph: After a summer of protests over the killing of George Floyd broadened into a wider reckoning on racial injustice, corporate America and the political establishment unleashed a flurry of promises to combat systemic racism. Diversity initiatives have been launched; high-profile companies in several sectors have settled on the advancement of a few people of color in their hierarchies.

headline: Biden calls Trump ‘one of the most racist presidents we’ve had in modern history.’
abstract: President Trump came to the debate ready with his regular wrap on race when asked to explain his description of “Black Lives Matter” as a symbol of hate: He claimed he had done more than any president since Abraham Lincoln for African-Americans, and he called himself the “least racist person in this room.” (Never mind that the moderator of the debate, Kristen Welker, is a Black woman.)
lead_paragraph: President Trump came to the debate ready with his regular wrap on race when asked to explain his description of “Black Lives Matter” as a symbol of hate: He claimed he had done more than any president since Abraham Lincoln for African-Americans, and he called himself the “least racist person in this room.” (Never mind that the moderator of the debate, Kristen Welker, is a Black woman.)

headline: Killer Mike Says He Has a Choice to Make
abstract: The rapper and activist on transforming fear into power.
lead_paragraph: You might know Michael Render, a.k.a. Killer Mike, from a speech he made that went viral four days after George Floyd’s death. Protests in Atlanta were escalating and so was the damage and violence. The mayor needed help turning the temperature down.

headline: Police in North Carolina use a chemical spray to disperse a get-out-the-vote rally.
abstract: Police officers and sheriff’s deputies in Graham, N.C., deployed a chemical spray and arrested eight people at a get-out-the-vote march and rally on Saturday, according to the police and participants.
lead_paragraph: Police officers and sheriff’s deputies in Graham, N.C., deployed a chemical spray and arrested eight people at a march and rally on Saturday that were intended to honor George Floyd and encourage people to vote, according to the police and participants.

headline: Black Art and Poetry Elevate a Tribute to Civil Rights Leaders
abstract: In “The Baptism,” Carrie Mae Weems and Carl Hancock Rux find an abstract, elegiac voice in their video honoring John Lewis and C.T. Vivian.
lead_paragraph: During the last several months, between the scourge of Covid-19 and the spate of Black deaths resulting from police brutality, Blackness has become a concept loaded with fresh injuries. In “The Baptism,” a short, abstract video tribute to Representative John Lewis and the civil rights leader C.T. Vivian, Blackness isn’t divorced from the tragedies but carefully picked apart and examined through an existential lens. The result is a work that is freeing and radical in a way that Black art so often doesn’t get to be.

headline: East Germany’s Love Affair With Angela Davis
abstract: An exhibition looks back at a point in the 1970s when the philosopher and activist was a state-promoted hero behind the Iron Curtain.
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — The philosopher, feminist and Black liberation activist Angela Davis is everywhere right now. In the wake of Black Lives Matter protests around the world, TV networks, magazines and newspapers have turned to her, drawing on her decades of activism and scholarship to explain the current moment.

headline: Scientific Journals Commit to Diversity but Lack the Data
abstract: Several prominent publishers said they did not track the race and ethnicity of the researchers contributing to their platforms.
lead_paragraph: On June 16, three weeks after the killing of George Floyd set off a wave of protests that would blaze across the globe, Joël Babdor received an unexpected email.

headline: Can I Tell My Friend Her Halloween Costume Is Problematic?
abstract: A reader feels that Scarlett O’Hara-style period dress may be seen as whitewashing the antebellum South.
lead_paragraph: A new friend in the Midwest was invited to an outdoor Halloween party where mask-wearing was requested. We went shopping for an art-inspired costume for her. But I saw that she was gravitating toward period costumes. After the party, she posted pictures online. I was stunned! She wore a full-blown Scarlett O’Hara-type gown — to a mansion, no less! If I’d known, I would have tried to talk her out if it. This year’s widespread Black Lives Matter protests, along with the traditional whitewashing of the antebellum South, make her choice seem insensitive. I’ll be seeing her soon, and I already feel awkward. I know she’ll share details of the party, and I feel obligated to enlighten her. Any advice?

headline: Louisville Officer Who Fatally Shot Breonna Taylor Is Now Suing Her Boyfriend
abstract: In a court filing, Sgt. Jonathan Mattingly said Kenneth Walker’s actions had caused him “severe trauma, mental anguish and emotional distress.”
lead_paragraph: One of the three police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor has sued Ms. Taylor’s boyfriend for assault and battery, the latest development in a case that electrified this year’s widespread protests for racial justice.

headline: What Topics Do Our Readers Want Trump and Biden to Debate?
abstract: In a year racked by crises, many important issues have been overshadowed. Times readers weighed in on what they want the candidates to address.
lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential election has been shaped by crises: Protests over police brutality and systemic racism. Fears about safe voting and election integrity. And above all, the devastating human and economic toll of the coronavirus.

headline: G.O.P. centrism gives way to fringe views in Biden’s home state, where a QAnon fan is running for Senate.
abstract: WILMINGTON, Del. — Lauren Witzke, a dabbler in QAnon, a self-proclaimed “flat earther” and the Republican Party’s nominee in Delaware for the Senate, was exhorting her supporters last month to “Go get ’em — America First,” as they squared off against a handful of Black Lives Matter protesters.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Lauren Witzke, a dabbler in QAnon, a self-proclaimed “flat earther” and the Republican Party’s nominee in Delaware for the Senate, was exhorting her supporters last month to “Go get ’em — America First,” as they squared off against a handful of Black Lives Matter protesters.

headline: Orchestras Are Rushing to Add Black Composers. Will It Last?
abstract: Ensembles shut by the coronavirus pandemic are shaking up their programming. Artists of color are hoping it’s for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: In June, as millions of Americans filled city streets with Black Lives Matter demonstrations and millions more rushed to share their solidarity online, the composer Jessie Montgomery noticed something unusual.

headline: A Dozen Protesters in Nigeria Reported Killed by Security Forces
abstract: Nigerians are stunned after police and soldiers opened fire on protesters against police brutality. The largely peaceful demonstrations have grown into a challenge for the government.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — With music playing and food being passed around, a festive atmosphere hung over the protest encampment on Tuesday night, despite the anger over police brutality that in recent weeks had driven youthful demonstrations that were the biggest Nigeria had seen in a generation.

headline: Joe Biden Had Close Ties With Police Leaders. Will They Help Him Now?
abstract: His proposed solution to addressing both urgent calls for police reform and animosity from law enforcement toward Democrats is one he’s long relied on: He’ll just get everyone in the same room.
lead_paragraph: Bill Johnson knew, before he reached out to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign last spring, that things had changed between the former vice president and the nation’s police unions. A once-close alliance had frayed amid clashes over police brutality and racism in the justice system. Still, Mr. Johnson, the executive director of the National Association of Police Organizations, invited Mr. Biden to address the group as it weighed its 2020 endorsement.

headline: Nigeria’s Police Brutality Crisis: What’s Happening Now
abstract: The authorities, unnerved in October by protests over police brutality, have promised changes. But the government’s response so far has only reinforced the views of protesters.

headline: Breonna Taylor Grand Jury Audio Reveals Conflicting Accounts of Fatal Raid
abstract: The 15 hours of recordings include interviews with witnesses, audio of 911 calls and other evidence — but few statements from prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Two very different accounts emerged on Friday from either side of an apartment door in Louisville, the one that police officers knocked off its hinges in March as they delivered a search warrant at the home of Breonna Taylor.

headline: A Memphis poll worker was fired for turning away voters wearing ‘Black Lives Matter’ shirts.
abstract: A poll worker in Memphis was fired last week after he improperly turned away several voters wearing T-shirts that said “Black Lives Matter” and “I Can’t Breathe,” a local election official said.
lead_paragraph: A poll worker in Memphis was fired last week after he improperly turned away several voters wearing T-shirts that said “Black Lives Matter” and “I Can’t Breathe,” a local election official said.

headline: Yelp Says It Will Mark Pages of Businesses Accused of Racist Conduct
abstract: The online review company said that it would raise flags when there was “resounding evidence” and that it would link to articles detailing racist reports.
lead_paragraph: Yelp, the local search and review site, said it would post alerts on the pages of businesses where customers or employees have reported incidents of racism, the latest attempt by a U.S. company to introduce a tougher response system to confront discrimination after the police killing of George Floyd in May.

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Jack Kerouac to Black Lives Matter
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE PURPOSE OF POWER: How We Come Together When We Fall Apart, by Alicia Garza, read by the author. (Random House Audio.) The co-creator of the Black Lives Matter movement shares the lessons she’s learned — about activism and civil rights — the hard way.

headline: Manslaughter Charge Urged for Israeli Officer in Killing of Autistic Palestinian
abstract: Palestinians assail the failure to recommend a murder charge in the case, which has become a cause célèbre in the fight against police brutality.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli prosecutors recommended on Wednesday that a police officer who shot and killed an unarmed Palestinian man with autism be charged with manslaughter in a case that became a rallying cry against police brutality.

headline: As Lawlessness Roils Nigeria, Police Chief Vows to Take Back Streets
abstract: As protests against police brutality have subsided after a violent crackdown, they have been followed by a wave of looting and vandalism that the police have vowed to end.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS — Nigeria’s police chief on Saturday ordered the mobilization of all police resources to reclaim public space after more than two weeks of peaceful protests over police brutality gave way to widespread vandalism and looting.

headline: George Floyd Billboard Goes Up in Times Square
abstract: The project from a group called the George Floyd Justice Billboard Committee features a painting by Donald Perlis and a quote from the Dalai Lama.
lead_paragraph: A billboard depicting the death of George Floyd went up in Times Square on Tuesday, placed there by a group called the George Floyd Justice Billboard Committee that hopes to expand with more billboards across the country.

headline: A New Oath for 140 Future Doctors in Pandemic N.Y.
abstract: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai welcomed first-year students with a virtual “white coat” ceremony, during which they referenced the coronavirus and Black Lives Matter.
lead_paragraph: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai welcomed first-year students with a virtual “white coat” ceremony, during which they referenced the coronavirus and Black Lives Matter.

headline: The Killing of Breonna Taylor
abstract: The New York Times Presents, our documentary TV series, investigates recordings, 911 calls and over 1,500 pages of police records to reveal a clearer picture of the botched drug raid by the Louisville police that led to Breonna Taylor’s death.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Presents, our documentary TV series, investigates recordings, 911 calls and over 1,500 pages of police records to reveal a clearer picture of the botched drug raid by the Louisville police that led to Breonna Taylor’s death.

headline: In the Breonna Taylor Case, a Battle of Blame Over the Grand Jury
abstract: In theory, jurors have broad powers to investigate, subpoena witnesses and bring charges, legal experts said. But in practice, prosecutors control the process and are rarely challenged.
lead_paragraph: News conferences, protest chants, witness statements — so much has been said by so many about the shooting death of Breonna Taylor in Louisville, Ky., six months ago. Except, that is, by the dozen people who have weighed the evidence in the case behind closed doors and decided that only one officer should be indicted.

headline: Why New Mexico’s 1680 Pueblo Revolt Is Echoing in 2020 Protests
abstract: Indigenous groups in the Southwest are imbuing their activism this year with commemorations of the 340-year-old Pueblo Revolt, one of Spain’s bloodiest defeats in its colonial empire.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — While protests over police violence against African-Americans spread from one city to the next in the aftermath of George Floyd’s killing in May, the missive scrawled in red paint on the New Mexico History Museum reached further back in time: “1680 Land Back.”

headline: Reform the Police? Guess Who Funds My State’s Officials
abstract: If the protests are to translate into laws, contributions for politicians from law enforcement must become toxic rather than coveted.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In late August, Los Angeles sheriff’s deputies shot a Black man, Dijon Kizzee, whom they had stopped for a suspected traffic violation as he rode his bicycle. He became the seventh man killed by deputies in Los Angeles since the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis on Memorial Day weekend.

headline: Nebraska Bar Owner Who Was Charged in Killing of Black Man Dies by Suicide
abstract: Jacob Gardner, who was indicted in the killing of James Scurlock during a May protest in Omaha, had been expected to turn himself in to the authorities, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: A white bar owner charged in the fatal shooting of a Black man during a protest in Nebraska in May — less than a week after the killing of George Floyd — has died by suicide, the man’s lawyer said on Sunday.

headline: Biden Gives Cautious Answers on Breonna Taylor and the Supreme Court
abstract: Asked by reporters about two issues of deep importance to Democrats, the party’s nominee was circumspect. The Biden campaign later released a fuller statement about Ms. Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Less than six weeks from Election Day, Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday shied away from two major issues of deep importance to Democrats, giving cautious responses to reporters’ questions about the police shooting of Breonna Taylor and President Trump’s imminent nomination for the Supreme Court.

headline: Trump has a long history of language that incites and demonizes.
abstract: President Trump has employed provocative and sometimes incendiary words and images to focus attention on demonstrations and away from the human and economic costs of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has seized on the response in the streets to police brutality against Black men and women to bolster his re-election campaign, employing provocative and sometimes incendiary language and images to incite his followers, demonize his opponents or both.

headline: Marian Wright Edelman Steps Down, and a New Generation Takes Over
abstract: A Ferguson activist will lead the Children’s Defense Fund at a time when an impassioned civil rights movement is challenging racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Marian Wright Edelman, 81, took to the streets this summer, joining millions of people around the country in protesting police brutality after the killing of George Floyd.

headline: What Does TikTok Mean to You?
abstract: Are you a user or content creator on TikTok? Have you been following the news about the threatened ban, and then sale, of TikTok? Do you think we should we care about what happens to TikTok?
lead_paragraph: TikTok is used by nearly 100 million Americans for everything from education about climate change and the Black Lives Matter movement to dance videos and comedic skits. The app has been downloaded more than two billion times. Do you use TikTok? What role does it play in your life?

headline: Fox News Is Accused of Hiding George Soros’s Influence
abstract: It’s a twist for the cable channel, which regularly airs criticism of the billionaire investor and Democratic donor.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no figure gets more attention in conspiracy circles than George Soros, the billionaire investor and Democratic donor. For years, he has been cast as an anticonservative villain by a loose network of activists and political figures on the right. And in recent months, he has become a convenient boogeyman for misinformation artists who have falsely claimed that he funds spontaneous Black Lives Matter protests as well as antifa, the decentralized and largely online, far-left activist network that opposes President Trump.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 12, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 12, 2020
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about President Trump’s encounters with Black leaders misstated the month George Floyd was killed by the police. It was May, not June.

headline: Without Evidence, Right-Wing Commentators Link Soros to Louisville U-Haul
abstract: A spokeswoman for the liberal financier said he had “absolutely not” paid for the rental of a truck used in a protest in Louisville.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, as protests formed over a grand jury’s decision not to charge police officers for the killing of Breonna Taylor, footage began circulating on social media of a U-Haul truck being used to distribute signs, shields and other materials to protesters in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Breonna Taylor Case Is Formidable Test for an Ascendant Attorney General
abstract: Daniel Cameron, a rising G.O.P. star in Kentucky, is seen as a possible successor to Senator Mitch McConnell. But first, he has to navigate a case roiling the nation.
lead_paragraph: As the first Republican attorney general in Kentucky in more than 70 years and the first Black attorney general in the state’s history, Daniel Cameron has a future in Republican politics that has seemed limitless.

headline: Can We Talk to Our ‘Blue Lives Matter’ Neighbors About Black Lives Matter?
abstract: A reader wants to know whether her son’s lawn sign crossed a line, and if she should take things further.
lead_paragraph: My husband, our tween son and I moved into a new house at the beginning of the year. We didn’t meet our neighbors before the pandemic hit; we still haven’t. After the horrible police shooting of Jacob Blake last week, our son made a beautiful Black Lives Matter poster and asked if he could display it on our lawn. We were proud to! A few days later, our neighbors seemed to respond with a Blue Lives Matter sign on their lawn. It hurts our hearts when we see it. Were we wrong to put up our son’s lawn sign? Can we talk to the neighbors about theirs?

headline: The Whitney Canceled Their Exhibition. Now Those Artists Want Reform.
abstract: Last month, the museum acquired works from 80 artists, often through discounted sales. A new letter signed by more than half of the artists asks for substantive changes in the Whitney’s policies.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art had planned to show  an exhibition of artistic responses to the coronavirus pandemic and Black Lives Matter demonstrations shortly after reopening. But the museum reversed course last month, canceling its plans after several artists of color included in the show publicly criticized the Whitney for acquiring their works without consent and through discounted sales meant to benefit racial justice charities.

headline: Fired Officer Is Indicted in Breonna Taylor Case; Protesters Wanted Stronger Charges
abstract: A former officer was charged with “wanton endangerment” for endangering Ms. Taylor’s neighbors with gunshots when she was killed by police officers in her Louisville apartment.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Breonna Taylor decision and Louisville protests updates.]

headline: What Is ‘Wanton Endangerment,’ the Charge in the Breonna Taylor Case?
abstract: Here’s what is behind the charge leveled by a Kentucky grand jury against one of the officers involved in the fatal raid on Ms. Taylor’s apartment in March.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury in Kentucky has indicted a former Louisville police detective, Brett Hankison, on three counts of “wanton endangerment in the first degree” for his actions during the raid of Breonna Taylor’s apartment. What does that mean?

headline: Steps Toward Police Reform
abstract: For one Black officer from Michigan, it’s the small moments that matter.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd, there has been a lot of talk about police reform: Calls to defund and dismantle departments, or to train better and to recruit wider.

headline: She Helped Put ‘Black Lives Matter’ on N.B.A. Courts
abstract: Michele Roberts grew up in the South Bronx and made her way to the pinnacle of the legal world before becoming the head of the players’ union.
lead_paragraph: In early March, Michele Roberts announced she would be stepping down as executive director of the National Basketball Players Association after six years on the job.

headline: Without evidence, right-wing commentators link Soros to a truck supplying protesters in Louisville.
abstract: A spokeswoman for the liberal financier said he had “absolutely not” paid for the rental of a truck used in a protest in Louisville.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, as protests formed over a grand jury’s decision not to charge police officers for the killing of Breonna Taylor, footage began circulating on social media of a U-Haul truck being used to distribute signs, shields and other materials to protesters in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Man Spent Donations to Black Lives Matter on Himself, Prosecutors Say
abstract: “There is no cause, no tragedy, and no event that fraudsters won’t seek to exploit,” prosecutors said in accusing a man of diverting funds from a group he ran that took in more than $450,000.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The donations poured in this summer as Black Lives Matter marchers surged through the streets of Atlanta and across the country, protesting the use of aggressive force by the police and demanding more action to scrub out the deep stain of institutional racism.

headline: Police Veteran Charged in George Floyd Killing Had Used Neck Restraints Before
abstract: Derek Chauvin, the officer who is charged with second-degree murder in Mr. Floyd’s death, is expected to go to trial next year.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder after pressing his knee into the neck of George Floyd for more than eight minutes had used neck and upper body restraints during at least seven previous arrests, prosecutors said in court documents filed this week.

headline: The Truth About ‘The Truth About’ Memes
abstract: Videos and viral images claiming to tell “the truth about” Black victims of police shootings are years old. This week, they are circulating about Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: This week, protests erupted around the nation after a Louisville grand jury did not charge any police officers in the killing of Breonna Taylor. And on social media, false and exaggerated claims about Ms. Taylor began recirculating, using a years-old format that was popularized years ago by far-right YouTube personalities.

headline: ‘The Time Has Come’: Barbados Casts Off the Queen as Head of State, and Others May Follow
abstract: The Black Lives Matter movement has revived a simmering debate about the legacy of colonialism, potentially inspiring change in other Caribbean countries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The last time a string of distant dominions cast off Queen Elizabeth was in the 1970s when the Black power movement emboldened three Caribbean countries to declare themselves republics. Now, in the heat of the Black Lives Matter movement, the Caribbean may once again turn against the queen.

headline: Justice Dept. Threatens to Withhold Federal Funds From N.Y., Seattle and Portland
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr criticized the cities for their responses to protests against police brutality. Democrats called it an effort to help President Trump’s re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr on Monday escalated the Trump administration’s attacks on Democratic-led cities by threatening to withhold federal funding from New York, Seattle and Portland, Ore., over their responses to protests against police brutality, portraying them as inadequate as President Trump seeks to make the unrest a cornerstone of his re-election campaign.

headline: Grand Juror in Breonna Taylor Case Says Deliberations Were Misrepresented
abstract: The Kentucky attorney general’s office said it would release the panel’s recordings after a grand juror contended in a court filing that its discussions were inaccurately characterized.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A juror in the Breonna Taylor case contends that the Kentucky attorney general misrepresented the grand jury’s deliberations and failed to offer the panel the option of indicting the two officers who fatally shot the young woman, according to the juror’s lawyer.

headline: Players’ Alliance Gets $10 Million From M.L.B. and Union to Build Diversity
abstract: The money is a substantial boost to the 12-week-old group formed by current and former players to increase Black participation at all levels of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball and the players’ union have pledged $10 million to the Players Alliance, a nonprofit formed this summer by more than 100 current and former Black players in the wake of George Floyd’s death, aiming to help build Black participation in the sport, from front offices to the diamond.

headline: How the Fatal Shooting at a Portland Protest Unfolded
abstract: We followed the final moments of a man shot and killed in Portland, Ore., as supporters of President Trump clashed with those protesting police violence.
lead_paragraph: The fatal shooting of a far-right group’s supporter in Portland, Ore., on Saturday is raising fears that the Black Lives Matter and pro-Trump protests across the country could escalate into more deadly skirmishes.

headline: New Details About Breonna Taylor’s Life and Death
abstract: ‘The New York Times Presents,’ on FX and Hulu, investigates recordings, 911 calls and over 1,500 pages of police records to reveal a clearer picture of the deadly botched raid.
lead_paragraph: Now streaming on Hulu and available here for New York Times subscribers in the U.S.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Black Lives Matter Reached Every Corner of America’
abstract: In this lesson, students will use more than 200 photographs to learn about the protests that swept across the United States in late May and June.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Black Lives Matter Reached Every Corner of America”

headline: News Quiz: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Breonna Taylor Decision, C.D.C.
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: 2 Officers Shot in Louisville Protests Over Breonna Taylor Charging Decision
abstract: A grand jury didn’t charge any officers with killing Ms. Taylor in her apartment, prompting protests nationwide. A former detective was indicted on three counts of “wanton endangerment.”
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live updates on the Breonna Taylor decision and the Louisville protests.]

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘What We Know About Breonna Taylor’s Case and Death’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about and respond to Ms. Taylor’s life and death, as well as the reaction to the recent grand jury decision for her case.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “What We Know About Breonna Taylor’s Case and Death” by Richard A. Oppel Jr., Derrick Bryson Taylor and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

headline: The Killing of Breonna Taylor, Part 1
abstract: Since the young medical worker was fatally shot in a police raid on her home, her name has become a rallying cry for protesters. In the first of two parts, we explore how officers came to raid her house.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: New York City Council, Don’t Roll Back Police Reforms
abstract: Officials might weaken a law that bans chokeholds and other police maneuvers that restrict airflow.
lead_paragraph: In June, as New York City was gripped by protests over the death of George Floyd, the City Council passed legislation banning police officers from using maneuvers that restrict a person’s airflow. Now the Council, cowed by pressure from police unions and officials, is considering rolling back part of this important step toward police accountability.

headline: ‘There Are Breonnas Everywhere’: Protests for Breonna Taylor in Pictures
abstract: The New York Times has photographers on the ground following protests across the country.
lead_paragraph: Protests extended into a second night in Louisville on Thursday, with demonstrators expressing outrage and anguish over Breonna Taylor’s killing in March and the prosecutors’ handling of the case. For months, Ms. Taylor’s family had pleaded for justice, pushing for criminal charges against the officers.

headline: Breonna Taylor, Coronavirus Vaccine, Belarus: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What to Know About the Death of Rayshard Brooks
abstract: Killed by an Atlanta police officer just weeks after George Floyd’s death touched off nationwide protests, Mr. Brooks became a potent symbol.
lead_paragraph: Less than three weeks after George Floyd’s death in police custody, fuel was added to the nationwide protests against police brutality when an Atlanta officer fatally shot Rayshard Brooks on June 12 in the parking lot of a Wendy’s restaurant.

headline: It Is Possible to Reform the Police
abstract: How to end the racial disparity in vehicle stops.
lead_paragraph: In his speech last week in Pittsburgh, Joe Biden pushed back against Donald Trump’s mischaracterization of him as soft on crime and beholden to progressives intent on defunding or abolishing police departments. He pledged to work with mayors and governors to tamp down violence. He also vowed to make progress on police reform, invoking the names of Breonna Taylor, George Floyd and Jacob Blake, and the cause of racial justice for which they have come to stand.

headline: From Bike Blockers to Street Medics: The Anatomy of an N.Y.C. Protest
abstract: Some demonstrators in New York have taken on informal but crucial roles over a summer of marches. Here’s how to spot them.
lead_paragraph: Only a few weeks after the first of what would become near-daily Black Lives Matter protests in New York City, Justina Heckard found herself on her bicycle in Brooklyn, leading a march in loose formation with other cyclists. An altercation with a driver left a protester injured, and Ms. Heckard and her fellow demonstrators decided they would need to sharpen their tactics.

headline: As Donations Shift in the Pandemic, New Databases Aim to Help
abstract: Donors are giving money in different ways this year, and two new projects are helping them identify the nonprofit groups that can best use their money.
lead_paragraph: Charitable giving both increased this year and went in new directions, as donors, big and small, responded first to the pandemic and then to social justice causes after the killing of George Floyd in May.

headline: American Suburbs Are Tilting for Biden. But Not Milwaukee’s.
abstract: The predominantly white neighborhoods outside Wisconsin’s largest city, among the nation’s most racially segregated suburbs, could be a key part of President Trump’s narrowing path to re-election.
lead_paragraph: CEDARBURG, Wis. — When Michael Hicks and his daughter chalked “Black Lives Matter” on the pavement outside their suburban home, someone scrubbed it away within hours.

headline: No, a Black Lives Matter Co-Founder Didn’t Partner With a Pro-Communist Chinese Group
abstract: A Heritage Foundation investigation went viral on Thursday, but it conflated two nonprofits with the same name.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, an article from The Daily Signal, the blog of the conservative Heritage Foundation, claimed to show a damning link between an organization started by a Black Lives Matter co-founder, Alicia Garza, and a nonprofit with ties to the Chinese government. The article went viral.

headline: N.F.L. Season Kicks Off With Players’ Protesting Racism
abstract: After an off-season of social turmoil, the Houston Texans chose not to be on the field for the playing of “Lift Every Voice and Sing” and “The Star-Spangled Banner” before the league’s season opener in Kansas City, Mo.
lead_paragraph: After an off-season of social and political turmoil, N.F.L. players made it clear on the night of the season opener that they will continue to shine a light on social injustice and police brutality against African Americans.

headline: Few Police Officers Who Cause Deaths Are Charged or Convicted
abstract: A wide gulf remains between the public perception of police violence and how it is treated in court.
lead_paragraph: Since Breonna Taylor was awakened in the night and shot to death by the police in her own home, Louisville has banned no-knock warrants. A police chief was fired, and so was an officer who was on the scene. But despite demands from across the country, no one was charged in Ms. Taylor’s death.

headline: Judge Allows 2-Day Delay in Release of Breonna Taylor Grand Jury Recording
abstract: The tape was to be released on Wednesday, but Daniel Cameron, the Kentucky attorney general, said he needed more time to redact information about witnesses.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A judge on Wednesday allowed the Kentucky attorney general to delay the release of an audio recording from the secret grand jury deliberations in which jurors decided not to charge the two Louisville police officers who shot and killed Breonna Taylor.

headline: Documents Reveal How the Police Kept Daniel Prude’s Death Quiet
abstract: Officials in Rochester, N.Y., spent months trying to suppress video footage of the police encounter that led to Mr. Prude’s death.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — It was early June, days after the death of George Floyd, and cities around the country were erupting in protests against police brutality.

headline: Breonna Taylor and Perpetual Black Trauma
abstract: The system erased her as if she never existed.
lead_paragraph: I filed this column late. Very late. I couldn’t find the words — an unsettling experience for a writer. The words I did conjure failed, not because the message was difficult to convey, but rather because the conveyance is maddeningly depressive in repetition.

headline: The Truth About Today’s Anarchists
abstract: “Insurrectionary anarchists” have been protesting for racial justice all summer. Some Black leaders wish they would go home.
lead_paragraph: On the last Sunday in May, Jeremy Lee Quinn, a furloughed photographer in Santa Monica, Calif., was snapping photos of suburban moms kneeling at a Black Lives Matter protest when a friend alerted him to a more dramatic subject: looting at a shoe store about a mile away.

headline: Breonna Taylor’s Family to Receive $12 Million Settlement From City of Louisville
abstract: In the aftermath of the botched police raid in which Ms. Taylor was killed, the city also agreed to institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — After months of protests that turned Breonna Taylor’s name into a national slogan against police violence, city officials agreed to pay her family $12 million and institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.

headline: Breonna Taylor Deserved Justice
abstract: No police officer will have to answer for her death. This never gets easier.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky’s attorney general, Daniel Cameron, announced Wednesday that one police officer would be charged, not in the shooting death of Breonna Taylor, but with endangering her neighbors with reckless gunfire. “If we simply act on emotion or outrage, there is no justice. Mob justice is not justice,” Mr. Cameron said, in an apparent attempt to explain the lack of more serious charges relating to the 26-year-old’s killing. “Justice sought by violence is not justice. It just becomes revenge.”

headline: News Quiz: Breonna Taylor, Hurricane Sally, Venus
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Attorney General Announces Charge Against 1 Officer in Breonna Taylor Killing
abstract: Daniel Cameron, the Republican attorney general in Kentucky, announced that a grand jury has indicted one officer on criminal charges in the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor at a news conference on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Cameron, the Republican attorney general in Kentucky, announced that a grand jury has indicted one officer on criminal charges in the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor at a news conference on Wednesday.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Lawyer Pushes Back on Police Claims
abstract: The family of George Floyd and their lawyer, Benjamin Crump, rebuked claims from police officers’ defense lawyers that Mr. Floyd died of an overdose.
lead_paragraph: The family of George Floyd and their lawyer, Benjamin Crump, rebuked claims from police officers’ defense lawyers that Mr. Floyd died of an overdose.

headline: One Officer Charged in Breonna Taylor Case
abstract: Daniel Cameron, Kentucky’s attorney general, announced that a grand jury indicted one officer on criminal charges in the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Cameron, Kentucky’s attorney general, announced that a grand jury indicted one officer on criminal charges in the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor.

headline: ‘Say Her Name!’ Protesters in Louisville Unite for Breonna Taylor
abstract: Demonstrators rallied in Louisville, Ky., on a second night of protests after a grand jury did not charge police officers with the fatal shooting of Ms. Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators rallied in Louisville, Ky., on a second night of protests after a grand jury did not charge police officers with the fatal shooting of Ms. Taylor.

headline: ‘Violence Is Never the Answer,’ Louisville Mayor Says
abstract: Mayor Greg Fischer of Louisville, Ky., acknowledged the community’s pain after a grand jury did not charge any officers with killing Breonna Taylor, and addressed the shooting of two police officers during protests.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Greg Fischer of Louisville, Ky., acknowledged the community’s pain after a grand jury did not charge any officers with killing Breonna Taylor, and addressed the shooting of two police officers during protests.

headline: Louisville Mayor Awards $12 Million Settlement to Breonna Taylor’s Estate
abstract: The mayor of Louisville, Ky., described police reform initiatives in response to Breonna Taylor’s killing, and announced a $12 million settlement in a wrongful-death lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Louisville, Ky., described police reform initiatives in response to Breonna Taylor’s killing, and announced a $12 million settlement in a wrongful-death lawsuit.

headline: Protests Erupt in Louisville After Breonna Taylor Decision
abstract: Protesters took to the streets in Louisville, Ky., after the state’s attorney general announced that only one of three officers involved in the killing of Breonna Taylor would be charged.
lead_paragraph: Protesters took to the streets in Louisville, Ky., after the state’s attorney general announced that only one of three officers involved in the killing of Breonna Taylor would be charged.

headline: 2 Officers Shot in Louisville Protests
abstract: Two Louisville, Ky., police officers were shot during protests Wednesday night after a grand jury did not charge officers with killing Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Two Louisville, Ky., police officers were shot during protests Wednesday night after a grand jury did not charge officers with killing Breonna Taylor.

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Dan Rather to Black Lives Matter
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE SWITCH, by Beth O’Leary, read by Alison Steadman and Daisy Edgar-Jones. (Macmillan Audio.) A lonely septuagenarian and her overworked granddaughter swap houses for two months — the elder woman looking for love, the younger hoping to recenter herself.

headline: Some Protests Against Police Brutality Take a More Confrontational Approach
abstract: The protests are moving into white residential neighborhoods, where activists demand that people choose a side.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Terrance Moses was watching protesters against police brutality march down his quiet residential street one recent evening when some in the group of a few hundred suddenly stopped and started yelling.

headline: Investigating the Killing of Breonna Taylor
abstract: Piecing together new details of her life and death through audio.
lead_paragraph: Listen to ‘The Killing of Breonna Taylor’: Part 1 and Part 2

headline: Quotation of the Day: Officer Charged and Two Cleared in Taylor Killing
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The decision before my office is not to decide if the loss of Breonna Taylor’s life was a tragedy — the answer to that question is unequivocally yes.”

headline: The Killing of Breonna Taylor, Part 2
abstract: What thousands of pages of documents tell us about the night the 26-year-old was killed and whether the officers involved will ever be charged.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: How George Floyd Died, and What Happened Next
abstract: Mr. Floyd, a Black man, died in May 2020 after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by Minneapolis police officers in an episode that was captured on video, touching off nationwide protests.
lead_paragraph: The death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man, in May 2020 drew widespread outrage after a video circulated online showing Officer Derek Chauvin holding his knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck on a Minneapolis street corner as he gasped for breath.

headline: Breonna Taylor, Justice Ginsburg, M.L.B.: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Anthony McGill, ‘Citizen Musician,’ Wins $100,000 Award
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s principal clarinet, and a leader in promoting racial representation, was chosen for the Avery Fisher Prize.
lead_paragraph: Anthony McGill, the New York Philharmonic’s principal clarinet, hasn’t been heard onstage at Lincoln Center since the coronavirus pandemic abruptly ended the orchestra’s season in March. But he has been difficult to miss online, whether as the instigator of #TakeTwoKnees performances in response to the killing of George Floyd, or as a prominent voice in subsequent conversations around racial representation in classical music.

headline: Jazz Has Always Been Protest Music. Can It Meet This Moment?
abstract: Over the past 50 years, the music has become entrenched in academic institutions. As a result, it’s often inaccessible to, and disconnected from, many of the very people who created it: young Black Americans.
lead_paragraph: If the Black Lives Matter movement has an anthem, it’s probably Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright.” Five years after its release, it’s still chanted en masse by demonstrators and blasted from car stereos at protests, fluttering in the air like a liberation flag.

headline: Biden gives cautious answers on Breonna Taylor and the Supreme Court.
abstract: Asked by reporters about two issues of deep importance to Democrats, the party’s nominee was circumspect. The Biden campaign later released a fuller statement about Ms. Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday shied away from two major issues of deep importance to Democrats, giving cautious responses to reporters’ questions about the police shooting of Breonna Taylor and President Trump’s imminent nomination for the Supreme Court.

headline: George Floyd Protests: A Timeline
abstract: At least six people have been killed in violence connected to the protests that started after Mr. Floyd died in police custody.
lead_paragraph: After the death of George Floyd on May 25, protests and unrest have rocked Minneapolis and other cities.

headline: 7 People Shot at Louisville Protest Over the Death of Breonna Taylor
abstract: The protests in Kentucky were prompted by the killing of Ms. Taylor, a black woman who was shot dead by white police officers who entered her home in March.
lead_paragraph: Seven people were struck by gunfire at a protest in Louisville, Ky., on Thursday night as tensions there continued to escalate over the fatal shooting of a black woman by three white police officers in March.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘What We Know About the Shooting Death of Ahmaud Arbery’
abstract: In this lesson, students will honor Mr. Arbery’s memory and consider what his case says about life in America today.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “What We Know About the Shooting Death of Ahmaud Arbery” by Richard Fausset

headline: Athletes’ Outpouring on Civil Unrest Rekindles Kaepernick Debate in N.F.L.
abstract: As a range of players called for unity and understanding in response to the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, the debate over Colin Kaepernick and his campaign for social justice resurfaced.
lead_paragraph: The outbreak of civil unrest initiated by the death of George Floyd has brought about an unusual outpouring from players, coaches and officials in the N.F.L., which has wrestled publicly with issues of race and racism more than other leagues. In some instances, however, longstanding disputes about whether the league takes the issue seriously enough have been rekindled.

headline: What Top Conservatives Are Saying About George Floyd and Police Brutality
abstract: For those on the right whose usual instinct is to stand up for law enforcement, the stark video showing Mr. Floyd being fatally pinned by a police officer raises conflicting feelings about the incident.
lead_paragraph: In her typical appearances on Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, a former Republican district attorney, reserves her highest dudgeon for castigating liberals and lamenting the demise of law and order.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery Shooting: A Timeline of the Case
abstract: A look at the major moments between Mr. Arbery’s killing in a Georgia suburb and the trial of three men found guilty of murder.
lead_paragraph: Ahmaud Arbery loved to run. A former high school football standout, he had been jogging near his home on the outskirts of Brunswick, Ga., when he was shot and killed after being pursued by two white men with guns, according to the authorities.

headline: Arrests in the Killing of Ahmaud Arbery
abstract: Readers react to articles about the killing of a black jogger in Georgia. Also: Defending Israel; the “Bridgegate” decision; a plasma recipient’s story; Pakistan’s religious minorities.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Corporate Voices Get Behind ‘Black Lives Matter’ Cause
abstract: Major companies are often wary of conflict, especially in a polarized time. But some are now taking a stand on racial injustice and police violence.
lead_paragraph: As tensions flared around the country after George Floyd’s death under a policeman’s knee, protesters received support from an unexpected corner: corporate America.

headline: Record Ratings and Record Chaos on Cable News
abstract: Cable networks are facing threats, and opportunities, in a national crisis. Now, Fox is fighting back and CNBC is looking to the right. CNN is defined by Jeff Zucker, and he may run for mayor.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Fox News’s anchors competed for President Trump’s ear about the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Tucker Carlson denounced the unrest as “riots.” Sean Hannity unexpectedly took a civil rights angle, speaking “as a person that has now been trained in mixed martial arts for seven straight years” to cast doubt on Officer Derek Chauvin’s actions.

headline: Reopening Risks, Ahmaud Arbery, Mother’s Day: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Appeals for Calm as Sprawling Protests Threaten to Spiral Out of Control
abstract: Escalating violence and destruction raised questions about whether a diverse, broadly decentralized protest movement was veering off track.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The nation was rocked again on Saturday as demonstrators clashed with police from outside the White House gates to the streets of more than three dozen besieged cities, as outrage over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis traversed a razor’s edge between protest and civic meltdown.

headline: Where Ahmaud Arbery Ran, Neighbors Cast Wary Eyes
abstract: He took his final jog across a stretch of South Georgia marked by increasingly blurred racial boundary lines.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — For many residents of Satilla Shores, a subdivision in coastal Georgia, their waterfront neighborhood is paradise without pretension.

headline: ‘Generations of Pain’: Gov. Tim Walz Appeals for Healing in Minnesota
abstract: The governor, a Democrat, is a former member of the National Guard who deployed the force after the killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: With the eyes of a burning city and rattled nation on him, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota tried on Friday to channel the anger of people enraged over the death of George Floyd at the hands of the police.

headline: George Floyd, Hong Kong, SpaceX: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Black America Knows About Quarantine
abstract: White people are protesting against being trapped at home. Black people know what it feels like to really be trapped.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 23, a 25-year-old black man named Ahmaud Arbery left his home in Brunswick, Ga., to go for a Sunday afternoon run. As he entered a nearby subdivision, he was followed and later shot dead by a father and son while their neighbor recorded the incident on his phone.

headline: Protests Near White House Spiral Out of Control Again
abstract: Washington’s mayor imposed a curfew and activated the National Guard, but the demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd turned into a repeat of the previous night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite an 11 p.m. curfew imposed by Mayor Muriel E. Bowser and the activation of the National Guard, protests near the White House fueled by anger over the police killing of George Floyd spiraled out of control again on Sunday night.

headline: Police Cars Rammed Protesters. Here’s What de Blasio’s Response Tells Us.
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has cultivated an image of fighting against inequality and police abuses, yet this crisis has challenged him more than ever.
lead_paragraph: The brief video clip, widely circulated on social media and on the national news, seemed to capture a wanton act of police brutality: One police cruiser, and then a second, jolting into a crowd of protesters in Brooklyn, sending people sprawling across the street.

headline: Destructive Power of Despair
abstract: The protests are not necessarily about Floyd’s killing in particular, but about the savagery and carnage that his death represents.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live updates on the George Floyd protests across the country.]

headline: Killing of Ahmaud Arbery Is Switched to a Fourth Prosecutor
abstract: Joyette M. Holmes, an Atlanta-area district attorney, will take over a case that has stirred protests, as the Justice Department said it was weighing federal hate crimes charges.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — The Georgia attorney general on Monday named a new prosecutor to oversee the case of Ahmaud Arbery, the 25-year-old black man whose killing has drawn national attention and inspired protests after a video emerged of his fatal encounter with two white men who have been charged with murder.

headline: Masks, State Aid, Ahmaud Arbery: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Body Cam’ Review: Rage in Physical Form
abstract: Mary J. Blige plays a bereaved police officer hunting a killer in this supernatural crime thriller.
lead_paragraph: A murdered African-American youth and a police cover-up drive Malik Vitthal’s “Body Cam,” a supernatural revenge fantasy that is anything but subtle. Its timeliness, however, is undeniable: With the investigations into the deaths of Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud Arbery currently making news, this awkward hybrid of horror and social consciousness plucks at one of our country’s rawest nerves.

headline: Do You Have Video of George Floyd’s Arrest?
abstract: The New York Times is seeking photos and videos from the scene of Mr. Floyd’s arrest in Minneapolis on May 25.
lead_paragraph: [Read more about George Floyd and Derek Chauvin once working together.]

headline: Past Presidents Faced Police Brutality and Protests. They Handled It Differently.
abstract: President Trump’s predecessors took different approaches when responding — or not responding — to police killings or assaults of black men. But they never threatened violence against protesters.
lead_paragraph: It is a bleak reality of American history that each of the past four presidents faced the same crisis President Trump is facing now: The police just killed or seriously injured a black man, and the city where it happened is reeling with grief and rage.

headline: A Lifetime of Running With Ahmaud Arbery Ends With a Text: ‘We Lost Maud’
abstract: Ahmaud Arbery and Akeem Baker were best friends who treated each other as brothers. With one now gone, the other struggles to move on.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Long after Akeem Baker escaped the orbit of small-town Georgia, he would continue to rely on his best friend, Ahmaud Arbery. He had relied on him almost from the beginning.

headline: Autopsy Shows Ahmaud Arbery Was Shot Twice in the Chest
abstract: The autopsy report, which also showed Mr. Arbery had no drugs or alcohol in his system, came as activists renewed their protests against prosecutors’ handling of the investigation into his death.
lead_paragraph: Follow updates on the trial over the killing of Ahmaud Arbery.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery and the Ghosts of Lynchings Past
abstract: As a black man living in Georgia, I am all too aware of the state’s history of lynching.
lead_paragraph: Well before the tragic killing of Ahmaud Arbery, a young black man, in Glynn County, Ga., on Feb. 23, I had a conversation with a very close white friend of mine. She wanted to exercise outside. I preferred the treadmill. I told her that I find it easier to walk or jog on the treadmill. She insisted the air is better for me. Again, I protested. Yet, I had not disclosed the whole truth.

headline: Investigators Say Man Who Filmed Arbery’s Killing Was More Than a Witness
abstract: The video captured by William Bryan brought the world’s attention to the case. Authorities said he participated in the deadly confrontation.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — From the beginning, William Bryan has portrayed himself as a concerned citizen, one drawn by commotion when he pulled out his phone and filmed the fatal encounter between two of his white neighbors and Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was running in their neighborhood.

headline: What to Know About Breonna Taylor’s Death
abstract: Fury over her killing by the police in Louisville, Ky., fueled protests, and questions persist about how the botched raid unfolded.
lead_paragraph: [Update: A former police detective has pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy, admitting she had helped mislead a judge into authorizing a raid of Breonna Taylor’s apartment.]

headline: Ahmaud Arbery’s Killing Will Go to Grand Jury as Graphic Video Emerges
abstract: Mr. Arbery, 25, was killed after two men pursued him in a South Georgia neighborhood, a confrontation that was caught on video. A prosecutor said charges should be considered in the case.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Gregory McMichael and Travis McMichael Have Been Charged with Murder in Killing of Ahmaud Arbery]

headline: Protests in Minnesota Renew Scrutiny of Klobuchar’s Record as Prosecutor
abstract: Amy Klobuchar, now being considered as a potential vice-presidential candidate, oversaw several cases involving police shootings in Minneapolis during her years as a prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: Senator Amy Klobuchar swept into office in 2007 as a former tough prosecutor, boasting of how she had reduced crime in the most populous county in Minnesota. But as protests over George Floyd’s death in police custody bring chaos and violence to Minneapolis, her record as prosecutor there is facing renewed scrutiny as she prepares to be vetted as a leading vice-presidential contender.

headline: A Justice Dept. Skeptical of Police Abuse Cases Vows to Investigate Floyd Death
abstract: Critics pointed to the president’s and the attorney general’s full-throated support for the police and the department’s inaction on systemic policing issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr on Friday labeled the images of the death of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis whom a white police officer knelt on for nearly nine minutes, as “harrowing” and “deeply disturbing” and vowed that the federal investigation into his death would proceed quickly.

headline: The Killing of Ahmaud Arbery
abstract: Another black man falsely assumed to be a criminal is dead.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Gregory McMichael and Travis McMichael Have Been Charged with Murder in the Killing of Ahmaud Arbery]

headline: Man Who Filmed Ahmaud Arbery’s Death Is Charged With Murder
abstract: The Georgia Bureau of Investigation arrested the man, William Bryan, who had recorded the fatal encounter in February.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The man who filmed the pursuit and shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, the 25-year-old black man who was killed after an encounter with two white men, was arrested on Thursday in connection with the killing, Georgia authorities said.

headline: Photos From the George Floyd Protests, City by City
abstract: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.

headline: News Quiz: George Floyd, Twitter, Coronavirus
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Protests Continue to Erupt in Cities Across the Country
abstract: Demonstrations raged overnight across the U.S. in the third night of unrest in response to George Floyd’s death in Minneapolis police custody.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations raged overnight across the U.S. in the third night of unrest in response to George Floyd’s death in Minneapolis police custody.

headline: Officer Who Pinned George Floyd Is Charged With Murder
abstract: Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who was seen on video using his knee to pin down George Floyd, was charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who was seen on video using his knee to pin down George Floyd, was charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter.

headline: ‘This Is No Time for Incendiary Tweets,’ Biden Says, Rebuking Trump
abstract: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the death of George Floyd, and condemned President Trump’s “shooting” remarks.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the death of George Floyd, and condemned President Trump’s “shooting” remarks.

headline: Protests in Minneapolis After George Floyd’s Death
abstract: Buildings burned in Minneapolis as anger intensified over the death of George Floyd, who died after being handcuffed and pinned by a police officer’s knee.
lead_paragraph: Buildings burned in Minneapolis as anger intensified over the death of George Floyd, who died after being handcuffed and pinned by a police officer’s knee.

headline: Protests, Calls for Justice in Georgia Over Ahmaud Arbery Killing
abstract: A crowd of protesters gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in Georgia to demand a thorough investigation into the killing of Ahmaud Arbery after a father and son were arrested, and charged with murder.
lead_paragraph: A crowd of protesters gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in Georgia to demand a thorough investigation into the killing of Ahmaud Arbery after a father and son were arrested, and charged with murder.

headline: Fiery Clashes Erupt Between Police and Protesters Over George Floyd Death
abstract: As standoffs intensified across the country on Saturday, officials in Minneapolis vowed to take a harder line against unrest in the streets.
lead_paragraph: This live briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

headline: The Citizen’s Arrest Law Cited in Arbery’s Killing Dates Back to the Civil War
abstract: Georgia has allowed its residents to arrest one another since 1863. But after the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, critics are calling for such laws to be repealed.
lead_paragraph: After Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead by two white men on a quiet residential road in coastal Georgia, a prosecutor cited a Civil War era state law to justify the killing.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery Video Was Leaked by a Lawyer Who Consulted With Suspects
abstract: The lawyer, Alan Tucker, declined to comment on his conversations with the suspects, citing attorney-client privilege. He later said he would not be representing them.
lead_paragraph: For weeks after Ahmaud Arbery was killed while running down a road in coastal southern Georgia, there were few public developments in the case of a 25-year-old unarmed black man who was shot while being pursued by two white men with weapons in February.

headline: Protests Continue to Rage After Death of George Floyd
abstract: Protesters breached a police station in Minneapolis and set it on fire, as demonstrations were reported across the country.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended.

headline: Man Who Filmed the Arbery Killing Faces Calls for Arrest
abstract: The man who recorded the fatal encounter is under investigation for his potential involvement in the pursuit of Ahmaud Arbery.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A South Georgia resident’s video of the killing of Ahmaud Arbery helped spark nationwide protests and revive law enforcement scrutiny of the case, resulting in murder charges against two men who chased and fatally shot Mr. Arbery.

headline: Investigators Say One Man Shot Ahmaud Arbery. Why Are Three Charged With Murder?
abstract: The authorities said Travis McMichael fired the fatal shots, yet his father and a neighbor also are charged with murder in connection with Mr. Arbery’s death.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Three shots were fired in the confrontation that killed Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was chased by white men as he ran through their southeastern Georgia neighborhood. The authorities said Travis McMichael, who with his father and a neighbor pursued Mr. Arbery, pulled the trigger.

headline: Trump’s Looting and ‘Shooting’ Remarks Escalate Crisis in Minneapolis
abstract: The president’s tweets prompted Twitter to append them with a note saying the posts were “glorifying violence.” Joe Biden condemned Mr. Trump, saying “it’s no time to encourage violence.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump issued a violent ultimatum to protesters in Minneapolis on Friday and inserted himself in a harshly divisive fashion into the crisis there, attacking the city’s Democratic mayor and raising the specter that the military could use armed force to suppress riots that erupted after the death of George Floyd, a black man, at the hands of a white police officer.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The Central Park bird watcher speaks. A re-examination of the chopstick. Farewell, Larry Kramer. Face-timing Pamela Anderson. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It’s been a hard week. The United States reached a grim milestone, and as we move into the weekend, the streets are on fire in Minneapolis as people protest the death of George Floyd. Here are some great articles you may have missed if you had to tune out a bit this week for your own well-being. So take a walk or get some coffee and settle in for some amazing journalism.

headline: In Ahmaud Arbery’s Hometown, Pain, Anger and Pride in a Shared Racial History
abstract: Brunswick, Ga., gained national attention during the civil rights era for the way black and white leaders had worked together to integrate peacefully.
lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — A 26-year-old black man stood on the steps of the old brick courthouse on Friday and decried the shooting death of another black man who would have turned 26 that day had he lived to see it. “That could have easily been me,” he said.

headline: Target Temporarily Closing or Shortening Hours at 200 Stores
abstract: The company said it acted to ensure employees’ safety. A store in Minneapolis, where Target is based, was badly damaged and looted last week.
lead_paragraph: Target is temporarily closing or shortening the hours of about 200 stores in the United States as protests and looting spread across country in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd.

headline: Investigators Call Evidence in the Ahmaud Arbery Shooting ‘Extremely Upsetting’
abstract: A father and son were arrested in connection with the Feb. 23 killing of Mr. Arbery, which had led to protests and 2.23-mile runs to show support under the hashtag #IRunWithMaud.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read about the troubled history of the Georgia police force that handled the Ahmaud Arbery case.

headline: Living Abroad Is My Way of Prolonging My Black Son’s Life
abstract: He is not a threat. He is a loving, innocent child. I can’t bear him becoming another hashtag.
lead_paragraph: Upon hearing the news of George Floyd’s killing at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer, I was devastated. Although I couldn’t bring myself to watch the video of his death, my anxiety went through the roof because I had seen this many, many times before.

headline: Bystander Videos of George Floyd and Others Are Policing the Police
abstract: The initial police account of the death of a Minneapolis man did not mention that an officer’s knee pinned him to the ground. “Please, I can’t breathe,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The Minneapolis police statement was short and sanitized. An allegation of forgery. A suspect who “appeared to be under the influence,” who “physically resisted officers” and who appeared to be “suffering medical distress.”

headline: Coronavirus, Iran, Jerry Stiller: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: For almost two months, the killing of Ahmaud Arbery received very little attention. Over the past two weeks, it has become a subject of national outrage.

headline: 2 Suspects Charged With Murder in Ahmaud Arbery Shooting
abstract: Gregory McMichael and Travis McMichael were arrested in connection with the killing of Mr. Arbery, which had led to protests in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The two white men who were seen on a widely shared video as one of them fatally shot Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man, were arrested and charged on Thursday in connection with the shooting — two days after the graphic footage became public and more than two months after the killing itself.

headline: Coronavirus, Ahmaud Arbery, Michael Flynn: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The world is entering a very risky period with the coronavirus — and many health experts and ordinary people are nervous.

headline: George Floyd and the Fury in Minneapolis
abstract: Readers hear echoes of the Eric Garner case and are thankful for the video evidence.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Officer Charged in Death of George Floyd in Minneapolis
abstract: City officials on Friday were urging calm the day after protests turned violent and a police precinct went up in flames.
lead_paragraph: A white former Minneapolis police officer was charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter on Friday after a shocking video of him kneeling for nearly nine minutes on the neck of a black man set off a wave of protests across the country.

headline: Black Journalists Are Exhausted
abstract: But we keep on keeping on.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, when I first pitched this essay about the unique stressors that many black journalists experience while covering the coronavirus pandemic, I pointed to the glaring racial disparities in deaths, the over-policing of black New Yorkers and Chicagoans, and the killings of Breonna Taylor, Douglas C. Lewis and Ahmaud Arbery.

headline: National Guard Called as Minneapolis Erupts in Solidarity for George Floyd
abstract: Violence in the streets prompted officials to call in troops and vow a swift federal review of the arrest.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Minnesota’s governor activated the National Guard on Thursday as angry demonstrators took to the streets for a third straight night to protest the death of George Floyd, a black man who was pleading that he could not breathe as a white police officer pressed his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck.

headline: Ahmaud Arbery’s Final Minutes: What Videos and 911 Calls Show
abstract: Using security footage, cellphone video, 911 calls and police reports, The Times has reconstructed the 12 minutes before Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead in Georgia on Feb. 23, 2020.
lead_paragraph: Using security footage, cellphone video, 911 calls and police reports, The Times has reconstructed the 12 minutes before Ahmaud Arbery was shot dead in Georgia on Feb. 23, 2020.

headline: Minneapolis Precinct Fire: How a Night of Chaos Unfolded
abstract: Videographers for The Times captured the scene outside the Third Precinct in Minneapolis as peaceful demonstrations over the death of George Floyd turned violent, and a group of protesters set the building on fire.
lead_paragraph: Videographers for The Times captured the scene outside the Third Precinct in Minneapolis as peaceful demonstrations over the death of George Floyd turned violent, and a group of protesters set the building on fire.

headline: Minnesota Governor Fully Mobilizes State National Guard
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said he would activate the state’s entire National Guard for the first time in its history in response to protests ignited by George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said he would activate the state’s entire National Guard for the first time in its history in response to protests ignited by George Floyd’s death.

headline: Protests in Los Angeles Over Police Violence
abstract: Demonstrations broke out across the country in response to the death of George Floyd. In Los Angeles, protesters shut down freeways and faced off with police officers.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations broke out across the country in response to the death of George Floyd. In Los Angeles, protesters shut down freeways and faced off with police officers.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Is ‘Entitled To Justice,’ Trump Says
abstract: President Trump said the Department of Justice would expedite the investigation into George Floyd’s death, and that Minneapolis should not “descend further into lawless anarchy and chaos.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump said the Department of Justice would expedite the investigation into George Floyd’s death, and that Minneapolis should not “descend further into lawless anarchy and chaos.”

headline: Minnesota Needs to ‘Get Tougher’ on Protesters, Trump Says
abstract: President Trump criticized Minnesota officials’ response to protests over the death of George Floyd, offering to send military troops to the state.
lead_paragraph: President Trump criticized Minnesota officials’ response to protests over the death of George Floyd, offering to send military troops to the state.

headline: George Floyd Protests Escalate in Minneapolis
abstract: Protests over the death of George Floyd, an African-American man who died in police custody, have intensified in Minneapolis. Some have turned violent, with the police firing tear gas and rubber bullets and people setting buildings on fire.
lead_paragraph: Protests over the death of George Floyd, an African-American man who died in police custody, have intensified in Minneapolis. Some have turned violent, with the police firing tear gas and rubber bullets and people setting buildings on fire.

headline: Violence at Breonna Taylor Protest in Louisville
abstract: Seven people were shot in Louisville, Ky., at protests against the police for the killing of Breonna Taylor, a black woman fatally shot by white officers in March.
lead_paragraph: Seven people were shot in Louisville, Ky., at protests against the police for the killing of Breonna Taylor, a black woman fatally shot by white officers in March.

headline: ‘We Have to Do This Right,’ Says Prosecutor in George Floyd Case
abstract: Mike Freeman, the county attorney in Minneapolis, urged patience as his office investigates Mr. Floyd’s death while in police custody. State and federal officials are also conducting inquiries.
lead_paragraph: Mike Freeman, the county attorney in Minneapolis, urged patience as his office investigates Mr. Floyd’s death while in police custody. State and federal officials are also conducting inquiries.

headline: Protesters Clash With Police in Union Square
abstract: At least 40 people were arrested as demonstrators surged into Union Square in New York City to protest what they called police brutality in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: At least 40 people were arrested as demonstrators surged into Union Square in New York City to protest what they called police brutality in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death in Minneapolis.

headline: Londoners Join in Protests Against Police Brutality
abstract: Hundreds of protesters rallied in central London and marched to the United States Embassy in support of demonstrations across the U.S. that were set off by the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of protesters rallied in central London and marched to the United States Embassy in support of demonstrations across the U.S. that were set off by the death of George Floyd.

headline: What Happened in the Chaotic Moments Before George Floyd Died
abstract: The episode began with a report of a $20 counterfeit bill. It ended in a fatal encounter with the police, which the authorities have described in detail for the first time.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — One was a veteran of the Minneapolis Police Department who moonlighted as a security guard. The other provided security at a Salvation Army store, and spent some of his evenings at local clubs, working as a bouncer.

headline: The Persistence of Police Killings
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: During a six-month span in 2014, four separate police killings of African-Americans grabbed the country’s attention. Eric Garner died after being put in a chokehold in New York, while Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.; Laquan McDonald in Chicago; and 12-year-old Tamir Rice in Cleveland were all shot.

headline: The Shooting of Ahmaud Arbery
abstract: A 25-year-old black man was pursued and killed. But no one was arrested until a video of the confrontation was released months later.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Ahmaud Arbery and the America That Doesn’t Exist
abstract: Black Americans need more than a trial and a verdict.
lead_paragraph: WHEATON, Ill. — Football does not prepare its athletes for a life of fitness. Its drills and exercises are meant to harden the body for collisions. After our playing days are over, we must find new ways to keep our bodies in shape.

headline: What Trump, Biden and Obama Said About the Death of George Floyd
abstract: Both President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. have called for justice for Mr. Floyd. Mr. Trump has also called protesters “thugs,” and Mr. Biden has blamed him for “incendiary tweets.”
lead_paragraph: The death of George Floyd, which set off huge and sometimes violent protests in Minneapolis, drew responses on Friday from President Trump, his predecessor and the man who hopes to succeed him.

headline: Charges Recommended Against 3 Officers Involved in Violent N.Y. Arrest
abstract: The departmental charges would be in connection with a May 2 incident in the East Village during which an officer sat on a man’s neck.
lead_paragraph: Investigators with the New York Police Department have recommended misconduct charges against three police officers, including one who sat and knelt on the neck and upper torso of a man he was arresting, a maneuver similar to the one used in the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, two people familiar with the matter said.

headline: In George Floyd’s Death, a Police Technique Results in a Too-Familiar Tragedy
abstract: Police departments have tried to ban or severely limit the use of chokeholds and neck restraints. But in Minneapolis, a knee pressing on a neck led to a man’s death.
