headline: Gunshots Ring Out in George Floyd Square on Anniversary of His Death
abstract: A series of gunshots sparked panic on Tuesday morning as people gathered to pay respects at the site of where George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis a year ago.
lead_paragraph: A series of gunshots sparked panic on Tuesday morning as people gathered to pay respects at the site of where George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis a year ago.

headline: New York Leaders Honor George Floyd
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York and the Rev. Al Sharpton held a ceremony to honor George Floyd on the one-year anniversary of his death.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York and the Rev. Al Sharpton held a ceremony to honor George Floyd on the one-year anniversary of his death.

headline: Protesters Gather in Brooklyn to Rally for Changes to Policing
abstract: Protesters marched in Brooklyn on Tuesday to commemorate George Floyd, who was killed in police custody one year ago, and to build momentum for changes and accountability in policing.
lead_paragraph: Protesters marched in Brooklyn on Tuesday to commemorate George Floyd, who was killed in police custody one year ago, and to build momentum for changes and accountability in policing.

headline: New York Demonstrators Detained After Blocking Holland Tunnel
abstract: A small group of Black Lives Matter protesters was arrested on Tuesday, including the mayoral candidate Shaun Donovan, after blocking the Holland Tunnel in a march on the one-year anniversary of the police killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: A small group of Black Lives Matter protesters was arrested on Tuesday, including the mayoral candidate Shaun Donovan, after blocking the Holland Tunnel in a march on the one-year anniversary of the police killing of George Floyd.

headline: A Timeline of What Has Happened in the Year Since George Floyd’s Death
abstract: A look back at what has transpired in the year since Mr. Floyd’s murder reveals a country both struggling to confront it history of racial division and continuing to succumb to it.
lead_paragraph: George Floyd, a 46-year-old African-American man, is killed on a street corner in Minneapolis after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by Derek Chauvin and other officers responding to a forgery call. Darnella Frazier, a 17-year-old, turns on her cellphone to capture video of Mr. Chauvin, who is white, using his knee to pin Mr. Floyd by his neck. Mr. Floyd is heard repeatedly saying, “I can’t breathe.”

headline: Tamir Rice’s Mother Asks Court to Block Rehiring of Officer Who Killed Her Son
abstract: Samaria Rice wants the Ohio Supreme Court to keep the man who killed her son in 2014 from being reinstated as a Cleveland police officer. The former officer, Timothy Loehmann, was never charged.
lead_paragraph: The mother of Tamir Rice, the 12-year-old Black boy who was fatally shot by a white police officer in Cleveland in 2014, is asking the Ohio Supreme Court to prevent the man who killed her son from being reinstated as an officer.

headline: Artists in a Post-George Floyd, Mid-Pandemic World
abstract: Two new exhibitions at Mass MoCA created over the past year offer insights into our new normal.
lead_paragraph: Two shows that recently opened at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art are keyed to our new normal: One came into being during the most restrictive moments of the pandemic; the other, though long planned, shifted its focus as these past, momentous months unfolded. Conceptually, both address the questions — personal and political — that are on many minds at the moment.

headline: A Year After George Floyd: Pressure to Add Police Amid Rising Crime
abstract: Los Angeles, like other cities across the nation, is facing a rise in gun violence. And the police budget is growing.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Helen Jones grew up in Watts in a time of gang wars and a crack epidemic, when the police used battering rams to knock down the walls of suspected drug houses and Black people were routinely profiled or beaten by street cops.

headline: Darnella Frazier, the teenager who recorded George Floyd’s murder, speaks out.
abstract: “I still hold the weight and trauma of what I witnessed a year ago,” she said. “A part of my childhood was taken from me.”
lead_paragraph: Darnella Frazier, the young woman who took out her cellphone on a Minneapolis street to record a video of a white police officer as he knelt on George Floyd’s neck that would ricochet around the world, released a powerful statement on Tuesday addressing the first anniversary of Mr. Floyd’s death.

headline: ‘I Knew That I Couldn’t Stay Quiet’
abstract: Millions of Americans took part in street demonstrations after the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. A year later, first-time protesters reflect on what happened — and what is next.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, millions of Americans took to the streets after the killing of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police, taking part in what would become the largest protest movement in U.S. history. Many participated in marches and demonstrations for the first time in their lives. From eight first-time protesters, here are reflections on what they did last summer, how this has affected them in the year since and what lies ahead. Their interviews have been edited and condensed.

headline: Did You Join a Protest for the First Time Last Year? Share Your Story
abstract: The protests that followed the killing of George Floyd were the largest in U.S. history. We want to hear from people who were moved to demonstrate for the first time.
lead_paragraph: We are approaching one year since the death of George Floyd at the hands of police set off the largest protest movement in U.S. history.

headline: Gaza, George Floyd, Eurovision: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: The anniversary of George Floyd’s killing.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday marked one year since George Floyd was killed during a police arrest after he went to buy cigarettes. What followed was an uprising for racial justice nearly unparalleled in American history.

headline: How Plywood From Last Year’s Protests Became Art
abstract: During the George Floyd marches last year, businesses boarded up. This year, hundreds of those boards will be displayed in exhibitions in Minneapolis, New York and Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The morning in April before a Minneapolis jury found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of murdering George Floyd, Leesa Kelly woke up from a nightmare. As she had done many times over the past year, she cried out feelings of anger and hopelessness.

headline: Gunshots and a panic at George Floyd Square.
abstract: Dozens of activists and bystanders paying their respects at the site where Mr. Floyd was killed ran from the area on Tuesday morning after a series of loud bangs rang out.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Dozens of activists and bystanders paying their respects at George Floyd Square in Minneapolis ran from the area on Tuesday after a series of loud bangs rang out, raising fears that shots were being fired.

headline: A Cry of ‘I Can’t Breathe’ United a Generation in a Gasp for Justice
abstract: Emmett Till’s death helped inspire America’s Second Reconstruction. George Floyd’s galvanized the third.
lead_paragraph: In Elizabeth City, N.C., the morning after a jury in Minneapolis found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of the murder of George Floyd, a unit from the county’s Sheriff’s Department dressed in tactical gear arrived at the home of Andrew Brown Jr. They were there to serve drug-related arrest and search warrants.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Meets With Biden Amid Push for Police Reform
abstract: The family said the president vowed to pass a police reform bill and promised justice not only for Mr. Floyd but for a nation still reeling from a year of killings and protests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a private meeting at the White House on Tuesday, President Biden renewed the promise he made to the family of George Floyd just hours after a Minneapolis police officer was convicted of murder in his death.

headline: Support for Black Lives Matter Surged Last Year. Did It Last?
abstract: The topline numbers hide important trends by race and political party.
lead_paragraph: The moment was called “a racial reckoning.” Multiracial crowds of protesters took to the streets to call for racial justice. Books about racism soared to the top of best-seller lists. And surveys suggested that white Americans, many of whom had long opposed efforts to advance the goals of racial equality, were having a change of heart.

headline: George Floyd, Moderna, Brood X: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: N.J. Teacher Suspended After Calling George Floyd a ‘Criminal’
abstract: The New Jersey high school teacher, Howard Zlotkin, has been suspended with pay after appearing to target Black students in an online class.
lead_paragraph: Students at a New Jersey high school logged into their remote landscape and design class on Wednesday morning expecting their teacher to lead a discussion about climate change. Instead, the teacher went on an expletive-filled, racist rant against Black Lives Matter and George Floyd, the man murdered by a Minneapolis police officer.

headline: Washington State Enacts Police Reform a Year After George Floyd’s Death
abstract: Gov. Jay Inslee signed 12 bills into law that include bans on chokeholds and no-knock warrants, making Washington the latest state to pass sweeping police reforms.
lead_paragraph: Washington became the latest state to enact sweeping police reforms in response to the police killing of George Floyd with the adoption this week of 12 new laws that ban chokeholds, require officers to announce their presence before raiding a home and call for the use of exhaustive de-escalation techniques before resorting to force.

headline: The Netherlands’ Eurovision entry featured a Black Lives Matter moment.
abstract: Jeangu Macrooy, the Netherlands’ entry, takes the stage to sing “Birth of a New Age,” a song penned in response to the police killing of George Floyd and the subsequent resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Jeangu Macrooy, the Netherlands’ entry, takes the stage to sing “Birth of a New Age,” a song penned in response to the police killing of George Floyd and the subsequent resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement worldwide.

headline: Derek Chauvin’s Lawyer Asks for a New Trial After Guilty Verdict
abstract: The expected legal motion came on the same day that one of the jurors was being criticized for his participation in the March on Washington last year.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for the former Minneapolis police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd filed a motion on Tuesday asking for a new trial on several grounds, including jury misconduct.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Oslo’ and Specials Honoring George Floyd
abstract: A film adaptation of J.T. Rogers’s Tony-winning play airs on HBO. And several specials recognize the anniversary of George Floyd’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 24-30. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Young Americans, How Has George Floyd’s Death Influenced Your Life?
abstract: We want to hear from readers under 30 about their changing views of race and racism.
lead_paragraph: Darnella Frazier was just 17 when she recorded a video that shook the world. Her cellphone video, uploaded to Facebook, captured Derek Chauvin kneeling on George Floyd’s neck and upended the Minneapolis Police Department’s official narrative of the encounter, ultimately contributing to a guilty verdict.

headline: The Obamas Are Freed in Their Blackness
abstract: They can finally be just as angry and unsettled as the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, “CBS This Morning” will air a longer interview between Gayle King and the former first lady Michelle Obama. In a portion already released, Ms. Obama discussed the statement that she and former President Barack Obama issued after Derek Chauvin was found guilty of murdering George Floyd.

headline: Biden will meet with George Floyd’s family on the anniversary of his death.
abstract: The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act is languishing in Congress, but the White House is optimistic that legislative talks will help move it forward.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will meet on Tuesday with relatives of George Floyd to mark the anniversary of his death and the start of a nationwide racial reckoning against police brutality.

headline: It’s My Job to Watch. With George Floyd’s Death, I Had to Look Away.
abstract: Devastated by the Rodney King verdict decades ago, our critic refused to view the video of Floyd’s murder. But she found solace in the art it inspired.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never watched the video of George Floyd’s murder. My decision wasn’t premeditated or preordained, but rather an improvised refusal. I did not want to be another spectator of that oldest of American rituals: the killing of a Black person in public.

headline: 8 Ways a Modern Civil Rights Movement Moved the Culture
abstract: From music to movies, canceled podcasts to toppled monuments, our writers take stock of the culture we shared in the year after George Floyd’s murder.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, 2020, George Floyd was murdered under the knee of a white police officer, who is now in prison. Even so, a year later — after Americans protested and posted black squares on social media; after calls for the convictions of the officers who killed Breonna Taylor and other Black Americans went unanswered — the question remains: After the most significant civil rights movement in the lifetime of many of us, how much has changed? When the dust settles, what of the uprising persists?

headline: The Venice Biennale, Twice Delayed, Takes On New Relevance
abstract: A celebration of architecture focuses on how, together, we can live now.
lead_paragraph: Hashim Sarkis, curator of this year’s Venice Architecture Biennale, developed its theme — “How Will We Live Together?” — long before Covid-19 had made us deathly afraid of one another, before the murder of George Floyd sparked worldwide unrest and before flag-waving rioters stormed the U.S. Capitol. His choice, it’s now clear, was remarkably prescient.

headline: How to Turn Protest Power Into Political Power
abstract: Two civil rights activists and organizers in St. Louis lay out their tactics and tools for pursuing electoral justice.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Last year, the world watched for nine minutes and 29 seconds as a video showed the final moments of George Floyd’s life. We all heard Mr. Floyd plead with the police as he gasped for enough air to repeat the words “I can’t breathe” more than 20 times. In the weeks that followed his death, as many as 26 million people took to the streets in defense of Black lives.

headline: ‘On the Ashes of Tragedy’: Mixed Emotions on Anniversary of George Floyd’s Death
abstract: The crowds that gathered in Minneapolis and elsewhere reflected on what has changed, and what has not, in America since Mr. Floyd was murdered by a police officer.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live news coverage of Derek Chauvin’s sentencing hearing.]

headline: After a Traumatizing Year, Black People Turn to Therapy
abstract: The death of George Floyd and other high-profile police killings have prompted African-Americans to seek help, mental health experts say.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, mental health experts across the country say they have seen African-Americans, whose skepticism of therapy has been documented by research, seeking it in growing numbers.

headline: Former Police Officers Indicted on Civil Rights Charges in George Floyd’s Death
abstract: The indictment was a rare instance of police officers facing accusations of federal civil rights violations.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live coverage of the civil rights trial against three ex-police officers in the killing of George Floyd.]

headline: A Year After George Floyd’s Murder
abstract: Readers reflect on the occasion of George Floyd's killing a year ago. Also: The altering of girls' yearbook photos; psychotherapy offered by drugstores; aging well.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What 14 Trump Voters Think About George Floyd’s Legacy
abstract: Trump voters discuss race  in America.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the first anniversary of George Floyd’s death on May 25, my Times Opinion colleagues and I began planning articles from civil rights leaders, academics and others to explore Mr. Floyd’s legacy, the impact of the Black Lives Matter movement and race in America. We also asked younger people to tell us, in their own words, what changed — and didn’t — after his death.

headline: If Only There Were a Viral Video of Our Jim Crow Education System
abstract: The George Floyd case may represent a milestone of progress in criminal justice. But can we expand this recognition of unfairness and inequity to other spheres?
lead_paragraph: We in the commentariat have leapt at covering police violence against Black citizens since George Floyd’s murder a year ago, but I don’t think we’ve been as good at responding to other inequities that cost a far greater number of lives.

headline: One Year Later
abstract: On the anniversary of George Floyd’s murder, we examine its legacy so far.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after 8 p.m. on May 25, 2020, Derek Chauvin, a Minneapolis police officer, placed his knee on George Floyd’s neck and kept it there for more than nine minutes. None of the three other officers standing near Chauvin intervened. Soon, Floyd was dead.

headline: A Year After George Floyd, Los Angeles Confronts Its Future and Its Past
abstract: Tuesday: Los Angeles has been struggling to respond to both calls for racial justice and a surge in gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The People in the Neighborhood
abstract: A powerful — and revealing — aspect of the Derek Chauvin trial was the community it created out of strangers.
lead_paragraph: Weeks later, we’re still thinking about the witnesses in the trial of Derek Chauvin, and the way they were connected in telling the story of how George Floyd lost his life. This phenomenon is reflected in works of art, like Spike Lee’s “Do the Right Thing,” which explores the conflict inherent in a community.

headline: ‘We Still Aren’t Safe’: 6 Young Americans on George Floyd’s Death
abstract: Readers share the effects of George Floyd’s death on their perceptions of race and racism.
lead_paragraph: The nationwide protests that followed George Floyd’s death last May hinted at a possible turning point in the way many Americans confront issues of racial injustice. How much has really changed, though?

headline: May 25 Should Be a Day of Mourning for George Floyd
abstract: There is an intimate yet still unexplored relationship between mourning and democracy.
lead_paragraph: When the protests started in the streets of Denver last spring, days after George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis, I watched dozens of people marching with anguish and affliction on their faces. Several of them were crying, or clearly had been. When I watched the video of the final moments of Mr. Floyd’s life, I myself felt the telltale symptoms of grief: a clenched stomach; a surge of adrenaline; and an overwhelming sense of powerlessness.

headline: How New Yorkers Marked the Anniversary of George Floyd’s Killing
abstract: Demonstrations across the city took on varied tones throughout the day, a mix of frustration, celebration and sadness.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: The Murder of George Floyd, One Year On
abstract: Times Opinion is publishing a special series on George Floyd and America, a year after his death.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: Derek Chauvin Appears Likely to Plead Guilty to Federal Crimes
abstract: A change of plea hearing has been set for Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who was found guilty of murdering George Floyd in April.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A federal court on Monday set a hearing for Derek Chauvin to change his plea, signaling that the former Minneapolis police officer who was convicted of murdering George Floyd intended to plead guilty to charges that he also deprived Mr. Floyd of his civil rights.

headline: To Rein In the Police, Look to the States, Not the Court
abstract: The police almost always win in cases before the Supreme Court. Protections against police overreach will need to come from the state and local level.
lead_paragraph: After the tragic killing of George Floyd, protests against police violence emerged in all 50 states. These conspicuous calls for change contributed to a sense that finally, the country’s leaders would take action to rein in police violence, which disproportionately affects people of color.

headline: Meet the Next Big Fashion Group
abstract: Kerby Jean-Raymond has spent the last year and a half secretly trying to change the game for minority designers.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, when the United States was being roiled by the aftermath of the George Floyd murder and businesses of all kinds were coming face to face with their own systemic racism, Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder and designer of Pyer Moss, who has used his brand to shed light on Black history as well as police brutality, began to get a lot of calls.

headline: Texas Board Withdraws Clemency Recommendation for George Floyd
abstract: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles said it had made “procedural errors” when it issued a recommendation that Mr. Floyd be posthumously pardoned for a 2004 drug conviction.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles has withdrawn a recommendation that George Floyd be granted a posthumous pardon for a 2004 drug conviction in Houston, citing “procedural errors” in the recommendation.

headline: California’s Reparations Task Force Meets Again
abstract: The first-in-the-nation effort is tackling fraught questions about who deserves payment and how much.
lead_paragraph: After the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, as the nation grappled with how to right a long history of wrongs, California took a momentous step in the name of racial equity.

headline: The Fashion Institute of Technology Will Open a Social Justice Center
abstract: With nearly $4 million in funding, the school wants to build a pipeline of diverse fashion talent from middle school to the C-suite.
lead_paragraph: Change takes time: That was the sentiment underlying many corporate responses in the wake of George Floyd’s murder in 2020, as the fashion industry, among others, faced new calls for systemic change.

headline: Derek Chauvin Pleads Guilty to Violating George Floyd’s Rights
abstract: A federal prosecutor said he would ask a judge to sentence Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, to 25 years in prison, extending his state prison term by two and a half years.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Derek Chauvin pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a federal charge that he used his position as a Minneapolis police officer to violate George Floyd’s constitutional rights, a move expected to extend Mr. Chauvin’s time in prison beyond a decades-long state sentence for murdering Mr. Floyd.

headline: A Painting of George Floyd Roils Catholic University
abstract: At the Catholic University of America in Washington, conservative students called for a campus ban on further displays of an artwork that depicts Floyd as Jesus.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, shortly after the murder of George Floyd, Kelly Latimore, a white artist who grew up surrounded by images of a white Jesus, decided to make a course correction. He’d paint the Virgin Mary and Jesus with gold halos encircling their heads — and both would be Black.

headline: Sherrilyn Ifill: ‘There Is No Guarantee We Make It Out of This Period as a Democracy’
abstract: After almost a decade at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Ifill explains why advocacy is an essential part of her legal work.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted on all charges related to the shooting of two people at a Black Lives Matter protest in Kenosha, Wisc. Before, during and after the trial, journalists and pundits broke down the most sensational moments on the stand, and many tried to discern what Rittenhouse’s not-guilty decision meant about the country at large. People were eager to draw direct connections between the arguments used in court and the inequities that are seen in the country on a daily basis.

headline: Some Jan. 6 Rioters May Use Police Brutality as a Defense
abstract: Half a dozen defendants in the assault on the Capitol are using video to try to make a case that they were simply protecting themselves and others. They face skepticism and an uphill legal battle.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the Jan. 6 Capitol Attack Anniversary.

headline: Suzi Analogue Wants Black Women in Experimental Music to Never Compromise
abstract: She couldn’t find a label that understood her work, so she started her own. Now she’s doubling down on her mission to provide a home for others who want to create with total freedom.
lead_paragraph: The Black Lives Matter protests of 2020 put renewed pressure on the music industry to scrutinize its long-troubled relationship with race. It’s a business that has relied on Black talent onstage without investing in Black executives behind the scenes; a space where Black artists have been nudged into specific genres and ways of creating; a place where women and L.G.B.T. people of color have been even further marginalized.

headline: Minneapolis Police Release Body Camera Video of Its First Killing Since George Floyd
abstract: The video shows a man raising something to his car window before a bang is heard. An officer ducks for cover and then fires several rounds at the man.
lead_paragraph: The Minneapolis Police Department released body camera footage on Thursday that shed new light on a fatal police shooting the night before, the first killing by a city police officer since George Floyd’s death in the spring.

headline: N.Y. Attorney General Sues N.Y.P.D. Over Protests and Demands Monitor
abstract: Letitia James says the police have used illegal and harmful tactics for years, and wants a federal monitor to oversee the department’s tactics at future demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general sued the New York City Police Department on Thursday over what she said were widespread abuses in how officers handled the protests that erupted last summer after the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

headline: For These Classical Musicians, It’s Always Been About Racial Equity
abstract: The work now being taken up by large institutions has long been the purpose of many smaller ones. We spoke with seven of them.
lead_paragraph: Last year was different. Black Lives Matter, in the national psyche for nearly a decade, crested with the killing of George Floyd and weeks of widespread demonstrations that could no longer be ignored — even by classical music. Orchestras and opera companies posted statements of solidarity, however platitudinous, denouncing racism and promising a more equitable future for an industry that has historically been led by white administrators and designed to maintain a status quo that gives white artists the advantage over their underrepresented peers.

headline: ‘I Answered the Call of My President’: Rioters Say Trump Urged Them On
abstract: The defense from Trump supporters arrested in the Capitol assault is emerging in court papers and interviews — and could play a role in impeachment proceedings.
lead_paragraph: In the two weeks since a raging mob stormed the Capitol, President Trump has shown no sign that he believes he shares responsibility for the worst incursion on the halls of Congress in more than two centuries. Shielding him further, his loyalists have started shifting blame for the attack to an array of distracting bogeymen: far-left anti-fascists, Black Lives Matter activists, even vague conspiracies of a setup involving Vice President Mike Pence.

headline: Traveling With a Purpose: For Some, It’s a 2021 Resolution
abstract: The crises of 2020, particularly the pandemic and violence against Black Americans, have caused many travelers to rethink how and where to travel.
lead_paragraph: Every year, John Shackelford, 26, a bicycle messenger in New York City, takes what he calls a “tour,” or long-distance ride with friends. Following a summer of social unrest sparked by the murders of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and other Black Americans at the hands of police, the 2020 tour, he decided, would travel roughly 1,100 miles from Mobile, Ala., to Washington, D.C., visiting places associated with Black history, including Civil Rights landmarks, history museums and memorials such as the National Memorial for Peace and Justice in Montgomery, Ala. The pandemic was an obstacle to visiting some sites, but not enough to hold back the ride.

headline: Are We Stuck With Trump in the White House?
abstract: Let’s talk about options to remove him, and to change norms.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember Martin Gugino? He was the 75-year-old man who in June was peacefully supporting a Black Lives Matter protest in Buffalo when police officers shoved him to the ground, cracking his skull and damaging his brain.

headline: We’ve Seen the Ugly Truth About America
abstract: But if the Democrats dare to use their power, a brave new world might be possible.
lead_paragraph: There are two images. In one, National Guard troops, most with no identifying information on their uniforms, stand on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in anticipation of violence from people peacefully protesting the killing of George Floyd. In the second image, thousands of protesters — domestic terrorists, really — swarm the Capitol. They wear red MAGA hats and carry Trump flags and show their faces because they want to be seen. They don’t seem to fear the consequences of being identified. More images — a man sitting in Nancy Pelosi’s office, his feet on a desk, a smirk on his face. A man carrying a stolen lectern, smiling at the camera. A man in the Senate chamber doing parkour.

headline: Listen to Rudolph: A New Year Is Both a Comfort and a Fiction
abstract: A 1976 TV movie that imagined years as people is a helpful reminder that a new page on the calendar is an arbitrary creation.
lead_paragraph: If 2020 were a person, what would it look like? I imagine someone tired, ravaged, beaten down by illness and police brutality, and weary from trying to stay afloat in a sinking economy. We’ve personified 2020 in articles and memes and GIFs, speaking of it as though it were a living, breathing antagonist in our collective story. And this past New Year’s celebration was not so much about the birth of a new year as about the death of an old one that no one asked for.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Capitol Breach Puts the Police Under Scrutiny
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 8, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “No one can tell me that if it had been a group of Black Lives Matter protesting yesterday, they wouldn’t have been treated very, very differently than the mob of thugs that stormed the Capitol.”

headline: A Nation in Pain: ‘The Daily’ Covers the Effects of Centuries of Systemic Racism in the U.S.
abstract: Listen to a collection of episodes on “The Daily” that examine the public reckoning with racial injustice in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Against the backdrop of a pandemic and economic crisis, the summer of 2020 became a season of protest after the killing of George Floyd and other Black Americans by the police. “The Daily” shared with its listeners the voices of people who rose up in anger and anguish as the country grappled with the legacy of police brutality and racial justice.

headline: Movies to Stream for Martin Luther King Jr. Day
abstract: Seven recent films help commemorate King’s legacy in fighting for racial justice.
lead_paragraph: With each year since it was designated as a holiday in 1983, Martin Luther King Jr. Day has carried new yet immovable significance. It did so the year following Rodney King’s 1991 assault. It did so in the years following the deaths of Oscar Grant, Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown and Freddie Gray. And now, following the past year’s deaths of Representative John Lewis and the Rev. C.T. Vivian, the killings of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, the arrival of the summer’s Black Lives Matter protests, the November presidential election and this month’s storming of the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob, the holiday carries that much more meaning. In our government, in our elections, and in our law enforcement the signs of racism still lurk.

headline: Police response to Capitol mob is in striking contrast to protests after George Floyd killing.
abstract: During the protests after the killing of George Floyd in May, President Trump vowed to “dominate” demonstrators, calling them “extremists” and “thugs,” while federal agents deployed tear gas and swept people into unmarked vans.
lead_paragraph: During the protests after the killing of George Floyd in May, President Trump vowed to “dominate” demonstrators, calling them “extremists” and “thugs,” while federal agents deployed tear gas and swept people into unmarked vans.

headline: Relatives of Jacob Blake Jr. and Breonna Taylor hope to push Biden on police reform.
abstract: Among those attending the inauguration were the relatives of Black victims of police violence. Jacob Blake, whose son, Jacob Blake Jr., was shot and gravely wounded by a police officer in Kenosha, Wis., Justin Blake, the uncle of the younger Jacob, and Bianca Austin, the aunt of Breonna Taylor, who was fatally shot in a botched raid by the Louisville police, attended together.
lead_paragraph: Among those attending the inauguration were the relatives of Black victims of police violence. Jacob Blake, whose son, Jacob Blake Jr., was shot and gravely wounded by a police officer in Kenosha, Wis., Justin Blake, the uncle of the younger Jacob, and Bianca Austin, the aunt of Breonna Taylor, who was fatally shot in a botched raid by the Louisville police, attended together.

headline: $200,000 Settlement for Texas Man Pepper-Sprayed While Recording Son’s Traffic Stop
abstract: An alleged racial profiling of a Latino man quickly escalated and led to the demotion of a police sergeant.
lead_paragraph: A city in Texas has agreed to a $200,000 settlement of a lawsuit alleging civil rights violations and police brutality brought by a man who was pepper-sprayed twice while recording his son during a traffic stop over the summer.

headline: Bomb Explodes at California Church Known for Hateful Views
abstract: Officials said no one was injured in the attack. The church had been the target of protests over its messages against women, Jews, L.G.B.T.Q. people and the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. and local authorities are investigating a bombing on Saturday morning at a church in Los Angeles County that had recently been the target of protests for its extremist views against L.G.B.T.Q. people, women and the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: ‘People Are Complex.’ Meet 3 Generations of a Georgia Family.
abstract: Leading up to the state’s U.S. Senate runoffs, the Gamel family shared their thoughts on voting and the current political climate.
lead_paragraph: Wulf Bradley has spent the past year capturing Georgia for the history books: from photographing the George Floyd protests in Atlanta to taking Stacey Abrams’s portrait.

headline: Woman Dies After Driver Hits Crowd in Minneapolis
abstract: The group was gathered on Sunday night to protest police brutality. Three other people were injured, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A woman was killed and three people were injured in Minneapolis late Sunday after a man drove a car into a group of people who had gathered for a vigil against police brutality, the police said.

headline: Juneteenth Was Supposed to Be a Holiday for N.Y.C. Workers. Not Anymore.
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed last year that Juneteenth would be an official holiday. City workers learned this week they would not be getting a paid day off after all.
lead_paragraph: When George Floyd was murdered by the police last May, galvanizing protests for racial justice, efforts to recognize Juneteenth — the day commemorating the end of slavery in the United States — picked up steam across the country.

headline: Philonise Floyd, George Floyd’s brother, asks the judge to give Derek Chauvin the maximum sentence.
abstract: “I was a trucker and immediately my life changed forever,” said Philonise Floyd, who became the main spokesman for the Floyd family since his death. “I began to speak to the world for George.”
lead_paragraph: Philonise Floyd, a brother of George Floyd who became the main spokesman for the Floyd family since his death, pleaded with a judge on Friday to give Derek Chauvin the maximum sentence for killing his brother.

headline: Judge narrows lawsuits over clearing of protesters before a Trump photo op.
abstract: The judge said that federal officials had immunity, and that claims of a conspiracy to clear Lafayette Square for President Donald J. Trump’s walk across it were “simply too speculative.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday partly dismissed claims filed by Black Lives Matter, the American Civil Liberties Union and others accusing the Trump administration of abusing its power to violently disperse a protest outside the White House last year.

headline: Greenwood Rising Links Tulsa’s Tragic History to Today’s Struggles
abstract: Throughout the South, fluid new museums serve as memorial markers too. Greenwood Rising follows a neighborhood’s history into the present.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — How do you best memorialize epochal heroes and happenings? You raise a statue, put up a plaque, right? But history isn’t containable in objects. It’s a slow, leaky, dirty-bomb explosion. An event like the George Floyd murder may look like a sudden flame that’s lit a fuse, but in fact that fuse has been uncoiling, and flaring, and smoldering for generations, and will continue to.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Never Forget Me’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Black ink streaked Renny’s soggy poster, blurring the letters in “Black Lives Matter.” After a period of distance, we had reunited in his condo, making posters on top of the bed we used to share. It was raining that day in Toronto. Hundreds of feet sloshed in the puddles on Yonge Street. People chanted, “No justice, no peace.” Renny chanted with me. He will never understand what it is like to live in my skin. But that day, for that protest, he marched next to me. He marched for me. — Daniel Reale-Chin

headline: Video of Montreal Police Kneeling on Black Teenager Spurs Outcry
abstract: Outrage over the video comes as Canada undergoes a national awakening about institutional racism, including among police forces.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — For some Canadians, the 90-second video evoked memories of George Floyd: A white police officer appears to be kneeling on the neck of a Black teenager who is face down on the ground on a Montreal street.

headline: Why Police Have Been Quitting in Droves in the Last Year
abstract: Asheville, N.C., has been among the hardest hit by police departures in the wake of last year’s George Floyd protests. About a third of the force quit or retired.
lead_paragraph: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — As protests surged across the country last year over the death of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police, Officer Lindsay C. Rose in Asheville, N.C., found her world capsized.

headline: Minneapolis Removes Memorials and Barricades From ‘George Floyd Square’
abstract: City workers began clearing the intersection where the police killed Mr. Floyd just over a year ago. The reopening efforts drew criticism from some activists.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The bulldozers arrived before dawn on Thursday at the South Minneapolis intersection where the police killed George Floyd. Moving quickly, city workers in neon vests hauled away flowers, artwork and large cement barricades that have allowed the corner to serve as an ever-growing memorial to Mr. Floyd for more than a year.

headline: How We Talk About Race and Gender
abstract: The way some Americans talk about these issues is changing. We want to hear what you think about these changes.
lead_paragraph: Much has changed in a year of racial reckoning that followed the killing of George Floyd and other Black men and women at the hands of the police, even the words we use to talk about these issues.

headline: Minneapolis Removes Memorials From ‘George Floyd Square’
abstract: City workers on Thursday began removing memorials and barricades from the intersection where the police killed George Floyd just over a year ago. The unannounced effort brought hundreds of people to the scene in protest.
lead_paragraph: City workers on Thursday began removing memorials and barricades from the intersection where the police killed George Floyd just over a year ago. The unannounced effort brought hundreds of people to the scene in protest.

headline: Philonise Floyd Requests Maximum Sentence for Derek Chauvin
abstract: Philonise Floyd, George Floyd’s brother, asked Judge Peter A. Cahill to give Derek Chauvin the maximum sentence for killing his brother.
lead_paragraph: Philonise Floyd, George Floyd’s brother, asked Judge Peter A. Cahill to give Derek Chauvin the maximum sentence for killing his brother.

headline: Prosecutors Urges Longer Prison Sentence for Derek Chauvin
abstract: Matthew A. Frank, one of the prosecutors in the Derek Chauvin trial, asked the judge to sentence the former police officer to three decades in prison for the ‘cruel’ killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Matthew A. Frank, one of the prosecutors in the Derek Chauvin trial, asked the judge to sentence the former police officer to three decades in prison for the ‘cruel’ killing of George Floyd.

headline: Chauvin Speaks to Floyd Family During Sentencing
abstract: Derek Chauvin briefly addressed the family of George Floyd for the first time on Friday, offering them his condolences before his sentence for murder was delivered.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin briefly addressed the family of George Floyd for the first time on Friday, offering them his condolences before his sentence for murder was delivered.

headline: A Race ‘Report Card’ Measures Whether the Music Industry Changed
abstract: The Black Music Action Coalition issued a 37-page report examining if powerful companies followed through on diversity commitments made last summer.
lead_paragraph: A new “report card” on race in the music business takes many of the industry’s most powerful companies to task, urging them to follow through on diversity commitments made last summer amid nationwide protests over the murder of George Floyd.

headline: 3 Columbus Officers Are Charged With Misconduct in George Floyd Protests
abstract: The officers face criminal prosecution for responses to demonstrations last year that Mayor Andrew Ginther said “did not meet my expectations or the community’s.”
lead_paragraph: Three police officers in Columbus, Ohio, face criminal charges for their conduct during protests over the death of George Floyd last year, when officers in cities across the United States frequently used force to break up demonstrations.

headline: Three other officers on the scene with Derek Chauvin still face their own charges.
abstract: Thomas Lane, J. Alexander Kueng and Tou Thao were originally set to stand trial together in August, but after Mr. Chauvin’s conviction, the judge ruled that the second trial would be held in March to put some “space” between them.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The sentencing of Derek Chauvin to 22 and a half years in prison for the second-degree murder of George Floyd will bring a measure of closure to a case that has deeply traumatized the Twin Cities and set off mass protests across the nation.

headline: Israeli Officer Who Killed Autistic Palestinian Man Charged With Manslaughter
abstract: The indictment came more than a year after the fatal shooting. The family of the victim protested the charges as too lenient, calling them “unjust” and “unacceptable.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A police officer who fatally shot an unarmed Palestinian man with autism was charged with manslaughter on Thursday, in a case that brought attention to the issue of police brutality.

headline: Urging a long prison sentence, a prosecutor says Derek Chauvin carried out ‘9 and a half minutes of cruelty.’
abstract: Matthew A. Frank asked the judge to sentence Derek Chauvin to 30 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Asking a judge to sentence Derek Chauvin to three decades in prison for killing George Floyd, a prosecutor said Mr. Chauvin had carried out “nine and a half minutes of cruelty” when he knelt on Mr. Floyd’s neck as he took his last breaths.

headline: ‘The Legend of the Underground’ Review: Gay Activism in Nigeria
abstract: In this stylish documentary, young men discuss their country’s laws criminalizing gay sex.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “The Legend of the Underground” captures queer Nigerian activists as they discuss their country’s laws criminalizing gay sex. Together, they lament unjust arrests and police brutality. But they are not aiming for either martyrdom or altruism — instead, their goal is to improve the circumstances of their own lives.

headline: Pulitzer Prizes Focus on Coverage of Pandemic and Law Enforcement
abstract: The annual awards recognized journalism on the murder of George Floyd, including a special citation for Darnella Frazier, the teenager who filmed the killing. The public service prize went to The New York Times for Covid coverage.
lead_paragraph: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded on Friday to news organizations that provided in-depth coverage of the dramatic turns of 2020, a year dominated by a pandemic that left millions dead and a national conversation on race after the murder of George Floyd.

headline: New Report Paints Bleak Picture of Diversity in the Music Industry
abstract: The Annenberg Inclusion Initiative examined 4,060 executives at six types of companies, and found 19.8 percent were from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, as protests spread across the country following the murder of George Floyd, the music industry promised to change.

headline: Black Lives Matter Has Grown More Powerful, and More Divided
abstract: Since the murder of George Floyd, the racial justice movement has received millions of dollars in donations. But some chapters have questioned how those funds are spent.
lead_paragraph: In the year since George Floyd was murdered, racial justice organizations across the country have been inundated with millions of dollars in donations and thousands of eager new activists. They have earned a prominent platform that puts them on the front lines of political and social battles.

headline: Should I Hang Out With Someone Whose Political Views I Hate?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s hypocritical for a liberal to socialize with an increasingly extreme conservative.
lead_paragraph: I am a liberal in a blue city in a red state. One of my friends is married to a man who has become increasingly conservative over the past year (an “anti-Black Lives Matter, anti-abortion, Democrats are all idiots and socialists are taking over the country” mind-set), and his posts on social media are becoming more and more extreme. We occasionally socialize as couples. When we are together, I am friendly with him, and we avoid overt political talk, but as his social media becomes more and more extreme, I feel conflicted about continuing to accept invitations to socialize with them. Is it hypocritical of me to socialize with them when I find his personal political views so abhorrent? Name Withheld.

headline: Derek Chauvin, held in solitary confinement, returns to the courtroom to learn his fate.
abstract: Mr. Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, may choose to speak at his hearing. He could face decades in prison.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — For the past two months, Derek Chauvin has been held in solitary confinement as lawyers and investigators have been busy with the next phase of his case: determining the length of his punishment for the murder of George Floyd.

headline: ‘I want to give my condolences to the Floyd family,’ Derek Chauvin says at his sentencing hearing.
abstract: Mr. Chauvin delivered brief remarks at his sentencing hearing but said he could not say more because he still faced additional charges in George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin spoke directly to George Floyd’s family for the first time on Friday, telling them in brief remarks at his sentencing hearing that he wanted to “give my condolences” but that he could not say more because he still faced charges in Mr. Floyd’s death.

headline: George Floyd Statue in Brooklyn Is Defaced With Hate Group’s Symbol
abstract: The vandalism came just days after the statue was unveiled, and only a day before the officer who killed Mr. Floyd was to be sentenced.
lead_paragraph: A statue of George Floyd that was installed in Brooklyn less than a week ago was spray-painted and marked with a white supremacist group’s logo in an act of vandalism that the police were investigating as a hate crime, officials said on Thursday.

headline: What do we know about Derek Chauvin?
abstract: Mr. Chauvin, 45, had been a police officer with the Minneapolis Police Department for more than 19 years before George Floyd’s death and had been the subject of at least 22 complaints and investigations.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, 45, had been a police officer with the Minneapolis Police Department for more than 19 years before George Floyd’s death. During that time, he was the subject of at least 22 complaints and internal investigations. One of the episodes led to two letters of reprimand — his only formal discipline.

headline: Derek Chauvin’s mother, speaking for the first time, says her son ‘is a good man.’
abstract: Carolyn Pawlenty told a judge that she believed he was innocent. Mr. Chauvin offered condolences to George Floyd’s family.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin’s mother, speaking publicly for the first time, said in court on Friday that her son had wrongly been described as a racist and that she believed he was innocent of murdering George Floyd.

headline: At George Floyd Square, traffic now mixes with the memorials.
abstract: Some scenes near Cup Foods are now very familiar — prayers, pictures, conversations — while others, like traffic, are new.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Some scenes at George Floyd Square in Minneapolis are now very familiar. Some people pray, others take pictures and some have conversations about where things stand.

headline: How to watch the Derek Chauvin sentencing.
abstract: Friday’s hearing will be streamed live from the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who was convicted of murdering George Floyd on a Minneapolis street corner last year, will be sentenced for the crime on Friday at 1:30 p.m. Central.

headline: Trump Aides Prepared Insurrection Act Order During Debate Over Protests
abstract: President Donald Trump never invoked the act, but fresh details underscore the intensity of his interest last June in using active-duty military to curb unrest.
lead_paragraph: Responding to interest from President Donald J. Trump, White House aides drafted a proclamation last year to invoke the Insurrection Act in case Mr. Trump moved to take the extraordinary step of deploying active-duty troops in Washington to quell the protests that followed the killing of George Floyd, two senior Trump administration officials said.

headline: Black Workers Stopped Making Progress on Pay. Is It Racism?
abstract: Economists are grappling with how much to blame bias or a changing economy for the widening wage gap over the last 40 years.
lead_paragraph: William Spriggs, a professor at Howard University, wrote an open letter last year to his fellow economists. Reacting to the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, he began the letter with a question: “Is now a teachable moment for economists?”

headline: George Floyd’s relatives wanted a longer sentence for Derek Chauvin but rejoiced nonetheless.
abstract: Relatives of George Floyd said on Friday that Derek Chauvin’s prison sentence of 22 and a half years was not long enough, but that they were grateful he would face a measure of accountability after being convicted of murdering Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of George Floyd said on Friday that Derek Chauvin’s prison sentence of 22 and a half years was not long enough, but that they were grateful he would face a measure of accountability after being convicted of murdering Mr. Floyd.

headline: The Times has covered George Floyd’s death from the beginning. Here are some of our most important stories.
abstract: The Times has covered George Floyd’s death from the beginning. Here are some of our best stories.
lead_paragraph: George Floyd and the arrest

headline: Lawmakers Sue N.Y.P.D., Saying They Were Beaten With Bicycles at Protest
abstract: State Senator Zellnor Myrie and Assemblywoman Diana Richardson say they were assaulted and pepper-sprayed by the police during last year’s Black Lives Matter protests.
lead_paragraph: Two New York lawmakers who said they were surrounded, beaten with bicycles and pepper-sprayed by the police during a Black Lives Matter protest in Brooklyn last year filed a federal civil-rights lawsuit against the city on Monday, adding to the blizzard of litigation over the Police Department’s conduct during the protests.

headline: ‘I want to play with him,’ Gianna Floyd, George Floyd’s daughter, says in a video.
abstract: Mr. Floyd’s 7-year-old daughter appeared in a video played in court during Derek Chauvin’s sentencing hearing.
lead_paragraph: Gianna Floyd, the 7-year-old daughter of George Floyd, said in a video played in court on Friday that she missed her father and that she wished she could play with him.

headline: Derek Chauvin is sentenced to 22 and a half years for murder of George Floyd.
abstract: Prosecutors had sought 30 years in prison for the former police officer. Mr. Chauvin’s defense team wanted him released immediately.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The killing of George Floyd on a Minneapolis corner led to nationwide protests, a reckoning over racial injustice touching on virtually every aspect of American life and, on Friday, a substantial prison sentence — 22 and a half years — for the former police officer, Derek Chauvin, who ignored Mr. Floyd’s desperate cries for help and pressed his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck for what seemed an eternity.

headline: 5 takeaways from Derek Chauvin’s sentencing for the murder of George Floyd.
abstract: The sentence came more than two months after Mr. Chauvin’s trial concluded with a guilty verdict on all three counts. The courtroom drama continued with powerful testimony from both sides.
lead_paragraph: After an extraordinary sequence of emotional testimony in a Minneapolis courtroom on Friday, a judge sentenced Derek Chauvin, a former police officer, to 22 and a half years in prison for murdering George Floyd while on duty by kneeling on his neck for more than nine minutes as he pleaded for air.

headline: Biden calls long prison sentence for Derek Chauvin ‘appropriate.’
abstract: Asked for his reaction to Derek Chauvin being sentenced Friday to 22 and a half years in prison for the murder of George Floyd, President Biden described it as “appropriate.”
lead_paragraph: Asked for his reaction to Derek Chauvin being sentenced Friday to 22 and a half years in prison for the murder of George Floyd, President Biden described it as “appropriate.”

headline: Read Judge Peter A. Cahill’s Memorandum for the Sentencing of Derek Chauvin
abstract: Mr. Chauvin was sentenced to more than 22 years for the murder of George Floyd. Here is the full opinion.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Chauvin was sentenced to more than 22 years for the murder of George Floyd. Here is the full opinion.

headline: Judge Sentences Derek Chauvin
abstract: Judge Peter A. Cahill of Hennepin County District Court sentenced Mr. Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, to 22 and a half years in prison for the murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Judge Peter A. Cahill of Hennepin County District Court sentenced Mr. Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, to 22 and a half years in prison for the murder of George Floyd.

headline: Video of George Floyd’s Daughter Played at Chauvin Sentencing
abstract: Gianna Floyd, 7, said in the video that she missed her father and wished she could play with him again. Derek Chauvin was sentenced on Friday to 22 and a half years in prison for George Floyd’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Gianna Floyd, 7, said in the video that she missed her father and wished she could play with him again. Derek Chauvin was sentenced on Friday to 22 and a half years in prison for George Floyd’s murder.

headline: Floyd Family Reacts to Derek Chauvin Sentencing
abstract: The family of George Floyd said the 22½-year sentence for the former police officer was not long enough but celebrated what they viewed as partial accountability.
lead_paragraph: The family of George Floyd said the 22½-year sentence for the former police officer was not long enough but celebrated what they viewed as partial accountability.

headline: Before Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, There Was Ahmaud Arbery
abstract: A year after his killing in Georgia,  his death has sparked a bipartisan effort to remake the state’s 158-year-old citizen’s arrest law. But a potentially divisive trial awaits.
lead_paragraph: WAYNESBORO, Ga. — Scores of mourners gathered last week at a rural cemetery for a service to mark the first anniversary of the slaying of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old Black man who was chased by a trio of white men and shot to death on a residential street.

headline: ‘Don’t Kill Me’: Others Tell of Abuse by Officer Who Knelt on George Floyd
abstract: Firsthand accounts accuse Derek Chauvin, the police officer who pressed his knee into George Floyd’s neck in Minneapolis, of using similar tactics on detainees over the years.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years before the Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin knelt on George Floyd as he cried out that he couldn’t breathe last May, Zoya Code found herself in a similar position: handcuffed facedown on the ground, with Mr. Chauvin’s knee on her.

headline: Making Black Lives, Not Just Black Deaths, Matter Onstage
abstract: The tragedy of racism is only part of the story in two very different plays from London that carry a dimension of meaning not usually seen in this country.
lead_paragraph: As far as theater is concerned, the pandemic has been a paradox, shrinking life down to lockdown bubbles and simultaneously expanding horizons. When you can stream plays from Europe as easily as from Brooklyn, the world seems more interconnected than in the past — tied together by bonds of humanity.

headline: Over 160 Confederate Symbols Were Removed in 2020, Group Says
abstract: The Southern Poverty Law Center said more “symbols of hate” were removed from public property last year after the death of George Floyd than in the previous four years combined.
lead_paragraph: More than 160 Confederate symbols were removed from public spaces or renamed last year after the death of George Floyd, more than the previous four years combined, a watchdog group said on Tuesday.

headline: They Supported ‘Defund the Police.’ Then the Mayoral Campaign Began.
abstract: Most of the leading mayoral candidates have been wary of embracing the “defund the police” movement, which has lost some mainstream political momentum.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: After 10 Months at Sea, a Giant Carrier Returns to a Changed Nation
abstract: A mounting pandemic death toll. A contested election. A riot at the Capitol. “The world at home has become completely different and we don’t know what we are coming home to,” one sailor on the Nimitz said.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD U.S.S. NIMITZ, off California — When this aircraft carrier and its city-size crew departed Naval Base Kitsap in Bremerton, Wash., on April 27, George Floyd was still alive.

headline: Blue Lives Matter Is Over
abstract: Once the Trump mob attacked officers, Republican hypocrisy was exposed.
lead_paragraph: Blue Lives Matter is officially dead. People may continue to chant and post the slogan, but it is dead. Senate Republicans killed it last week when they voted to acquit Donald Trump of inciting an insurrection that left one officer dead and 138 injured. (Two officers who responded to the insurrection later died by suicide.)

headline: Why William Barr Rejected a Plea Deal in the George Floyd Killing
abstract: Mr. Barr, then the attorney general, rejected a plea deal days after Mr. Floyd died, worried in part of protesters calling it lenient. Derek Chauvin was set to plead guilty to third-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It was three days after George Floyd died in police custody last May, and businesses in the Twin Cities were on fire. Police officers were shooting rubber bullets and tear gas to hold back protesters, their anger fueled by a cellphone video of Mr. Floyd, a Black man, gasping for breath under the knee of a white officer.

headline: After Officer’s Racist Post, New York’s Top Judge Demands ‘Zero Tolerance’
abstract: A Buffalo area court officer did not face a disciplinary hearing after he wrote a Facebook post saying George Floyd “deserved what he got.”
lead_paragraph: Just days after George Floyd’s death, a court officer in New York posted two pictures side-by-side on his Facebook page.

headline: Protests Rise After Officer in Tamir Rice Shooting Plays on Football Team
abstract: Timothy Loehmann, who was fired from the Cleveland police force after the shooting death of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, has quietly played with a semipro team in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: When the new player appeared on the semipro football team made up of emergency workers, he simply went by Tim or Timmy. He was noticeably bad at football, said Randy Knight, a lineman on the team, who took Tim under his wing and taught him the basics: assuming a three-point stance, “firing off” the line, proper hand placement at the line of scrimmage.

headline: With New Grand Jury, Justice Department Revives Investigation Into Death of George Floyd
abstract: As the state murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged in the death of George Floyd, approaches, the federal government has accelerated its own investigation.
lead_paragraph: A new federal grand jury has been empaneled in Minneapolis and the Justice Department has called new witnesses as part of its investigation of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who will go on trial in state court next month on a murder charge for the death of George Floyd, according to two people with direct knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Can a Comic Book Contain the Drama and Heat of Activism?
abstract: In his Graphic Content column, Ed Park looks at “The Black Panther Party,” a new history of the group, and “Come Home, Indio,” a memoir about growing up part Native American.
lead_paragraph: “Writing this book broke my heart,” David F. Walker admits in the afterword to his ambitious and informative graphic history THE BLACK PANTHER PARTY (Ten Speed, 183 pp., $19.99), crisply illustrated by Marcus Kwame Anderson. Founded in 1966 by Bobby Seale and Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense was the most famous exponent of the Black Power movement. Its Ten Point Program (reproduced in full in these pages) was a forceful manifesto demanding “land, bread, housing, education, clothing, justice and peace” for the Black community. In the immediate wake of the horrific killings of Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery and George Floyd, Walker notes that “every single concern” the Panthers addressed — from police brutality to reparations — “is still relevant.”

headline: K.K.K. Member Who Drove Into Protesters Gets More Than 3 Years in Prison
abstract: When Harry H. Roger drove his pickup truck through protesters near Richmond, Va., his girlfriend’s 14-year-old son was in the vehicle with him, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Ku Klux Klan who drove his pickup truck through a crowd of Black Lives Matter protesters near Richmond, Va., last year while his girlfriend’s teenage son was in the vehicle was sentenced on Tuesday to three years and eight months in prison, officials said.

headline: George Floyd Image With ‘You Take My Breath Away’ Prompts Internal Police Investigation
abstract: The valentine-style image was “passed around” the Los Angeles Police Department, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department has opened an internal investigation after an inappropriate image of George Floyd, the man killed in police custody in Minneapolis last year, was reported to have been circulated in the department, officials said.

headline: ‘Women in Blue,’ and Redefining What It Means to Protect and Serve
abstract: A new documentary takes viewers inside the Minneapolis Police Department and explores whether more women officers, particularly Black women, could lead to better policing.
lead_paragraph: Long before George Floyd was killed during an encounter with Minneapolis Police officers last May, the department was struggling with a history of police misconduct and allegations of racism and sexism within its ranks.

headline: Minneapolis Will Pay Influencers to Fight Misinformation During Officers’ Trials
abstract: The city will pay six social media influencers $2,000 each to share messages during the trials of Derek Chauvin and three other former police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: The City of Minneapolis plans to pay social media influencers to spread city-approved messages as part of an effort to combat misinformation during the upcoming trials of the four police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd, officials said.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Talking About Race and Racism in the Classroom Using The New York Times
abstract: In this webinar, Learning Network editors and educators share resources and strategies for engaging in these critical discussions.
lead_paragraph: Our students are living through history, from the protests following the killing of George Floyd while in police custody to the insurrection at the Capitol, all while dealing with a deadly pandemic that has disproportionately affected Black and brown communities. Though stories of police brutality and racial inequality are not new, the events of the last year have amplified the call to educators to create safe spaces for students to have critical conversations about race and racism. Navigating these conversations can be challenging. If you are struggling with where to start, or where to go next, you are not alone.

headline: Eric Garner’s Mother Backs McGuire for Mayor Over Progressive Rivals
abstract: Gwen Carr said she was endorsing Ray McGuire because his financial background could help him lead New York’s recovery and make the city a “safer place.”
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Disagreement Before Chauvin Trial Delays the Start of Jury Selection
abstract: Jury selection was delayed in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer facing second-degree murder and manslaughter charges in the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Jury selection was delayed in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer facing second-degree murder and manslaughter charges in the death of George Floyd.

headline: ‘I Need Justice for George,’ Floyd’s Brother Says on Eve of Chauvin Trial
abstract: George Floyd’s brother, Philonise Floyd, and a family lawyer, Ben Crump, spoke in Minneapolis on Sunday night ahead of the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: George Floyd’s brother, Philonise Floyd, and a family lawyer, Ben Crump, spoke in Minneapolis on Sunday night ahead of the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in George Floyd’s death.

headline: Chauvin Trial: Day 2 Key Moments
abstract: As the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, continued on Tuesday in Minneapolis, the prosecution and the defense used witness testimony to focus on how the arrest unfolded.
lead_paragraph: As the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, continued on Tuesday in Minneapolis, the prosecution and the defense used witness testimony to focus on how the arrest unfolded.

headline: $27 Million Settlement Impedes Jury Selection for Chauvin Trial
abstract: Jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who is accused of killing George Floyd, were questioned on their ability to be remain impartial following the City of Minneapolis announcement to pay $27 million to Mr. Floyd’s family.
lead_paragraph: Jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who is accused of killing George Floyd, were questioned on their ability to be remain impartial following the City of Minneapolis announcement to pay $27 million to Mr. Floyd’s family.

headline: Protests in Minneapolis Ahead of Jury Selection in Chauvin Trial
abstract: On Monday, protests in Minneapolis occurred ahead of the jury selection in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in connection with George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, protests in Minneapolis occurred ahead of the jury selection in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in connection with George Floyd’s death.

headline: Jury Selection Begins After Initial Delay in Chauvin Trial
abstract: On Tuesday, after a delayed start, official jury selection began in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer facing second-degree murder and manslaughter charges in the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, after a delayed start, official jury selection began in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer facing second-degree murder and manslaughter charges in the death of George Floyd.

headline: Derek Chauvin’s Defense Team Requests Trial Delay
abstract: On Monday, Derek Chauvin’s defense team asked for a trial delay following the news of a $27 million settlement for George Floyd’s family. Mr. Chauvin’s defense team also asked for the trial’s location be changed.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Derek Chauvin’s defense team asked for a trial delay following the news of a $27 million settlement for George Floyd’s family. Mr. Chauvin’s defense team also asked for the trial’s location be changed.

headline: Hundreds March in Louisville a Year After Breonna Taylor’s Death
abstract: On the anniversary of her death, the family of Breonna Taylor rallied in Louisville, Ky., on Saturday alongside supporters and the families of several other people of color who were fatally shot by police around the country.
lead_paragraph: On the anniversary of her death, the family of Breonna Taylor rallied in Louisville, Ky., on Saturday alongside supporters and the families of several other people of color who were fatally shot by police around the country.

headline: Prosecutors Introduce New George Floyd Surveillance Footage
abstract: Christopher Martin, a teenage store clerk, testified on Wednesday about his encounter with George Floyd using a fake $20 bill at the Cup Foods convenience store on May 25. The witness’s testimony introduced new surveillance footage of the scene and the events leading up to Mr. Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Martin, a teenage store clerk, testified on Wednesday about his encounter with George Floyd using a fake $20 bill at the Cup Foods convenience store on May 25. The witness’s testimony introduced new surveillance footage of the scene and the events leading up to Mr. Floyd’s death.

headline: Cup Foods Worker Shares ‘Guilt’ Over Taking George Floyd’s Fake Bill
abstract: Christopher Martin, a teenage store clerk, testified on Wednesday about his encounter with George Floyd in the minutes proceeding his death. Mr. Martin said he felt guilt and regret for taking Mr. Floyd’s counterfeit bill.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Martin, a teenage store clerk, testified on Wednesday about his encounter with George Floyd in the minutes proceeding his death. Mr. Martin said he felt guilt and regret for taking Mr. Floyd’s counterfeit bill.

headline: Corporations that decried police violence last year are mostly mum on Georgia’s voting rights crackdown.
abstract: As Black Lives Matter protesters filled the streets last summer, many of the country’s largest corporations pledged support for racial justice.
lead_paragraph: As Black Lives Matter protesters filled the streets last summer, many of the country’s largest corporations pledged support for racial justice.

headline: Sharpton and Crump warn that the ‘world is watching’ as witnesses begin to testify.
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton and Ben Crump, a lawyer for George Floyd’s family, told supporters on Monday, just as witnesses began to give testimony during the trial, that the world was focused on the case of the former police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton and Ben Crump, a lawyer for George Floyd’s family, told supporters on Monday, just as witnesses began to give testimony during the trial, that the world was focused on the case of the former police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of Mr. Floyd.

headline: Here’s how to watch the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd is being livestreamed from Minneapolis, and the public’s interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd is unusual for many reasons: It is being livestreamed from Minneapolis, attendance is severely limited because of the coronavirus and the public’s interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.

headline: The House passes a policing overhaul bill named for George Floyd, whose death spurred nationwide protests.
abstract: The bill is aimed at combating racial discrimination and excessive use of force in law enforcement. But its prospects are dim in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats passed a sweeping federal policing overhaul on Wednesday that would combat racial discrimination and excessive use of force in law enforcement, as lawmakers seek to rekindle bipartisan negotiations on the issue.

headline: Trial draws protests, TV coverage and a bonfire at George Floyd Square.
abstract: At the intersection in South Minneapolis where George Floyd died, people sat around a bonfire, discussing what would be unfolding a few miles away in the courtroom where Mr. Chauvin, the former police officer charged with murder in Mr. Floyd’s death, is on trial.
lead_paragraph: As the trial of Derek Chauvin began on Monday, local news channels were airing gavel-to-gavel coverage, while groups of protesters gathered on the streets demanding justice.

headline: What is the defense’s strategy?
abstract: The defense is likely to argue that George Floyd died from drug use and an underlying health condition, not Derek Chauvin’s knee restraint.
lead_paragraph: Glimpses of how Derek Chauvin’s lawyer, Eric J. Nelson, plans to defend his client, a former Minneapolis police officer who is accused of killing George Floyd, have emerged in numerous court filings over the last several months.

headline: Prosecutors show surveillance footage of George Floyd in Cup Foods for the first time.
abstract: An employee of Cup Foods testified on Wednesday that he had spoken briefly about sports with Mr. Floyd when he entered the store and that Mr. Floyd had appeared to be on a drug of some kind.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Wednesday showed surveillance footage of George Floyd laughing and chatting in the Cup Foods convenience store moments before his death in May, providing a glimpse of his actions inside the store for the first time.

headline: Takeaways from the second day of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: The second day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who is accused of killing George Floyd, was marked by emotional testimony from witnesses who recounted what they saw and how it left them feeling traumatized. Six people testified in all, including four witnesses who were younger than 18 on the day of Mr. Floyd’s arrest.
lead_paragraph: The second day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who is accused of killing George Floyd, was marked by emotional testimony from witnesses who recounted what they saw and how it left them feeling traumatized. Six people testified in all, including four witnesses who were younger than 18 on the day of Mr. Floyd’s arrest.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Releases Secret Misconduct Records After Repeal of Shield Law
abstract: Inspired by racial justice protests, the Legislature repealed a law blocking police misconduct records from scrutiny. Now the outcomes of thousands of cases are available online.
lead_paragraph: Nearly nine months after New York lawmakers, inspired by mass protests over police brutality, repealed a law that kept the discipline records of officers secret for decades, the New York Police Department on Monday began publishing some of the sealed information.

headline: Senator Ron Johnson has spread misinformation on the virus, the election, the Capitol riot, even Greenland’s greenness.
abstract: Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, incited widespread outrage when he said recently that he would have been more afraid of the rioters who rampaged the Capitol on Jan. 6 had they been members of Black Lives Matter and antifa.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, incited widespread outrage when he said recently that he would have been more afraid of the rioters who rampaged the Capitol on Jan. 6 had they been members of Black Lives Matter and antifa.

headline: ‘Don’t shoot me.’ Body camera video shows the fatal encounter between police officers and George Floyd.
