abstract: The chilling footage provides a new, up-close perspective on the last moments of Mr. Floyd’s life, as he screamed in terror, sobbed and pleaded with officers.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors showed chilling video from police body cameras as Derek Chauvin and other Minneapolis police officers confronted and tried to arrest George Floyd outside the Cup Foods in Minneapolis on May 25.

headline: L.A.P.D. Severely Mishandled George Floyd Protests, Report Finds
abstract: An independent report commissioned by the Los Angeles City Council faulted the department for its lack of planning and chaotic response.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department severely mishandled protests last summer in the wake of George Floyd’s death, illegally detaining protesters, issuing conflicting orders to its rank-and-file officers and striking people who had committed no crimes with rubber bullets, bean bags and batons, according to a scathing report released on Thursday.

headline: George Floyd’s family, the news media and protesters gather outside the courthouse.
abstract: A scrum of reporters gathered on the lawn just south of the courthouse, where members of Mr. Floyd’s family and their lawyers held a news conference ahead of opening statements.
lead_paragraph: A helicopter whirred overhead on a sunny, yet chilly and windy morning on Monday in downtown Minneapolis, where the streets were largely empty and calm ahead of the big trial.

headline: How Pro-Trump Forces Pushed a Lie About Antifa at the Capitol Riot
abstract: On social media, on cable networks and even in the halls of Congress, supporters of Donald J. Trump tried to rewrite history in real time, pushing the fiction that left-wing agitators were to blame for the violence on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: At 1:51 p.m. on Jan. 6, a right-wing radio host named Michael D. Brown wrote on Twitter that rioters had breached the United States Capitol — and immediately speculated about who was really to blame. “Antifa or BLM or other insurgents could be doing it disguised as Trump supporters,” Mr. Brown wrote, using shorthand for Black Lives Matter. “Come on, man, have you never heard of psyops?”

headline: An outspoken off-duty firefighter testified: ‘There was a man being killed.’
abstract: The firefighter, Genevieve Hansen, who is also an emergency medical technician, said police officers wouldn’t allow her to offer George Floyd assistance.
lead_paragraph: When Genevieve Hansen encountered police officers arresting George Floyd last May, she quickly realized that something was wrong. Ms. Hansen, who was off duty from her job as a Minneapolis firefighter and emergency medical technician, noticed that Mr. Floyd was handcuffed, seemed disoriented and that his face was “smushed into the ground,” she testified in court on Tuesday.

headline: With Five Jurors Now Seated, Momentum Builds in Chauvin Trial
abstract: The quick pace of juror selection and an awaited ruling from the State Supreme Court means opening statements in Derek Chauvin’s trial are likely to begin on March 29 as scheduled.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A third-degree murder charge may be back on the table for Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the death of George Floyd, after a ruling from the Minnesota Supreme Court on Wednesday.

headline: What do we know about Derek Chauvin?
abstract: Derek Chauvin, 44, had been a police officer with the Minneapolis Police Department for more than 19 years before George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, 44, had been a police officer with the Minneapolis Police Department for more than 19 years before George Floyd’s death. During that time, he was the subject of at least 22 complaints and internal investigations. One of the episodes led to two letters of reprimand — his only formal discipline.

headline: What is Derek Chauvin charged with?
abstract: Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, is charged with second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, is charged with second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in the death of George Floyd. If convicted of the most severe charge, he could face a maximum of 40 years in prison.

headline: The Officers Danced at a Black Lives Matter Rally. Then They Stormed the Capitol.
abstract: What appeared to be racial progress in rural Virginia turned into bitter conflict over a Confederate statue, the election and the Capitol riot. Now, people there foresee “a very dangerous time.”
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Derek Chauvin on trial.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, a former police officer, faces charges of manslaughter, second-degree murder and third-degree murder in the death of George Floyd. Mr. Chauvin held his knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck on a Minneapolis street corner in May before he died.

headline: Inside Cup Foods, customers stay glued to the trial.
abstract: The owner said he and his employees were paying close attention.
lead_paragraph: Customers inside Cup Foods put their shopping on pause on Wednesday morning to watch the Derek Chauvin trial on a television mounted above an A.T.M. The coverage again thrust the store into the spotlight as a former employee took the stand and previously unseen surveillance video from inside the store on the day George Floyd died was shown for the first time.

headline: How to Find an Impartial Jury in the Trial Over George Floyd’s Death
abstract: Jury selection is scheduled to begin on Monday in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in connection with Mr. Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: [Live: Follow coverage of the Derek Chauvin trial.]

headline: Ten Months After George Floyd’s Death, Minneapolis Residents Are at War Over Policing
abstract: As the trial of a former officer accused of murdering Mr. Floyd starts, residents and community leaders have struggled to reach consensus on how to radically change public safety, and the role that the police should play in that.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The first day of the murder trial of Derek Chauvin.
lead_paragraph: Ten months after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis set off protests across the U.S. and then the world, the first day of the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing him, attracted global interest. Here’s what happened:

headline: George Floyd’s Family Settles Suit Against Minneapolis for $27 Million
abstract: The settlement is one of the largest of its kind, but it may make it harder to seat an impartial jury for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged with murder in Mr. Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]

headline: Prosecutors say Derek Chauvin knelt on George Floyd for 9 minutes 29 seconds, longer than initially reported.
abstract: The length of time that Mr. Chauvin was initially said to have knelt on Mr. Floyd was put on masks, shirts and signs and became a rallying cry for months at protests in Minneapolis and across the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The length of time that Derek Chauvin was initially said to have knelt on George Floyd’s neck — eight minutes 46 seconds — was put on masks, shirts and signs and became a rallying cry for months at protests in Minneapolis and across the United States.

headline: Spike Lee Predicts the Future
abstract: The director of “Da 5 Bloods” talks about why his old movies still resonate, whether an awards snub even matters and how it’s not his job to end racism.
lead_paragraph: Spike Lee has a knack for seeing what’s ahead. After Eric Garner’s death in 2014 and George Floyd’s death last year, Mr. Lee’s 1989 film “Do the Right Thing,” which culminates in a violent confrontation between a Black character and a white police officer, was seen as downright prophetic.

headline: Darnella Frazier, the teenager who filmed George Floyd’s arrest, testifies at the trial.
abstract: Ms. Frazier was just 17 when she recorded the cellphone video in May and uploaded it to Facebook. ‘When I look at George Floyd, I look at my dad,’ she said in court.
lead_paragraph: The woman who recorded Derek Chauvin as he knelt on George Floyd’s neck in a video that challenged the initial police narrative and brought a wave of attention to the death of Mr. Floyd gave emotional testimony in court on Tuesday morning.

headline: Derek Chauvin will now face a third-degree murder charge.
abstract: The judge overseeing the trial of the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd has allowed prosecutors to add an additional charge.
lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]

headline: How a Museum Show Honoring Breonna Taylor Is Trying to ‘Get It Right’
abstract: An upcoming exhibition brings Black contemporary artists to Louisville’s Speed Art Museum to honor Taylor and her legacy. For the curator Allison Glenn, it’s been an intense journey.
lead_paragraph: “Promise, Witness, Remembrance” — an exhibition opening April 7 at the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., in honor of Breonna Taylor, the 26-year-old medical worker killed by police there nearly a year ago — came together fast, yet in a manner “tempered by conversations,” said its curator Allison Glenn.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Settles Suit for $27 Million
abstract: Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose killing by a white police officer was caught on video and ignited months of nationwide protests.
lead_paragraph: Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose killing by a white police officer was caught on video and ignited months of nationwide protests.

headline: Georgia added a hate-crimes law last year after the death of Ahmaud Arbery.
abstract: The law could come into play if the authorities determine that the suspect in the shootings at Atlanta-area spas was motivated by racism or misogyny.
lead_paragraph: A hate-crimes law that was passed in Georgia last year could come into play if the authorities determine that the suspect in this week’s deadly shootings at Atlanta-area massage parlors was motivated by racism or misogyny.

headline: Corporations, Vocal About Racial Justice, Go Quiet on Voting Rights
abstract: “They are complicit in their silence,” one activist said, as bills that would disproportionately affect Black citizens across the country stir public debate.
lead_paragraph: As Black Lives Matter protesters filled the streets last summer, many of the country’s largest corporations expressed solidarity and pledged support for racial justice. But now, with lawmakers around the country advancing restrictive voting rights bills that would have a disproportionate impact on Black voters, corporate America has gone quiet.

headline: In the first signs of tension, Chauvin’s defense takes aim at a mixed martial artist who witnessed Floyd’s death.
abstract: The defense attorney attempted to discredit Donald Williams II by drawing attention to his lack of knowledge of medical aid and police training.
lead_paragraph: The defense attorney for the former police officer Derek Chauvin spent Tuesday morning discrediting Donald Williams II, a mixed martial artist who witnessed the death of George Floyd, by drawing attention to his lack of knowledge of medical aid and police training.

headline: Here’s what we’ve learned so far from Day 2 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Among the witnesses to testify on Tuesday was the teenager who took the widely shared video of Mr. Chauvin kneeling on George Floyd’s neck.
lead_paragraph: Three witnesses testified on Tuesday morning, the second day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who has been charged with murder in George Floyd’s death. They included Darnella Frazier, the teenager who took the widely shared video of Mr. Chauvin kneeling on Mr. Floyd’s neck.

headline: The Best and Worst of the 2021 Grammy Awards
abstract: Megan Thee Stallion owned the stage, struggling indie venues got a much needed spotlight and the event proved a pandemic awards show doesn’t have to look like a video conference.
lead_paragraph: The 63rd annual Grammy Awards promised to be different: There was a new executive producer at the helm for the first time in decades; a new host; and a new challenge — assembling a pandemic awards show that didn’t feel like a video conference. With a small audience of nominees outside in Los Angeles, the show highlighted the contributions of women and the impact of Black Lives Matter protests, offered screen time to workers at independent venues crushed by the pandemic and extended tributes to musicians we lost during this challenging year.

headline: Judge denies motion to delay Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Judge Peter A. Cahill of Hennepin County District Court on Friday ruled against motions by Mr. Chauvin’s lawyer for a continuance and change of venue, setting the stage for opening statements to begin March 29.
lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]

headline: What Are the Questions for Potential Jurors in the Derek Chauvin Trial?
abstract: A jury questionnaire shows what each side may be looking for as jury selection begins next week. Our reporters analyzed some of the questions.
lead_paragraph: The call to jury duty for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the white former police officer accused of murdering George Floyd, a Black man, came with 14 pages of questions about race, policing, martial arts and podcasts.

headline: Charles McMillian, who saw the police pin George Floyd, breaks down on the stand.
abstract: Charles McMillian, 61, who saw the police trying to get George Floyd into the police car and begged him to cooperate, broke down in sobs as he watched video in court of Mr. Floyd calling for his mother.
lead_paragraph: Charles McMillian, 61, who saw the police trying to get George Floyd into the police car and begged him to cooperate, broke down in sobs as he watched video in court of Mr. Floyd calling for his mother. Mr. McMillian had to stop testifying, take off his glasses and wipe his eyes. “I couldn’t help but feel helpless,” he said.

headline: Upbeat Official Report on Race in Britain Draws a Swift Backlash
abstract: The government report, while acknowledging enduring racism, said Britain provided a model for other white-majority countries on issues of race. Critics accused it of ignoring racial injustice in the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British cities echoed last year with the cries of Black Lives Matter protesters, demanding a racial reckoning in Britain similar to that convulsing the United States in the wake of multiple killings of Black Americans by the police.

headline: ‘Believe Your Eyes,’ Prosecutor Tells Jury on First Day of Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: The lawyer for Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer charged in the killing of George Floyd, suggested that jurors should look beyond the video.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — For nearly a year, the country’s understanding of George Floyd’s death has come mostly from a gruesome video of a white Minneapolis police officer kneeling on Mr. Floyd’s neck for more than nine minutes. It has become, for many, a painful encapsulation of racism in policing.

headline: Donald Williams II, Mixed Martial Artist, Questioned in Chauvin Trial
abstract: On Tuesday, Derek Chauvin’s defense team questioned Donald Williams II, a mixed martial artist who witnessed George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Derek Chauvin’s defense team questioned Donald Williams II, a mixed martial artist who witnessed George Floyd’s death.

headline: Witness Breaks Down During Testimony in Chauvin Trial
abstract: On Wednesday, Charles McMillian, who was driving by Cup Foods at the time of George Floyd’s arrest and stopped to see what was happening, grew emotional in the courtroom when describing what he saw.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Charles McMillian, who was driving by Cup Foods at the time of George Floyd’s arrest and stopped to see what was happening, grew emotional in the courtroom when describing what he saw.

headline: Judge Denies Motion to Delay Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: On Friday, Judge Peter A. Cahill of Hennepin County District Court, who is overseeing the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis officer charged in the death of George Floyd, denied the defense team’s request for a trial delay.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Judge Peter A. Cahill of Hennepin County District Court, who is overseeing the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis officer charged in the death of George Floyd, denied the defense team’s request for a trial delay.

headline: House Passes Sweeping Police Reform Bill Named for George Floyd
abstract: House lawmakers passed the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act late Wednesday, aimed at combating racial discrimination and excessive use of force. The bill was first passed last summer, before stalling in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: House lawmakers passed the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act late Wednesday, aimed at combating racial discrimination and excessive use of force. The bill was first passed last summer, before stalling in the Senate.

headline: ‘He Was Suffering’: Teenager Who Filmed Floyd’s Arrest Testifies at Trial
abstract: Darnella Frazier, who was 17 years old when she filmed video of George Floyd’s arrest, testified during the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in Mr. Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Darnella Frazier, who was 17 years old when she filmed video of George Floyd’s arrest, testified during the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in Mr. Floyd’s death.

headline: Judge Approves Third-Degree Murder Charge in Chauvin Trial
abstract: Judge Peter A. Cahill on Thursday added a third-degree murder charge in the trial of Derek Chauvin, which includes second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter charges in the killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Judge Peter A. Cahill on Thursday added a third-degree murder charge in the trial of Derek Chauvin, which includes second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter charges in the killing of George Floyd.

headline: Young Bystander Testifies in Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: On Tuesday, the prosecution called to the stand a 9-year-old girl who witnessed the arrest of George Floyd. She testified that she saw Derek Chauvin put his knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the prosecution called to the stand a 9-year-old girl who witnessed the arrest of George Floyd. She testified that she saw Derek Chauvin put his knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck.

headline: ‘There’s a Lot of Anxiety’: Crowds Gather Outside Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Jury selection was delayed Monday in the case of the first police officer to stand trial for the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Jury selection was delayed Monday in the case of the first police officer to stand trial for the death of George Floyd.

headline: Two Jurors Dropped From Chauvin Trial
abstract: Two jurors were dismissed from the murder trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin, in the death of George Floyd, saying they could not be impartial after news of a $27 million settlement with Mr. Floyd’s family.
lead_paragraph: Two jurors were dismissed from the murder trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin, in the death of George Floyd, saying they could not be impartial after news of a $27 million settlement with Mr. Floyd’s family.

headline: 911 Operator Recounts Watching Floyd Arrest Unfold
abstract: Jena Scurry, the first witness in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, recalled on Monday watching live surveillance footage of officers pinning George Floyd to the ground.
lead_paragraph: Jena Scurry, the first witness in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, recalled on Monday watching live surveillance footage of officers pinning George Floyd to the ground.

headline: Amy Sherald Directs Her Breonna Taylor Painting Toward Justice
abstract: After painting a portrait of Taylor, whose killing by police helped galvanize national protests, the artist decided she wanted the work to live on in public.
lead_paragraph: Typically, Amy Sherald’s gallery would handle the sale of her artwork to a collector or an institution. But when it came to her portrait of Breonna Taylor — the 26-year-old medical worker who was shot and killed by police officers in Louisville, Ky. — Sherald herself wanted to see that particular painting all the way home.

headline: What happened on the second day of jury selection at the Derek Chauvin trial?
abstract: MINNEAPOLIS — A third-degree murder charge may be back on the table for Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the death of George Floyd, after a ruling from the Minnesota Supreme Court on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A third-degree murder charge may be back on the table for Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the death of George Floyd, after a ruling from the Minnesota Supreme Court on Wednesday.

headline: Georgia to Weaken Citizen’s Arrest Law Cited in Ahmaud Arbery’s Death
abstract: The governor supports a bill passed on Wednesday that repeals language allowing people to arrest someone who they witnessed committing a crime.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Georgia lawmakers on Wednesday approved a bill gutting a Civil War-era law that allowed residents to arrest one another, a move championed by critics who said such laws have historically been used by white citizens to justify the killing of African-Americans.

headline: It May Soon Be Easier to Sue the N.Y.P.D. for Misconduct
abstract: A year after nationwide protests against police brutality, the City Council passed a bill limiting qualified immunity, a longstanding legal protection officers had against lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: A year after nationwide protests against police brutality ignited calls for reform, the New York City Council passed legislation on Thursday aimed at reining in police misconduct by making it far easier to sue officers for conducting illegal searches or using excessive force.

headline: How will the jury be chosen?
abstract: The task of assembling a suitably impartial jury is expected to be one of the most challenging aspects of a case that has generated enormous attention in Minneapolis and around the world.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, prospective jurors in Minneapolis and surrounding communities received an extensive questionnaire about their knowledge of the case of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who is accused of murdering George Floyd. It was a first step to gauge public sentiment about the case and weed out prospective jurors who have strong enough opinions to disqualify them from hearing the case.

headline: In Nigeria, ‘Feminist’ Was a Common Insult. Then Came the Feminist Coalition.
abstract: Protests against police brutality brought the nation’s attention to the Feminist Coalition. Now its members want to change life for Nigerian women.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — During the biggest demonstrations in Nigeria’s recent history, 13 women came together to support their fellow citizens risking their lives to march against police brutality.

headline: How Do Women Feel About Women’s History Month? Conflicted.
abstract: The pandemic, racial reckonings, economic hardship and a next-to-impossible year have made this March particularly fraught.
lead_paragraph: — Patrisse Cullors, a founder of the Black Lives Matter movement, on Women’s History Month

headline: Takeaways from the third day of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: A witness broke down in sobs as he recounted his memory of George Floyd’s arrest. Jurors watched the fatal incident from the perspective of the police officers’ body cameras.
lead_paragraph: The grief and guilt of witnesses have been center stage throughout the first three days of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer accused of killing George Floyd. On Wednesday, the judge temporarily halted the proceedings after a 61-year-old witness broke down in sobs as he recounted his memory of Mr. Floyd’s arrest.

headline: The Allies’ Betrayal of George Floyd
abstract: Did the summer’s protests reflect a racial reckoning or seasonal solidarity?
lead_paragraph: Something happened this summer in the wake of the killing of George Floyd, and maybe only history will be able to fully explain what it was.

headline: The Fashion World Promised More Diversity. Here’s What We Found.
abstract: Tracking an industry where Black representation has been rare.
lead_paragraph: Against the backdrop of the 2020 Black Lives Matter protests, and amid a flurry of racist incidents in the fashion industry, the fashion world vowed it would change.

headline: ‘It Wasn’t Right’: Young Witnesses Offer Emotional Testimony in Chauvin Trial
abstract: On the second day of Derek Chauvin’s trial, eyewitnesses painted a harrowing and consistent picture of what they saw during the fatal arrest of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — She was the teenager whose video of George Floyd’s final moments rippled across the globe. And in a courtroom on Tuesday, Darnella Frazier, now 18, shared her story publicly for the first time, testifying that she remained haunted by Mr. Floyd’s cries for help as she watched a police officer kneel on his neck.

headline: The case against Derek Chauvin will center on proving George Floyd’s cause of death.
abstract: With the central question of the case being exactly how Mr. Floyd died, and what role Mr. Chauvin’s actions played, the state indicated it would cast a much wider net than just relying on the autopsy report of the county medical examiner by bringing in a number of medical experts.
lead_paragraph: With the central question of the case being exactly how Mr. Floyd died, and what role Mr. Chauvin’s actions played, the state indicated it would cast a much wider net than just relying on the autopsy report of the county medical examiner by bringing in a number of medical experts.

headline: Takeaways from the first day of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: The prosecution’s opening remarks focused on nine minutes and 29 seconds of bystander video.
lead_paragraph: One of the most closely watched court cases in decades got underway on Monday as the murder trial began for Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who is being charged with murder in the death of George Floyd.

headline: On the Scene as a Much Anticipated Trial Begins
abstract: The first jurors were seated in the closely watched trial over the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: The first jurors were seated in the closely watched trial over the death of George Floyd.

headline: Read the full report on the L.A.P.D.’s response to the George Floyd protests
abstract: The 101-page report commissioned by the Los Angeles City Council was highly critical of the Police Department’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: The 101-page report commissioned by the Los Angeles City Council was highly critical of the Police Department’s leadership.

headline: 3 Weeks, Dozens of Witnesses: Chauvin Trial Begins
abstract: The murder trial for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, began on Monday in Minneapolis. The prosecution and defense focused on the cause of Mr. Floyd’s death and Mr. Chauvin’s use of force.
lead_paragraph: The murder trial for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, began on Monday in Minneapolis. The prosecution and defense focused on the cause of Mr. Floyd’s death and Mr. Chauvin’s use of force.

headline: The ‘World Is Watching’: Sharpton, Crump Speak Before Chauvin Trial
abstract: The civil rights activist Rev. Al Sharpton, and Ben Crump, a lawyer for George Floyd’s family, held a news conference in Minneapolis on the first day of the trial for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: The civil rights activist Rev. Al Sharpton, and Ben Crump, a lawyer for George Floyd’s family, held a news conference in Minneapolis on the first day of the trial for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing Mr. Floyd.

headline: Crowds Take to the Streets as Chauvin Trial Begins
abstract: Crowds gathered near the courthouse in Minneapolis on Monday as the trial for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, began.
lead_paragraph: Crowds gathered near the courthouse in Minneapolis on Monday as the trial for Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, began.

headline: Inside the Battle Over George Floyd Square
abstract: The trial over George Floyd’s death is underway in Minneapolis. What to do with his memorial site has become a controversy of its own.
lead_paragraph: The trial over George Floyd’s death is underway in Minneapolis. What to do with his memorial site has become a controversy of its own.

headline: Final Juror Selected in Derek Chauvin Murder Trial
abstract: The final member of the jury was interviewed and seated Tuesday for the murder trial of former police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd. Opening statements are set to begin Monday.
lead_paragraph: The final member of the jury was interviewed and seated Tuesday for the murder trial of former police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd. Opening statements are set to begin Monday.

headline: After Unrest and Protests, N.Y.C. Creates Group to Dismantle Structural Racism
abstract: A new racial justice commission will make policy recommendations that could include baby bonds, a jobs guarantee or reparations for Black residents.
lead_paragraph: After a year where the pandemic and protests over police brutality underscored New York City’s broad racial inequities, Mayor Bill de Blasio has unveiled a sweeping initiative to examine and remake the City Charter to correct imbalances.

headline: Inside the courtroom, a rotating pool of journalists is monitoring the developments.
abstract: Two seats for the trial of Derek Chauvin are reserved for journalists. Outside the courtroom, many other members of the media are standing by.
lead_paragraph: Because of the pandemic, a limited audience has been allowed to watch the trial of Derek Chauvin from inside the courtroom. Among those allowed inside are the judge, the jurors, the witnesses, the court staff, the lawyers and Mr. Chauvin himself. One seat has been set aside for a member of George Floyd’s family and one for Mr. Chauvin’s.

headline: In City After City, Police Mishandled Black Lives Matter Protests
abstract: Inquiries into law enforcement’s handling of the George Floyd protests last summer found insufficient training and militarized responses — a widespread failure in policing nationwide.
lead_paragraph: For many long weeks last summer, protesters in American cities faced off against their own police forces in what proved to be, for major law enforcement agencies across the country, a startling display of violence and disarray.

headline: Minneapolis Abandons Plan to Pay Influencers During Officers’ Trials
abstract: The city had faced criticism over plans to pay social media influencers $2,000 each to fight misinformation during the trials of Derek Chauvin and three other former police officers charged in George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: The City of Minneapolis has abandoned a contentious plan to pay social media influencers $2,000 each to help it combat misinformation during the upcoming trials of four police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd, officials said on Monday.

headline: What we learned from the opening statements.
abstract: Before prosecutors called their first witness, lawyers for both sides made opening statements to jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Before prosecutors called their first witness, lawyers for both sides made opening statements to jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in George Floyd’s death. Here’s what happened.

headline: A 911 dispatcher said officers pinned down George Floyd for so long she thought the camera feed ‘had frozen.’
abstract: “My instincts were telling me that something’s wrong,” Jena Scurry testified in court on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A 911 dispatcher who watched the police pin George Floyd to the ground on a surveillance camera said in court on Monday that the restraint went on for so long that she asked someone if her “screens had frozen.”

headline: In the Presence of George Floyd
abstract: A reader says memorializing the man is a step forward on the slow path to racial justice. Also: Power couples.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The jury in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin has been seated.
abstract: The 12-member jury includes two white men, four white women, three Black men, one Black women and two women who identify as mixed race, according to information provided by the court.
lead_paragraph: The jury for the murder trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd has been seated, clearing the way for the opening arguments in the trial, set to begin on Monday.

headline: What happened on the first day of jury selection at the Derek Chauvin trial?
abstract: The first three jurors were selected on Tuesday, with one saying he was not “scared to take on a trial of this magnitude.”
lead_paragraph: The first three jurors were selected on Tuesday for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer accused of second-degree murder in the death of George Floyd.

headline: Two jurors were removed after saying they couldn’t be impartial after a $27 million payout to George Floyd’s family.
abstract: News that the City of Minneapolis had agreed to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd made it hard for them to be impartial about the former police officer accused of killing him, the jurors said.
lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]

headline: The first witness is a 911 dispatcher who ‘called the police on the police’ as George Floyd was arrested.
abstract: The first witness to take the stand in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin on Monday was Jena Scurry, a 911 dispatcher in Minneapolis who alerted a police supervisor in May after she watched officers pin George Floyd to the ground live on a surveillance camera.
lead_paragraph: The first witness to take the stand in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin on Monday was Jena Scurry, a 911 dispatcher in Minneapolis who alerted a police supervisor in May after she watched officers pin George Floyd to the ground live on a surveillance camera.

headline: Assaulting the Truth, Ron Johnson Helps Erode Confidence in Government
abstract: Pushing false theories on the virus, the vaccine and the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Mr. Johnson, the Republican senator from Wisconsin, has absorbed his party’s transformation under Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: BROOKFIELD, Wis. — Senator Ron Johnson incited widespread outrage when he said recently that he would have been more afraid of the rioters who rampaged the Capitol on Jan. 6 had they been members of Black Lives Matter and antifa.

headline: After Breonna Taylor’s Death, Black Engagement in Kentucky Politics Soared
abstract: “Her door being kicked in was our door being kicked in,” a former state representative said as the first anniversary of Ms. Taylor’s death approached. “It really has transformed everything.”
lead_paragraph: Exactly one year ago, a young woman died as a barrage of police gunfire ripped through the walls of her modest apartment in Louisville, Ky. For months, her death went largely unrecognized.

headline: Resources for Teaching About Race and Racism With The New York Times
abstract: A curated collection of over 75 lesson plans, writing prompts, short films and graphs relating to racism and racial justice.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 2020 was not the first time that urgent conversations about race and racism were happening in homes, classrooms and workplaces. But the energy of the Black Lives Matter protests, believed by many to be the largest in U.S. history, was unparalleled. Though the demands and chants may have echoed those heard in previous years, never before, The New York Times reported, “have the cries carried this kind of muscle.” Among American voters, support for the movement grew in the first two weeks of protests almost as much as it did in the preceding two years.

headline: The Trial of Derek Chauvin
abstract: What we know about the prosecution, defense and jury in the trial of the former police officer accused of murdering George Floyd in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: On the docket on Monday at a Minneapolis courthouse is the biggest police brutality case in the United States in three decades: the trial of Derek Chauvin, a white former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, a Black man, last May.

headline: Trump supporters are still pushing false claims that antifa was behind the Capitol riot.
abstract: At 1:51 p.m. on Jan. 6, a right-wing radio host named Michael D. Brown wrote on Twitter that rioters had breached the United States Capitol — and immediately speculated about who was really to blame. “Antifa or BLM or other insurgents could be doing it disguised as Trump supporters,” Mr. Brown wrote, using shorthand for Black Lives Matter. “Come on, man, have you never heard of psyops?”
lead_paragraph: At 1:51 p.m. on Jan. 6, a right-wing radio host named Michael D. Brown wrote on Twitter that rioters had breached the United States Capitol — and immediately speculated about who was really to blame. “Antifa or BLM or other insurgents could be doing it disguised as Trump supporters,” Mr. Brown wrote, using shorthand for Black Lives Matter. “Come on, man, have you never heard of psyops?”

headline: Derek Chauvin’s lawyer asks for a delay in the trial.
abstract: The lawyer also asked the judge on Monday to move the trial outside of the city and that the seven jurors already picked to serve on the case be brought back in for further questioning.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Expressing grave concern that the City of Minneapolis’s $27 million settlement with the family of George Floyd last week will tarnish his client, the lawyer for Derek Chauvin asked the judge on Monday to delay the trial and move it outside of the city.

headline: A $27 million settlement for George Floyd’s family could influence jurors.
abstract: The City of Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose death set off months of protests after a video showed a white police officer kneeling on his neck.
lead_paragraph: The City of Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose death set off months of protests after a video showed a white police officer kneeling on his neck.

headline: Just tuning in to Day 3 of the Derek Chauvin trial? Here’s what we learned this morning.
abstract: Christopher Martin, a teenage clerk, says he regrets accepting a fake bill from George Floyd, and other highlights from the first half of the day.
lead_paragraph: The teenage store clerk who first confronted George Floyd about his use of a fake $20 bill said in court on Wednesday that he felt “disbelief and guilt” when he saw Derek Chauvin kneeling on Mr. Floyd’s neck in front of the store after a co-worker called 911.

headline: Grammys 2021: Women Sweep Awards Shaped by Pandemic and Protest
abstract: Beyoncé broke a record, Megan Thee Stallion and H.E.R. won awards, Taylor Swift’s “Folklore” was named album of the year and Billie Eilish’s “Everything I Wanted” record of the year.
lead_paragraph: The 63rd annual Grammy Awards combined splendor, star power and pandemic-era versatility on Sunday night to celebrate the music that emerged in a deeply challenging year, highlighting the Black Lives Matter protests and — after years of pointed criticism for past slights — the role of women in pop music.

headline: Bystander Killed in Police Crash Is Uncle of Teen Who Filmed George Floyd’s Death
abstract: A Minneapolis police officer slammed his vehicle into Leneal Frazier’s car while chasing a different car. His niece Darnella Frazier said his death was a “big loss” for her family.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, Darnella Frazier has struggled with the trauma that came from witnessing — and recording — George Floyd’s pleas as he struggled for air under the unyielding knee of a Minneapolis police officer. Mr. Floyd was a stranger to her, but his death has haunted her ever since.

headline: M.L.B. Pledges Millions to Build Black Participation
abstract: The league made a 10-year commitment to the Players Alliance that includes $10 million a year, plus an additional $5 million in matching contributions.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball announced on Monday that it would donate up to $150 million to the Players Alliance, a nonprofit formed last summer by more than 100 Black current and former players in the wake of George Floyd’s death. The donation is aimed at helping build Black participation in the sport.

headline: The Liberty’s Role in Making W.N.B.A. Players ‘Top Dogs’ of Activism
abstract: Five years ago, players were fined for wearing unapproved shirts to protest the fatal shootings of two Black men. The league has since embraced players’ desire to speak out against social injustice.
lead_paragraph: On June 22, the Liberty hosted a game celebrating Juneteenth. Some players wore Black Lives Matter T-shirts during shootaround, and the night’s festivities began with a rendition of “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” often considered the national anthem of Black Americans.

headline: Gabriela Garcia Remembers the Women Who Helped Make Her a Best Seller
abstract: “Of Women and Salt” is a novel about sisters and mothers — and its author is an expert on these subjects.
lead_paragraph: MUJER POWER Gabriela Garcia dedicated her debut novel, “Of Women and Salt,” to Iraida Rosa López, her 101-year-old grandmother who emigrated to the United States from Cuba in 1968. In a photograph pinned at the top of Garcia’s Twitter feed, López is wearing jazzy sneakers and holding a Black Lives Matter sign; even without a neatly printed Spanish expletive, it would be clear that this is a woman with strong convictions.

headline: Maryland Passes Sweeping Police Reform Legislation
abstract: The measures, enacted over the objections of Gov. Larry Hogan, placed the state at the forefront of a national debate over police brutality and officers’ excessive use of force.
lead_paragraph: Maryland lawmakers voted on Saturday to limit police officers’ use of force, restrict the use of no-knock warrants and repeal the nation’s first Bill of Rights for law enforcement, taking sweeping action to address police violence after nationwide demonstrations following the death of George Floyd.

headline: Simon & Schuster Says It Won’t Distribute Book by Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor
abstract: Plans by Post Hill Press to publish the book, written by Sgt. Jonathan Mattingly, have drawn sharp criticism.
lead_paragraph: Simon & Schuster said late Thursday night that it had scrapped plans to distribute a book by one of the Louisville police officers who shot Breonna Taylor during the botched drug raid last year that resulted in her death.

headline: The doctor who pronounced George Floyd dead says a lack of oxygen was the likely cause.
abstract: Dr. Bradford Wankhede Langenfeld testified that he had tried to save Mr. Floyd for 30 minutes but had never been able to restart his heart.
lead_paragraph: An emergency room doctor who tried to save George Floyd’s life for 30 minutes before pronouncing him dead testified on Monday that he believed Mr. Floyd had most likely died of a lack of oxygen, bolstering a central argument of the prosecution.

headline: New body camera footage shows George Floyd handcuffed on the street.
abstract: Video shown to jurors on Tuesday shows George Floyd handcuffed and sitting on the street near a Chinese restaurant.
lead_paragraph: In new body camera footage shown to jurors on Tuesday in the trial of Derek Chauvin, George Floyd is seen handcuffed and sitting on the street near a Chinese restaurant, giving his name and birth date to one of the first police officers who arrived at Cup Foods after a clerk called to report that Mr. Floyd had used a fake $20 bill to buy cigarettes.

headline: The Death of George Floyd Reignited a Movement. What Happens Now?
abstract: Calls for racial justice touched nearly every aspect of American life on a scale that historians say has not happened since the civil rights movement of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: George Floyd ‘Changed the World,’ and Other Reflections
abstract: Readers discuss a proclamation by Mr. Floyd’s young daughter and note the key roles played by the judge and the teenager who took the nine-minute video.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: George Floyd’s death ‘was absolutely preventable,’ a cardiologist testifies.
abstract: Dr. Jonathan Rich said Mr. Floyd had an “exceptionally strong heart” and ruled out a drug overdose and a primary cardiac event.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jonathan Rich, a cardiologist called to testify in the trial of Derek Chauvin, said on Monday that George Floyd’s heart was not the main cause of his death. He also ruled out a drug overdose.

headline: In Early Testimony for Defense, Witness Says Chauvin’s Force Was ‘Justified’
abstract: The defense also presented body camera video from a previous arrest of George Floyd, part of its strategy to shift the jurors’ focus to his use of illicit drugs.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A police officer approached a car with George Floyd in the front seat, and Mr. Floyd started to panic. While officers ordered him to spit out a pill he was trying to swallow, he repeatedly begged them not to shoot him.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Verdict in the Derek Chauvin Trial?
abstract: Do you feel that justice has been served? Does the verdict mark a turning point in American history, or is there much work still to be done?
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: The trial of Derek Chauvin, and recounting of the murder of George Floyd, include painful and graphic subject matter. You might consider some of the resources listed at the bottom of this post, from The Learning Network and from other educational organizations, to help your students make sense of and process these events before you ask them to comment in this open forum. (Please also note that all comments are moderated by the Learning Network to follow Times standards.)

headline: Derek Chauvin Found Guilty of Murder
abstract: The former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was found guilty of murder and manslaughter charges in the death of George Floyd, a Black man whose killing sparked nationwide protests.
lead_paragraph: The former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was found guilty of murder and manslaughter charges in the death of George Floyd, a Black man whose killing sparked nationwide protests.

headline: Minnesota Law Enforcement Agent James Reyerson Testifies
abstract: On Wednesday, James Reyerson, the Minnesota law enforcement agent in charge of investigating George Floyd’s death, testified about how he collected information at the scene of the arrest.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, James Reyerson, the Minnesota law enforcement agent in charge of investigating George Floyd’s death, testified about how he collected information at the scene of the arrest.

headline: Morries Hall, George Floyd’s Friend, Hopes to Avoid Chauvin Trial Testimony
abstract: Morries Hall, a friend of George Floyd who was with him when he was arrested, is hoping to avoid testifying. On Tuesday, Mr. Hall’s legal team stated he planned to invoke his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.
lead_paragraph: Morries Hall, a friend of George Floyd who was with him when he was arrested, is hoping to avoid testifying. On Tuesday, Mr. Hall’s legal team stated he planned to invoke his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

headline: George Floyd’s Emergency Room Physician Testifies in Chauvin Trial
abstract: Dr. Bradford Wankhede Langenfeld, the emergency room physician who cared for George Floyd the day he died, testified about Mr. Floyd’s condition when he reached the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Bradford Wankhede Langenfeld, the emergency room physician who cared for George Floyd the day he died, testified about Mr. Floyd’s condition when he reached the hospital.

headline: Expert: ‘No Force’ Should’ve Been Used Once Floyd Was Restrained
abstract: Sgt. Jody Stiger of the Los Angeles Police Department and an expert on the use of force, testified on Wednesday about reasonable force in the arrest of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Jody Stiger of the Los Angeles Police Department and an expert on the use of force, testified on Wednesday about reasonable force in the arrest of George Floyd.

headline: Pulmonologist Details How George Floyd Lost Consciousness During Arrest
abstract: A veteran pulmonologist Dr. Martin J. Tobin testified that George Floyd’s death was caused in part by Derek Chauvin’s knees pressing against his neck and back, making it impossible for him to breathe.
lead_paragraph: A veteran pulmonologist Dr. Martin J. Tobin testified that George Floyd’s death was caused in part by Derek Chauvin’s knees pressing against his neck and back, making it impossible for him to breathe.

headline: Defense Calls Retired Paramedic to the Stand in the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Michelle Moseng, a retired paramedic, testified about George Floyd’s condition after a 2019 arrest, saying Mr. Floyd told her he had been taking some form of opioid. Her testimony was limited to the physical effects of opioids on Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Moseng, a retired paramedic, testified about George Floyd’s condition after a 2019 arrest, saying Mr. Floyd told her he had been taking some form of opioid. Her testimony was limited to the physical effects of opioids on Mr. Floyd.

headline: Police Surgeon Says George Floyd Died of Asphyxia
abstract: Dr. Bill Smock, a surgeon for the Louisville Metropolitan Police Department, testified on Thursday that he had found no evidence to support claims that George Floyd died of an overdose.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Bill Smock, a surgeon for the Louisville Metropolitan Police Department, testified on Thursday that he had found no evidence to support claims that George Floyd died of an overdose.

headline: Forensic Pathologist Says Physiologic Stress Contributed to Floyd’s Death
abstract: Dr. Lindsey Thomas, a forensic pathologist, testified on Friday that police restraint killed George Floyd, primarily by restricting his oxygen with a secondary effect of physiological stress on his body.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lindsey Thomas, a forensic pathologist, testified on Friday that police restraint killed George Floyd, primarily by restricting his oxygen with a secondary effect of physiological stress on his body.

headline: Minnesota Attorney General Thanks Floyd Family After Trial
abstract: Keith Ellison, the attorney general of Minnesota, thanked George Floyd’s family after Derek Chauvin was found guilty. Mr. Ellison also encouraged peaceful reactions to the verdict.
lead_paragraph: Keith Ellison, the attorney general of Minnesota, thanked George Floyd’s family after Derek Chauvin was found guilty. Mr. Ellison also encouraged peaceful reactions to the verdict.

headline: Guilty of All Charges
abstract: After 10 hours of deliberation, a jury found that Derek Chauvin had murdered George Floyd. We were in Minneapolis for the verdict and the reaction.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, after three weeks of jury selection, another three weeks of testimony and 10 hours of deliberations, Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, was found guilty of murder in the death of George Floyd.

headline: Lessons From Lynchings
abstract: There’s a through-line from a noose on the neck to a knee on the neck.
lead_paragraph: There are many appalling narratives emerging from the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin in the killing of George Floyd.

headline: Takeaways from Day 4 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Paramedics who responded to the scene said they did not see any signs of life in George Floyd. “In lay terms, I thought he was dead,” one said.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd in Minneapolis, entered a new phase on Thursday with the testimony of paramedics who responded to the scene, making it the first time that jurors heard about Mr. Floyd’s medical condition in the immediate aftermath of the arrest.

headline: Although Chauvin was convicted, many well-known cases of police violence never went to trial.
abstract: For many observers, the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in George Floyd’s death, has felt like the culmination of years of outrage and grief over police killings of Black people in America. Video of the arrest that led to Mr. Floyd’s death inspired demonstrations that touched every corner of the country last summer, with protesters demanding justice for Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: For many observers, the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in George Floyd’s death, has felt like the culmination of years of outrage and grief over police killings of Black people in America. Video of the arrest that led to Mr. Floyd’s death inspired demonstrations that touched every corner of the country last summer, with protesters demanding justice for Mr. Floyd.

headline: Mother of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old killed by the police, asks D.O.J. to reopen its investigation.
abstract: The request to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland comes after he and President Biden vowed to use the powers of the federal government to fight racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting, which was closed in December after the department said it could not charge the officers.

headline: Minnesota students walk out of schools in solidarity with the racial justice movement.
abstract: The organizers of the walkout, Minnesota Teen Activists, said that students at more than 100 schools participated.
lead_paragraph: Students streamed out of schools across Minnesota on Monday afternoon to protest racial injustice, in a coordinated action that coincided with closing arguments in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd.

headline: At Daunte Wright Funeral, Minneapolis Mourns the ‘Prince of Brooklyn Center’
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton delivered the eulogy for Mr. Wright, the 20-year-old Black man who was shot and killed by a police officer in Brooklyn Center, Minn., last week.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Two days after the streets of Minneapolis were filled with people celebrating the conviction of a police officer for the murder of George Floyd, the city returned to a period of mourning on Thursday for another Black man killed by a police officer.

headline: Buoyed by Floyd Verdict, Congress Eyes New Bid to Overhaul Policing
abstract: A bipartisan effort to change policing practices collapsed last summer after George Floyd’s murder by a white officer. Can a “guilty” verdict and President Biden’s call for action resurrect it?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after a white Minneapolis police officer was found guilty of murdering George Floyd, a Black man, lawmakers in both parties said they were cautiously optimistic that the verdict could provide new momentum in Congress to overcome the hurdles that have thwarted a far-reaching police overhaul.

headline: What Students Are Saying About The Verdict in the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: We invited teenagers to share what they were feeling and wondering about the verdict in a trial that shook the nation. Here is what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, was found guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in the death of George Floyd, whose killing last May drew millions into the streets for the largest racial justice protests in generations.

headline: Does it matter whether Chauvin knelt on Floyd’s neck versus his shoulder?
abstract: Derek Chauvin’s defense has repeatedly suggested that his knee was actually on George Floyd’s shoulder, but several experts said the knee could be lethal in either position.
lead_paragraph: In the widely viewed bystander video of George Floyd’s arrest, it seemed plain that Derek Chauvin had positioned his left knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck.

headline: Teachers Address Derek Chauvin’s Guilty Verdict
abstract: After a tumultuous year, classrooms are talking about the murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, many teachers will have a big topic to discuss with their students: the news that a jury convicted Derek Chauvin of murder for the killing of George Floyd. We reached out to some of the educators who have been in touch with this newsletter to see how they’ll handle it.

headline: Business owners assess the damage after a night of unrest outside Minneapolis.
abstract: Business owners in Brooklyn Center, a suburb of Minneapolis, spent Monday repairing damaged property after a night of unrest. Protesters clashed with the police on Sunday, after an officer fatally shot a 20-year-old Black driver during a traffic stop. The shooting occurred not far from the courthouse where Derek Chauvin is on trial for the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Business owners in Brooklyn Center, a suburb of Minneapolis, spent Monday repairing damaged property after a night of unrest. Protesters clashed with the police on Sunday, after an officer fatally shot a 20-year-old Black driver during a traffic stop. The shooting occurred not far from the courthouse where Derek Chauvin is on trial for the death of George Floyd.

headline: Here’s how to watch the closing arguments in the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd is being livestreamed from Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd is unusual for many reasons: It is being livestreamed from Minneapolis, attendance is severely limited because of the coronavirus and the public’s interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.

headline: What Grade Would You Give President Biden on His First 100 Days?
abstract: It’s report card time for the Biden administration. Have the president’s actions met your expectations?
lead_paragraph: When President Biden took office in January, we asked students what the new administration’s priorities should be. We heard from teenagers who wanted Mr. Biden to distribute coronavirus vaccines, support veterans, address police brutality, curb climate change and prioritize unity and bipartisanship.

headline: Just tuning in to Day 4 of the Derek Chauvin trial? Here’s what happened this morning.
abstract: Testimony continued on the fourth day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, with appearances from George Floyd’s girlfriend and a paramedic who responded to the scene.
lead_paragraph: Testimony continued on the fourth day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, with appearances from George Floyd’s girlfriend and a paramedic who responded to the scene.

headline: Al Sharpton and the Floyd family pray for ‘justice’ outside of the courthouse.
abstract: Relatives of George Floyd prayed outside the courthouse with the Rev. Al Sharpton on Tuesday, asking God for “justice” from the jury and for strength to continue closely watching the trial taking place on the 18th floor of the building behind them.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of George Floyd prayed outside the courthouse with the Rev. Al Sharpton on Tuesday, asking God for “justice” from the jury and for strength to continue closely watching the trial taking place on the 18th floor of the building behind them.

headline: Sports World Reacts to Chauvin Verdict
abstract: After the deaths of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd and other instances of violence against Black people, many athletes engaged in activist efforts last year.
lead_paragraph: The reverberations throughout sports came swiftly after a jury in Minnesota convicted Derek Chauvin on Tuesday of murdering George Floyd, as athletes, teams and leagues weighed in on the verdict in a case that had reignited fierce debate about racism and policing in the United States.

headline: ‘Totally unnecessary’: the longest-serving Minneapolis Police officer says Chauvin violated police policy.
abstract: Lt. Richard Zimmerman, who leads the homicide unit, said the police are supposed to quickly move people out of the prone position.
lead_paragraph: The longest-serving police officer in the Minneapolis Police Department said on Friday that Derek Chauvin had violated department policy by kneeling on George Floyd’s neck for more than nine minutes as he lay handcuffed on his stomach.

headline: A toxicologist’s testimony challenged claims by Derek Chauvin’s lawyer that George Floyd overdosed on fentanyl.
abstract: Dr. Daniel Isenschmid said that intoxicated driving suspects who used fentanyl often had higher levels of the drug in their blood than Mr. Floyd did.
lead_paragraph: A forensic toxicologist at the laboratory that tested George Floyd’s blood said it was common for intoxicated driving suspects who used fentanyl to have higher levels of the drug in their systems than Mr. Floyd did when he died. Prosecutors hoped his testimony would strike a blow to the argument by Derek Chauvin’s lawyer that Mr. Floyd’s death may have been an overdose.

headline: Key Moments on Day 11 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: The judge denied a defense motion to sequester the jury after a police shooting in the Minneapolis suburbs.
lead_paragraph: The third week of testimony in the trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin began on Monday with prosecutors continuing to call witnesses they think will bolster their argument that Mr. Chauvin caused George Floyd’s death by pinning him to the ground for more than nine minutes.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A jury finds Derek Chauvin guilty.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, was found guilty yesterday on all three charges he faced in the death last year of George Floyd, capping one of the most-watched trials in the U.S. in recent memory. Follow live reactions.

headline: When reporters try to speak with Floyd’s family outside the courtroom, sheriff’s deputies step in.
abstract: The chief judge of Hennepin County has set strict rules prohibiting the Floyd family from speaking to the news media outside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, when Charles McMillian, a witness to the death of George Floyd, broke down while recounting what he saw last May, Judge Peter Cahill called a short recess to allow Mr. McMillian to compose himself.

headline: Officers should have stopped restraining George Floyd sooner, a former supervisor of Derek Chauvin’s testified.
abstract: Mr. Chauvin said the officers had to restrain Mr. Floyd because he would not stay in the back of a police car. “He was going crazy,” he said.
lead_paragraph: A sergeant who supervised Derek Chauvin testified on Thursday that Mr. Chauvin and other police officers should have stopped holding George Floyd down once he became unresponsive.

headline: Book by Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor Is a New Test for Publishers
abstract: Sgt. Jonathan Mattingly, one of the officers involved in the fatal shooting, has a book deal with a small press, but its distributor, Simon & Schuster, in an unusual move, said it won’t ship it.
lead_paragraph: When the small, independent publisher Post Hill Press said on Thursday that it would release a book by one of the Louisville police officers who shot Breonna Taylor, the outrage practically burned down the internet. It took less than 12 hours for Simon & Schuster to announce that it would not distribute the book.

headline: What is the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, the agency that investigated George Floyd’s death?
abstract: A special agent from the bureau testified at the Derek Chauvin trial on Wednesday. The agency has a range of responsibilities, including investigating all Minneapolis police killings.
lead_paragraph: The second witness to take the stand in the trial of Derek Chauvin on Wednesday was a special agent with the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension. Other employees of the agency are also expected to testify. So, what is it?

headline: National Guard troops are called to U.S. cities as the jury deliberates in the Chauvin trial.
abstract: With the memory of last summer’s protests still fresh, some states have already ordered troops to be on standby in anticipation of large protests if there is an acquittal.
lead_paragraph: Cities across the country are preparing for protests as the jury in the murder trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin entered its second day of deliberations on Tuesday. With the memory of last summer’s protests after George Floyd’s death still fresh, some states have ordered National Guard troops to be on standby in anticipation of large protests if there is an acquittal.

headline: How Chuck Schumer Plans to Win Over Trump Voters
abstract: The Senate majority leader also discusses the filibuster, Joe Manchin and Democrats’ plan for 2022.
lead_paragraph: In his 100 days address this week, Joe Biden outlined his plans for a big, bold legislative agenda to come. He previewed a two-pronged economic package: the $2.25 trillion American Jobs Plan and the $1.8 trillion American Families Plan. He spoke about the need to pass universal background checks for firearms, comprehensive immigration reform, and the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act.

headline: Derek Chauvin ‘absolutely’ violated policy, the Minneapolis police chief says.
abstract: “That is not what we teach,” Chief Medaria Arradondo said of Mr. Chauvin kneeling on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: The chief of the Minneapolis Police Department testified on Monday that Derek Chauvin had “absolutely” violated department policies when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes in May, saying Mr. Chauvin “should have stopped” when Mr. Floyd was calling out for help.

headline: On TV, a tense wait, and then an emotional response.
abstract: Every major broadcast and cable news network — and even ESPN — broke into regular programming on Tuesday for live coverage of the Derek Chauvin verdict.
lead_paragraph: Every major broadcast and cable news network — and even ESPN — broke into regular programming on Tuesday for live coverage of the verdict, ensuring that millions of Americans watched in unison as a Minnesota jury found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty on all charges in the death of George Floyd.

headline: Takeaways from Day 12 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: An expert testifying for the defense said Mr. Chauvin was justified in pinning George Floyd under his knee. He contradicted numerous experts called by prosecutors, including the police chief of Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin, a witness explicitly defended his actions when he knelt on George Floyd for nine and a half minutes.

headline: Attorney General Announces Investigation Into Minneapolis Police
abstract: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced on Wednesday a new civil investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department for misconduct, separate from the ongoing federal investigation into the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced on Wednesday a new civil investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department for misconduct, separate from the ongoing federal investigation into the death of George Floyd.

headline: ‘Deadly Force’: Minneapolis Police Officer Describes Chauvin’s Actions
abstract: Lt. Richard Zimmerman, who responded to the scene of George Floyd’s arrest after he was taken away in an ambulance, testified in court that Derek Chauvin did not follow police protocol.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Richard Zimmerman, who responded to the scene of George Floyd’s arrest after he was taken away in an ambulance, testified in court that Derek Chauvin did not follow police protocol.

headline: Reaction to the Guilty Verdict in the Chauvin Trial
abstract: Crowds in Minneapolis took to the streets in celebration chanting George Floyd’s name after the verdict was announced.
lead_paragraph: Crowds in Minneapolis took to the streets in celebration chanting George Floyd’s name after the verdict was announced.

headline: Defense’s Medical Expert Testifies Chauvin’s Knee Did Not Injure Floyd
abstract: Dr. David Fowler, an expert for Derek Chauvin’s defense team, testified that the weight of Mr. Chauvin’s knee on George Floyd’s neck did not injure him. Several experts for the prosecution said it was enough to asphyxiate him.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Fowler, an expert for Derek Chauvin’s defense team, testified that the weight of Mr. Chauvin’s knee on George Floyd’s neck did not injure him. Several experts for the prosecution said it was enough to asphyxiate him.

headline: Medical Examiner Describes George Floyd’s Heart Condition
abstract: Dr. Andrew Baker, the medical examiner for Hennepin County, said on Friday that Mr. Floyd had a heart condition that put him at a greater risk in situations with high physical stress.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew Baker, the medical examiner for Hennepin County, said on Friday that Mr. Floyd had a heart condition that put him at a greater risk in situations with high physical stress.

headline: Derek Chauvin Declines to Testify in Murder Trial
abstract: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the killing of George Floyd, invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to testify in his own defense on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the killing of George Floyd, invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to testify in his own defense on Thursday.

headline: Chauvin’s Use of Force Was ‘Excessive,’ L.A.P.D. Sergeant Says
abstract: Los Angeles Police Sgt. Jody Stiger, a use-of-force expert, told jurors on Tuesday that the former police officer Derek Chauvin used excessive force on George Floyd during his arrest.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles Police Sgt. Jody Stiger, a use-of-force expert, told jurors on Tuesday that the former police officer Derek Chauvin used excessive force on George Floyd during his arrest.

headline: George Floyd’s Girlfriend Recalls Relationship in Emotional Testimony
abstract: Courteney Ross, who was dating George Floyd for nearly three years before his death in May, delivered tearful testimony on Thursday about their shared struggle with an opioid addiction.
lead_paragraph: Courteney Ross, who was dating George Floyd for nearly three years before his death in May, delivered tearful testimony on Thursday about their shared struggle with an opioid addiction.

headline: George Floyd ‘Did Not Die From a Drug Overdose,’ Cardiologist Testifies
abstract: Dr. Jonathan Rich, a cardiologist called to testify in the trial of Derek Chauvin, said the condition of George Floyd’s heart and drug use did not contribute to his death, as the defense has claimed.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jonathan Rich, a cardiologist called to testify in the trial of Derek Chauvin, said the condition of George Floyd’s heart and drug use did not contribute to his death, as the defense has claimed.

headline: Toxicologist Challenges Claim of Floyd Overdose
abstract: Daniel Isenschmid, a forensic toxicologist, testified on Thursday at the trial of Derek Chauvin that the level of norfentanyl in George Floyd’s system was not consistent with a typical fentanyl overdose.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Isenschmid, a forensic toxicologist, testified on Thursday at the trial of Derek Chauvin that the level of norfentanyl in George Floyd’s system was not consistent with a typical fentanyl overdose.

headline: Police officers, not drugs, caused George Floyd’s death, a pathologist testifies.
abstract: Dr. Lindsey C. Thomas said Mr. Floyd died of a lack of oxygen and that there was “no evidence” he would have died that day if he had not been pressed to the ground by police officers.
lead_paragraph: A forensic pathologist testified on Friday that George Floyd had primarily died of low oxygen, also called asphyxia, which she said had been caused by Derek Chauvin and the other police officers who pressed him to the ground.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Leader Says ‘a Few Checks’ Can’t Fix Structural Racism
abstract: “There is a responsibility of corporations to ensure that we maintain a stable democracy,” Derrick Johnson said.
lead_paragraph: Derrick Johnson, the president and chief executive of the N.A.A.C.P., was on the phone with other civil rights leaders on Tuesday afternoon, discussing strategy for how to respond to different possible outcomes in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the police officer charged with murdering George Floyd.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Year of Protest and Reform. What Now for Racial Justice?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 21, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “We will forever look back at this moment in American history. George Floyd’s death created a new energy around making changes, though it’s not clear how lasting they will be.”

headline: ‘I Was Failing’: Bystanders Carry Guilt From Watching George Floyd Die
abstract: Their pain has been mostly hidden for the last 10 months. But over the first week of Derek Chauvin’s murder trial, it spilled tearfully into the open as witnesses testified to their shared trauma.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Alyssa Funari needed a cord to connect her cellphone to the car to play music, so she pulled up to a corner store in South Minneapolis one early evening last May.

headline: ‘We have already boarded’: Businesses in Minneapolis brace for protests, like the ones last year.
abstract: Shop owners hope they don’t experience destruction similar to that of last summer as a verdict draws closer in the Derek Chauvin trial and tensions flare over a police shooting.
lead_paragraph: Carl Mitchell spent Sunday nailing wood to the windows of the Amstar convenience shop he manages in North Minneapolis. Hours earlier, Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man, had been shot by the police 10 miles north. With the trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin, accused of killing George Floyd, heading into its third week, Mr. Mitchell didn’t want to take any chances.

headline: Corrections: April 21, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 21, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the trial of Derek Chauvin and his decision to invoke his Fifth Amendment privilege described incorrectly his posture seen on video as he knelt on George Floyd. His hands were resting on his thighs, not in his pockets.

headline: The police caused George Floyd’s death, but drugs and heart disease played a role, the medical examiner says.
abstract: Dr. Andrew Baker, who performed Mr. Floyd’s autopsy, said police officers’ restraint of Mr. Floyd and compression of his neck were the main causes of his death.
lead_paragraph: The medical examiner who conducted George Floyd’s autopsy testified on Friday that while Mr. Floyd’s heart disease and drug use contributed to his death, it was police officers’ compression of his neck and restraint of his body that were the primary causes.

headline: Facebook, preparing for Chauvin verdict, to limit posts that might incite violence.
abstract: The company said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Monday said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd, to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.

headline: Key Moments on Day 13 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: A forensic pathologist called to testify by the defense said it was his medical opinion that George Floyd died from cardiac arrhythmia.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for the former officer Derek Chauvin began calling witnesses to the stand this week, including an associate of George Floyd’s who was in the car with him when the police arrived, and a Minneapolis Park Police officer on the scene. The defense is trying to build a case that Mr. Floyd was affected by drugs he had taken, and that the bystanders were a threat to the officers who pinned Mr. Floyd to the ground.

headline: Breonna Taylor Show Puts Art Museums on a Faster Track
abstract: Assembled in a mere four months, pivoting off an important national event, the Speed Museum offers a new, relevant model for aging institutions.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — People talk a lot about getting back to pre-Covid normal. But our traditional art museums can forget about that. After a year of intense racial justice reckoning, a paralyzing pandemic and crippling economic shortfalls, aging hidebound institutions are scrambling just to stay afloat. And the only way for them to do so is to change. Strategies for forward motion are needed. One is in play here at the Speed Art Museum, in the form of a quietly passionate show called “Promise, Witness, Remembrance,” which might, with profit, be studied by other institutions in survivalist mode.

headline: A Minneapolis police sergeant and crisis intervention trainer testifies that officers often have time to ‘slow things down.’
abstract: Prosecutors called Sgt. Ker Yang to the stand and walked through the various decisions that officers are expected to make while on the job.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for both the prosecution and the defense continued to argue on Tuesday over whether Derek Chauvin violated police policy when he knelt on George Floyd, asking a range of questions to the day’s first witness, a crisis intervention coordinator with the Minneapolis Police Department.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Reacts to the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: In an episode hosted by Carey Mulligan, “S.N.L.” looked at the American justice system through the lens of a fictional midday news program.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks of testimony, the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged in the death of George Floyd, has gripped viewers — including the hosts of a fictional news program on “Saturday Night Live,” who drew very different conclusions from what they’d seen.

headline: Takeaways from Day 10 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
