abstract: The medical examiner who performed the initial autopsy of George Floyd said he died as a result of his interaction with law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: One of the most anticipated witnesses of Derek Chavin’s trial, the Hennepin County medical examiner who performed the initial autopsy of George Floyd, testified on Friday that while police restraint was the main cause of Mr. Floyd’s death, drug use and heart disease were contributing factors.

headline: Who are the key players in the Derek Chauvin trial?
abstract: Here’s what to know about the witnesses, the prosecution and defense, and the jurors, who will decide the case.
lead_paragraph: The jury has begun deliberations in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who has been charged in connection with the death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man who died on May 25 after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground under the knee of Mr. Chauvin, who is white, for more than nine minutes.

headline: A police force expert says Derek Chauvin used ‘deadly force’ on George Floyd when he should have used none.
abstract: Sgt. Jody Stiger, who works for the Los Angeles Police Department, said Mr. Chauvin had put Mr. Floyd at risk of positional asphyxia, a key point for prosecutors who have argued that Mr. Floyd died of asphyxia.
lead_paragraph: A use-of-force expert with the Los Angeles Police Department testified on Wednesday that Derek Chauvin had used “deadly force” on George Floyd at a time when it was not appropriate to use any force.

headline: What Might Bring Changes to Policing in Minneapolis?
abstract: The Justice Department has opened up a new avenue for potentially major policy shifts in the city.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin had worked for almost two decades at the Minneapolis Police Department, amassing a history riddled with accusations of abuse, before he murdered George Floyd on May 25, 2020.

headline: More Businesses Are Standing for Justice
abstract: The corporate response to civil rights has changed over the years.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Yesterday’s guilty verdict against George Floyd’s murderer, a former Minneapolis police officer, was a symbol of something profound: a demonstrable shift in the way this country, increasingly supported by business, has strived for civil rights.

headline: The judge revoked Derek Chauvin’s bail and said he would be sentenced in eight weeks.
abstract: Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who has been free on bail since the fall, was led out of the courtroom in handcuffs.
lead_paragraph: Judge Peter A. Cahill revoked Derek Chauvin’s bail on Tuesday after he was convicted of murdering George Floyd.

headline: Damon Locks and the Black Monument Ensemble’s Spiritual, Funky Escape
abstract: The Chicago musician’s group is following up its 2019 album, “Where Future Unfolds,” with an LP reacting to the events of 2020 titled “Now.”
lead_paragraph: During the summer of 2020, as protesters took to the streets after the deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor, and the United States once again reckoned with fierce racial and ideological divides, the Chicago-based vocalist, producer and sound artist Damon Locks found himself at a creative impasse.

headline: Police officers have taken the stand in their defense. The results have been mixed.
abstract: Although Derek Chauvin opted not to testify Thursday, other police officers have testified in their own trials.
lead_paragraph: Although Derek Chauvin has opted not to testify in his defense against charges that he murdered George Floyd, police officers have taken the stand in their own defense. The results have been mixed. Here are a few examples:

headline: Philonise Floyd, George Floyd’s Brother, Testifies
abstract: George Floyd’s brother, Philonise Floyd, testified on Monday in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in Mr. Floyd’s death, and spoke about who George Floyd was as a person and the memories they shared growing up.
lead_paragraph: George Floyd’s brother, Philonise Floyd, testified on Monday in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in Mr. Floyd’s death, and spoke about who George Floyd was as a person and the memories they shared growing up.

headline: Prosecutor Describes George Floyd’s Last Moments in Closing Statement
abstract: Steve Schleicher, a prosecutor for the Derek Chauvin trial, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, focused his closing statements on describing in vivid detail the last moments of Mr. Floyd’s life.
lead_paragraph: Steve Schleicher, a prosecutor for the Derek Chauvin trial, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, focused his closing statements on describing in vivid detail the last moments of Mr. Floyd’s life.

headline: Pulmonologist Testifies That Car Exhaust Did Not Kill George Floyd
abstract: Returning to the stand for the state on Thursday, Dr. Martin J. Tobin referenced tests done on Mr. Floyd’s blood and called the statement by Dr. David Fowler, a defense witness and forensic pathologist, that carbon monoxide could have killed him “simply wrong.”
lead_paragraph: Returning to the stand for the state on Thursday, Dr. Martin J. Tobin referenced tests done on Mr. Floyd’s blood and called the statement by Dr. David Fowler, a defense witness and forensic pathologist, that carbon monoxide could have killed him “simply wrong.”

headline: Supervisor Says Chauvin Should Have Provided Medical Aid
abstract: Katie Blackwell, the former Minneapolis Police Department training director, testified on Monday that Derek Chauvin had undergone extensive training and should have provided medical aid to George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Katie Blackwell, the former Minneapolis Police Department training director, testified on Monday that Derek Chauvin had undergone extensive training and should have provided medical aid to George Floyd.

headline: Police Expert in Chauvin Trial Says He Didn’t See Crowd as ‘Threat’
abstract: Sgt. Jody Stiger of the Los Angeles Police Department testified on Wednesday in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin that he did not perceive bystanders as a threat after reviewing body camera video of George Floyd’s arrest.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Jody Stiger of the Los Angeles Police Department testified on Wednesday in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin that he did not perceive bystanders as a threat after reviewing body camera video of George Floyd’s arrest.

headline: Forensic Pathologist Testifies That Police Actions Caused Floyd’s Death
abstract: Dr. Lindsey Thomas, a forensic pathologist, testified on Friday in Derek Chauvin’s murder trial that George Floyd died from low oxygen caused by law enforcement’s subdual restraint and compression to the neck.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lindsey Thomas, a forensic pathologist, testified on Friday in Derek Chauvin’s murder trial that George Floyd died from low oxygen caused by law enforcement’s subdual restraint and compression to the neck.

headline: Derek Chauvin Trial Judge Gives Instructions to Jury
abstract: With closing arguments beginning, Judge Peter A. Cahill read aloud the instructions to the jurors to follow in deciding their verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: With closing arguments beginning, Judge Peter A. Cahill read aloud the instructions to the jurors to follow in deciding their verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd.

headline: Minneapolis Officer Testifies in Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Sgt. Jon Edwards was the first witness to testify on the fifth day of the Derek Chauvin murder trial. He was sent to secure the crime scene after George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Jon Edwards was the first witness to testify on the fifth day of the Derek Chauvin murder trial. He was sent to secure the crime scene after George Floyd’s death.

headline: Shawanda Hill, George Floyd’s Associate, Testifies in Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Shawanda Hill, an associate of George Floyd’s who was sitting in the back seat of the car when Mr. Floyd was arrested, testified about his demeanor before the arrest.
lead_paragraph: Shawanda Hill, an associate of George Floyd’s who was sitting in the back seat of the car when Mr. Floyd was arrested, testified about his demeanor before the arrest.

headline: ‘Praying the Verdict Is the Right Verdict,’ Biden Tells Floyd Family
abstract: President Biden disclosed the details of a phone call he shared with the family of George Floyd, as the family awaits the verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer accused of killing Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: President Biden disclosed the details of a phone call he shared with the family of George Floyd, as the family awaits the verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer accused of killing Mr. Floyd.

headline: Chauvin Was Convicted. Something Is Still Very Wrong.
abstract: What can be done about all of the suffering that remains?
lead_paragraph: After a wretched and withering year that didn’t so much pass by as scorch through, the guilty verdict in Derek Chauvin’s trial for the murder of George Floyd arrived as a relief. It’s been a long time since it felt as though Americans had the luxury of thinking about the future we want to live in, as opposed to putting out fires in an endless present. In so many respects, we were due for a little hope.

headline: White Police Officer to Face Charge She Intimidated Son’s Black Friend
abstract: Officer Patricia Lio of the Milton Police Department in Massachusetts is accused of berating her son’s 14-year-old Black friend about his stance on the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: A white Massachusetts police officer will face criminal charges in connection with an off-duty episode in which she is accused of berating a Black teenager, a friend of her son, over his support of the Black Lives Matter movement, a court official ruled this week.

headline: ‘I constantly get emotional.’ After a year of protests, Minneapolis activists await justice.
abstract: For some who marched after George Floyd’s death, the murder trial of Derek Chauvin has been difficult to watch.
lead_paragraph: By the time George Floyd died in May, Leslie Redmond was a veteran of protests in Minneapolis. In 2015, she was one of the people who occupied a police precinct for 18 days. In 2020, she was the leader of the local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., organizing marches and meeting with community leaders.

headline: Attorney General Merrick Garland announces an investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department.
abstract: The inquiry will likely lead to a consent decree between the department and the federal government, a tool that the Obama administration repeatedly used to address police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department will investigate the policies and operations of the Minneapolis Police Department, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced on Wednesday, a day after the former officer Derek Chauvin was convicted of murder in the death of George Floyd in a rare rebuke of police violence.

headline: Film Club: ‘Inside the Battle Over George Floyd Square’
abstract: After almost a year of protests, the trial of the former officer accused of killing Floyd has begun. What does the debate over a memorial site tell us about the struggle for racial justice in one city, and for America?

headline: Despite Other Factors, Police Caused Floyd’s Death, Medical Examiner Says
abstract: Dr. Andrew Baker, who performed the official autopsy of George Floyd, said that fentanyl and heart disease had contributed to his death, but that the officers’ actions were the main cause.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — In a trial where many key figures have spent hours on the stand, the prosecution whipped through one of their most anticipated witnesses, the doctor who performed George Floyd’s official autopsy, in a mere 50 minutes on Friday.

headline: Takeaways from the closing arguments of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Prosecutors and the defense made their final pitches to the jury.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks of testimony from 45 witnesses, the lawyers gave their concluding arguments on Monday in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murdering George Floyd.

headline: Little has been said about the $20 bill that brought officers to the scene.
abstract: George Floyd used it to buy cigarettes, but a store clerk thought it was fake. Neither side in the trial has spent much time addressing it.
lead_paragraph: The last three weeks of the Derek Chauvin trial provided jurors with a comprehensive understanding of George Floyd’s final moments, pieced together from hours of video and witness testimony. But there is one part of the case that lawyers for both sides have spent little time on: the $20 bill that brought the police to the scene in the first place.

headline: Key Moments on Day 10 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: George Floyd’s struggle to breathe while under Mr. Chauvin’s knee has become a major discussion during testimony.
lead_paragraph: The trial of the former officer Derek Chauvin will end its second week on Friday after testimony from several witnesses about George Floyd’s precise cause of death. Mr. Floyd was pinned to the ground for more than nine minutes by Mr. Chauvin’s knee; prosecutors are arguing that he died from asphyxia, while the defense says that drugs in his system may be the cause.

headline: Key Moments on Day 14 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Mr. Chauvin invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to testify in his own defense. With testimony concluded, the case will go to the jury on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution and the defense rested their cases in the trial of Derek Chauvin on Thursday, bringing an end to testimony, which in recent days has focused on attempts by Mr. Chauvin’s lawyers to convince  jurors that George Floyd was not killed by Mr. Chauvin’s actions.

headline: Throughout Trial Over George Floyd’s Death, Killings by Police Mount
abstract: Since testimony in Derek Chauvin’s trial began on March 29, more than three people a day have died at the hands of law enforcement.

headline: Morries Hall, who was with George Floyd before his arrest, will not be compelled to take the stand.
abstract: Mr. Hall invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. He was with Mr. Floyd moments before police officers pulled him out of a car and later pinned him to the ground for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: Morries Lester Hall, who was in a car with George Floyd outside of Cup Foods in Minneapolis moments before the police pulled Mr. Floyd out of the car and later pinned him to the ground for more than nine minutes, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when he was called to testify on Wednesday.

headline: A central claim of Derek Chauvin’s defense: Bystanders who witnessed the arrest influenced his actions.
abstract: Eric J. Nelson, a lawyer for Mr. Chauvin, returned again to the people who had watched Mr. Chauvin kneel on George Floyd, suggesting that the crowd was an aggressive and unpredictable group.
lead_paragraph: Since the first day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, it has been one of the central arguments in his defense: that the bystanders who witnessed George Floyd’s arrest last May in Minneapolis also influenced Mr. Chauvin’s actions.

headline: In Photos: America Reacts to the Derek Chauvin Verdict
abstract: Scenes from around the country after Mr. Chauvin was found guilty of murdering George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Cheers erupted in Minneapolis on Tuesday after a jury found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty on all counts in the murder of George Floyd last May.

headline: With George Floyd, a Raging Debate Over Bias in the Science of Death
abstract: Critics say the profession of forensic pathology has been slow to acknowledge how big a role bias may play in decisions such as whether to classify a death in police custody as a homicide.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — From the beginning, the death of George Floyd disrupted the field of forensic pathology in much of the way it challenged policing.

headline: ‘It was a murder in full light of day,’ President Biden says of George Floyd’s death.
abstract: Mr. Biden delivered his nationwide address hours after weighing in on the trial’s outcome and telling reporters that he had been “praying” for the “right verdict.”
lead_paragraph: [Follow live coverage of the Derek Chauvin sentence hearing.]

headline: George Floyd’s Cause of Death Is Crucial in Trial. Forensic Pathologists Explain.
abstract: The prosecution in Derek Chauvin’s trial is trying to establish that George Floyd died from a lack of oxygen. Here, experts break down the key medical terminology surrounding his autopsies.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew Baker may be one of the most important witnesses to be called in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin. It was his duty to determine why George Floyd died.

headline: Expert Witness Pinpoints Floyd’s Final Breath and Dismisses Talk of Overdose
abstract: A pulmonologist told jurors that Derek Chauvin pressed 86.9 pounds onto the neck of George Floyd, who tried to push himself off the pavement with his fingertips.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It was a video everyone in the courtroom has been shown repeatedly, of George Floyd facedown on the street with Derek Chauvin’s knee on his neck. But this time, it was slowed down so the jury could see the briefest widening of Mr. Floyd’s eyes — what the expert witness on the stand on Thursday said was his last conscious moment.

headline: What’s next for the other three officers at the scene of Mr. Floyd’s arrest?
abstract: Thomas Lane, J. Alexander Kueng and Tou Thao were charged with aiding and abetting second-degree murder and aiding and abetting second-degree manslaughter and are expected to be tried jointly beginning in August.
lead_paragraph: Now that the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin has been found guilty in the murder of George Floyd, attention is turning to the coming trial of the other three officers who were involved in the arrest. All three were fired the day after Mr. Floyd’s death, and they are expected to be tried jointly beginning in August.

headline: Derek Chauvin faces three charges. Here’s how his sentencing could unfold.
abstract: How much prison time Mr. Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the killing of George Floyd, would have to serve if he is found guilty will not be decided until several weeks later.
lead_paragraph: If the jury in the trial of Derek Chauvin finds him guilty on any of the three charges he faces, it will certainly be a dramatic televised moment when the verdict is read. But how much prison time Mr. Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged in the killing of George Floyd, would have to serve if he is found guilty will not be decided until several weeks later, after a pre-sentencing report about Mr. Chauvin’s background is produced. Judge Peter A. Cahill would also have to determine if there were special circumstances of the crime that would justify a higher sentence than the prison terms laid out by Minnesota’s sentencing guidelines.

headline: Colorado Judge Will Resign After Using Racial Slur, Court Says
abstract: Natalie T. Chase, a District Court judge in Arapahoe County, agreed to step down after the Colorado Supreme Court censured her for insensitive remarks to Black judicial employees.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado judge has agreed to resign after the state Supreme Court censured her for repeatedly using a racial slur and making insensitive comments to Black judicial employees regarding police brutality and systemic racism.

headline: Republicans’ Fake War Against ‘Woke Capital’
abstract: If they really wanted to help the working class, there is plenty they could do.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party may not have much of an agenda to sell to the public right now, but it does have an enemy with which to rally its troops: “woke capital,” or those corporations that have adopted progressive rhetoric on social issues and used their platforms to support voting rights or back movements like Black Lives Matter.

headline: 3 Indicted on Federal Hate Crime Charges in Ahmaud Arbery Shooting
abstract: The Justice Department’s announcement of the charges was the latest in a string of moves to make civil rights protections a priority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three Georgia men were indicted on federal hate crime charges in connection with the death of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old Black man who was shot to death while jogging through a South Georgia neighborhood last year, the Justice Department announced on Wednesday.

headline: Letter From the Family of Tamir Rice to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland
abstract: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting.
lead_paragraph: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting.

headline: Paramedic Testifies on George Floyd’s Death
abstract: On Thursday, Seth Bravinder, a paramedic, testified that George Floyd was unresponsive when an ambulance arrived at Cup Foods, and that the medical team was unable to revive him.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Seth Bravinder, a paramedic, testified that George Floyd was unresponsive when an ambulance arrived at Cup Foods, and that the medical team was unable to revive him.

headline: Minneapolis Police Chief Says Chauvin Violated Policy
abstract: Chief Medaria Arradondo testified Monday that the former officer Derek Chauvin should have halted his use of force to restrain George Floyd after Mr. Floyd had stopped resisting.
lead_paragraph: Chief Medaria Arradondo testified Monday that the former officer Derek Chauvin should have halted his use of force to restrain George Floyd after Mr. Floyd had stopped resisting.

headline: Watch Live: George Floyd’s Family Reacts to Verdict
abstract: The family of George Floyd hold a news conference after the jury announced the guilty verdict in the trial of the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.
lead_paragraph: The family of George Floyd hold a news conference after the jury announced the guilty verdict in the trial of the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

headline: Prosecution Presents Rebuttal in Closing Arguments
abstract: Jerry Blackwell, a prosecutor in the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin, made closing arguments on Monday, urging jurors to use common sense to evaluate the evidence and find Mr. Chauvin guilty in the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Blackwell, a prosecutor in the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin, made closing arguments on Monday, urging jurors to use common sense to evaluate the evidence and find Mr. Chauvin guilty in the death of George Floyd.

headline: Pulmonologist Says George Floyd Died From a ‘Low Level of Oxygen’
abstract: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a world-renowned expert on breathing, testified on Thursday that George Floyd died from a “low level of oxygen.” His testimony also highlighted how force from Derek Chauvin’s knee and Mr. Floyd’s position on the concrete obstructed Mr. Floyd’s airways.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a world-renowned expert on breathing, testified on Thursday that George Floyd died from a “low level of oxygen.” His testimony also highlighted how force from Derek Chauvin’s knee and Mr. Floyd’s position on the concrete obstructed Mr. Floyd’s airways.

headline: Defense Concludes With ‘Burden of Proof’ Argument in Chauvin Trial
abstract: The defense in the Derek Chauvin trial, the former Minneapolis police officer accused of killing George Floyd, argued in its closing statements that the jury must prove Mr. Chauvin was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
lead_paragraph: The defense in the Derek Chauvin trial, the former Minneapolis police officer accused of killing George Floyd, argued in its closing statements that the jury must prove Mr. Chauvin was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.

headline: As protests against police violence surge, Florida passes a bill to combat ‘public disorder.’
abstract: Critics call the measure racist and anti-democratic, and say it could criminalize peaceful demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led Florida Senate on Thursday passed a bill that was intended to crack down on rioting, but that critics said would criminalize the peaceful demonstrations against police brutality that have swept across the state and the country since the killing of George Floyd last year.

headline: George Floyd, Indianapolis, Spring Migration: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Key Moments on Day 6 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: The chief of the Minneapolis Police Department testified on Monday that Mr. Chauvin had “absolutely” violated department policies when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: After a week of often emotional and occasionally explosive testimony, the trial of Derek Chauvin resumed on Monday, with the prosecution continuing to present witnesses that they hope will support the charges of murder in the death of George Floyd.

headline: What is proportional force?
abstract: Proportional force is the idea that the force that an officer is supposed to use on a suspect, including the use of chokeholds or other neck restraints, should not be more intense than necessary.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “proportional force” or “proportional use of force” has been mentioned several times during the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis officer who has been charged with the death of George Floyd.

headline: George Floyd showed signs of a brain injury 4 minutes before Derek Chauvin lifted his knee, a doctor testifies.
abstract: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a lung expert, said Mr. Floyd died of “a low level of oxygen” caused in part by Mr. Chauvin’s pressure, and that fentanyl did not have an effect on Mr. Floyd’s breathing before he lost consciousness.
lead_paragraph: A veteran lung doctor testified on Thursday that George Floyd’s death was caused in part by Derek Chauvin’s knees pressing against his neck and back, making it impossible for him to breathe, and that Mr. Floyd showed signs of a brain injury about four minutes before Mr. Chauvin lifted his knee from his neck.

headline: Lawmakers and activists react to the Derek Chauvin verdict.
abstract: “Today, a jury did the right thing,” former President Barack Obama said. “But true justice requires much more.”
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin’s murder conviction on Tuesday in the killing of George Floyd brought a flood of emotion from the streets of Minneapolis to the halls of Congress, tempered with exhortations not to view the verdict as a victory against systemic racism.

headline: Darnella Frazier captured George Floyd’s death on her cellphone. The teenager’s video shaped the Chauvin trial.
abstract: Ms. Frazier was 17 when she recorded the cellphone video in May and uploaded it to Facebook. ‘When I look at George Floyd, I look at my dad,’ she said in court.
lead_paragraph: Months before the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who was convicted of killing George Floyd, millions of people around the world watched footage of Mr. Floyd’s death that had been recorded by a teenage witness.

headline: Late Night Gets Serious About Police Brutality
abstract: Trevor Noah and Stephen Colbert criticized officers’ use of force against Black men, citing two cases in which traffic stops turned violent.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Lawyers for George Floyd’s family say jurors should look past his drug use after hearing testimony about his addiction.
abstract: Many people who are addicted to drugs “are treated with dignity, respect and support, not brutality,” the lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: Two lawyers for the family of George Floyd said jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin should look beyond Mr. Floyd’s drug use after his girlfriend testified on Thursday about their shared struggles with addiction.

headline: With Closing Arguments Finished, Chauvin’s Fate Is Now in Jury’s Hands
abstract: The jury will be sequestered in a hotel during their deliberations over Derek Chauvin, who is charged with second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The two sides in one of the nation’s most closely watched police brutality trials returned one last time to the graphic video of George Floyd’s final moments on Monday, with the prosecution asking jurors to “believe your eyes” and the defense warning them not to be “misled” by a freeze-frame view.

headline: Minneapolis’s Native American community is closely watching the trial.
abstract: The American Indian Center was near areas that were damaged in protests after George Floyd’s death, and residents are preparing for possible unrest again after a verdict.
lead_paragraph: The regular updates that Johnny Crow’s girlfriend gives him about the former officer Derek Chauvin’s trial trigger reminders of how the Native American community in Minneapolis rallied to support one another in the months after George Floyd died.

headline: ‘He showed us how to treat our mom,’ George Floyd’s brother breaks down during his testimony.
abstract: Philonise Floyd described his oldest brother as a “leader in the household” who had a close relationship with their mother.
lead_paragraph: In brief, but tearful testimony, Philonise Floyd spoke in loving terms about his oldest brother, George Floyd, on the 11th day of testimony in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin.

headline: George Floyd’s girlfriend described their relationship: A shared struggle with addiction, their first kiss, a ‘dad selfie.’
abstract: Courteney Ross, 45, said she and Mr. Floyd had started taking opioids when they were prescribed for chronic pain.
lead_paragraph: Courteney Ross, who was dating George Floyd for nearly three years before his death in May, delivered tearful testimony on Thursday about their shared struggle with an opioid addiction.

headline: Policing Is Not Broken. It’s ‘Literally Designed to Work in This Way.’
abstract: Jane Coaston debates three proposals to fix America’s broken policing.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin has been found guilty of the murder of George Floyd. But whatever bittersweet feelings the rare outcome elicited were short-lived, since instances of police brutality compound almost daily. There’s no debate: Policing is broken in America. But how do we fix it?

headline: In Rare Testimony, Chief Says Chauvin ‘Should Have Stopped’ Pinning Floyd
abstract: “To continue to apply that level of force to a person proned out, handcuffed behind their back — that in no way, shape or form is anything that is by policy,” Chief Medaria Arradondo testified.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The prospect that a police chief would take the witness stand against a fellow officer is exceedingly rare. But there was the chief of the Minneapolis Police Department on Monday, condemning the actions of Derek Chauvin, the officer charged with murdering George Floyd, as wrong by every imaginable measure.

headline: A Jane Austen Museum Wants to Discuss Slavery. Will Her Fans Listen?
abstract: Exhibits at the house where the writer lived in the early 1800s are being updated to add historical context. Not everyone is thrilled.
lead_paragraph: As part of the discussion over racism that followed the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, museums have asserted solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and begun to rethink and recast how they portray history.

headline: Rage Is the Only Language I Have Left
abstract: Society has become horribly desensitized to police killings of Black men.
lead_paragraph: One of the first times I wrote about the police killing of an unarmed Black man was when Michael Brown was gunned down in the summer of 2014 in Ferguson, Mo. Brown was a Black teenager accused of an infraction in a convenience store just before his life was taken. Last summer, six years on, I wrote about George Floyd, a large Black man accused of an infraction in a convenience store, this time in Minneapolis.

headline: School District Investigating ‘Abhorrent’ George Floyd Image Posted by Student
abstract: A football player posted the image, which superimposed two Virginia high schools’ logos on the faces of Derek Chauvin and George Floyd, to celebrate his team’s victory, according to the district superintendent.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia school district said it was investigating an image posted on social media by a high school football player that repurposed a photo of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murdering George Floyd, kneeling on Mr. Floyd’s neck to celebrate his team’s recent victory.

headline: Defense focuses on George Floyd’s prior arrest and drug use.
abstract: Judge Peter Cahill, who has maintained that Mr. Floyd’s past actions are largely irrelevant to the case, initially said that the prior arrest could not be introduced in court.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin’s defense hinges on an argument that George Floyd’s drug use, not Mr. Chauvin’s knee, caused his death. To that end, the defense asked permission to present an arrest of Mr. Floyd in May 2019 — exposing jurors to Mr. Floyd’s history of interactions with law enforcement.

headline: George Floyd was dead by the time medical help arrived, a paramedic testified.
abstract: Derek Smith, the paramedic, said that he had first felt Mr. Floyd’s neck for a pulse while police officers were still on top of him and that he could not find one.
lead_paragraph: When a paramedic arrived at the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, he could not find a pulse and believed that Mr. Floyd was already dead, he testified in court on Thursday.

headline: Derek Chauvin is found guilty of murdering George Floyd.
abstract: The jury convicted Mr. Chauvin of second- and third-degree murder, as well as manslaughter. He faces up to 40 years in prison but is likely to be sentenced to far less time, based on state guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin was found guilty of two counts of murder on Tuesday in the death of George Floyd, whose final breaths last May under the knee of Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, were captured on video, setting off months of protests against the police abuse of Black people.

headline: Takeaways from Derek Chauvin’s defense case.
abstract: The presentation of evidence concluded on Thursday without testimony from Mr. Chauvin himself.
lead_paragraph: The presentation of evidence in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in the death of George Floyd, concluded on Thursday without testimony from Mr. Chauvin himself.

headline: President Biden calls George Floyd’s family and says evidence for a guilty verdict is ‘overwhelming.’
abstract: Mr. Biden said he expressed his support and sympathy during the call and told reporters that he was praying for “the right verdict” in the Derek Chauvin trial.
lead_paragraph: President Biden called the family of George Floyd on Monday to express his support and sympathy, telling reporters on Tuesday that the evidence against the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was “overwhelming” and that he was praying for the “right verdict.” Hours later, a jury found Mr. Chauvin guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder and manslaughter.

headline: Dr. Andrew Baker, Hennepin County’s chief medical examiner, takes the stand.
abstract: Dr. Baker determined during his autopsy of George Floyd that he died from “cardiopulmonary arrest” and declared his death a homicide.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew Baker, the Hennepin County medical examiner,  testified on Friday at former officer Derek Chauvin’s trial that he found bruises on George Floyd’s body during the initial autopsy.

headline: Hollywood’s Anti-Black Bias Costs It $10 Billion a Year
abstract: If the industry won’t change on principle, it can at least change for the money. Reform would enrich people of color, and everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Days after a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, suffocated George Floyd and the video went viral, I watched my social media feed fill with blackout tiles and corporate publicity statements. They poured in from every industry, proclaiming solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement. Hollywood — where I have worked for almost two decades — was no exception.

headline: An Alameda Police Officer Used His Knee to Pin Down Mario Gonzalez
abstract: An analysis of body camera footage shows that one officer appeared to keep his knee on the upper right side of Mr. Gonzalez’s back for 2 minutes 50 seconds.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — One day before a Minneapolis jury convicted a former officer of murdering George Floyd, police officers answering a complaint about someone loitering in a park in the Bay Area suburb of Alameda pinned Mario Arenales Gonzalez to the ground facedown, using their knees, elbows and forearms.

headline: Takeaways from Day 13 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: The first medical expert called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team said George Floyd died after a combination of factors — including pre-existing heart conditions, drug use and exposure to vehicle exhaust from the police cruiser — caused his death. He faced difficult cross-examination.
lead_paragraph: The first medical expert witness called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team faced difficult cross-examination on Wednesday after he testified that George Floyd died from sudden cardiac arrhythmia, rather than a deprivation of oxygen caused by Mr. Chauvin.

headline: Here are the takeaways from Day 6 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Jurors heard from two key witnesses, including the chief of police. He said Mr. Chauvin “absolutely” violated department policies.
lead_paragraph: The sixth day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, brought two key witnesses to the stand: the doctor who spent 30 minutes trying to save Mr. Floyd’s life before pronouncing him dead, and the chief of the Minneapolis Police Department.

headline: Michigan, George Floyd, Baseball: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Derek Chauvin is being held in solitary confinement for 23 hours a day.
abstract: He has been placed in an isolated wing of Minnesota’s only maximum-security prison because of fears for his safety.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin is being held in solitary confinement for 23 hours a day in Minnesota’s only maximum-security prison after he was convicted of murdering George Floyd and led out of a courtroom in handcuffs, according to authorities.

headline: Use-of Force Expert Says Chauvin’s Actions Were Justified
abstract: Barry Brodd, a former police officer and use-of-force expert, testified on Tuesday that Derek Chauvin’s actions during the arrest of George Floyd were justified by Mr. Floyd’s resistance.
lead_paragraph: Barry Brodd, a former police officer and use-of-force expert, testified on Tuesday that Derek Chauvin’s actions during the arrest of George Floyd were justified by Mr. Floyd’s resistance.

headline: Forensic Pathologist Says Floyd Should Have Received Medical Aid
abstract: Dr. David Fowler, a medical expert called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team, said under cross examination on Wednesday that George Floyd might have survived if he received immediate medical attention.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Fowler, a medical expert called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team, said under cross examination on Wednesday that George Floyd might have survived if he received immediate medical attention.

headline: Floyd Family Reacts to Guilty Verdict
abstract: Relatives of George Floyd, the Black man killed by the former police officer Derek Chauvin, spoke out after Mr. Chauvin was found guilty of murder and manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of George Floyd, the Black man killed by the former police officer Derek Chauvin, spoke out after Mr. Chauvin was found guilty of murder and manslaughter.

headline: Police Officer Testifies on ‘Aggressive’ Crowd During George Floyd Arrest
abstract: Peter Chang, a Minneapolis Park Police officer, said he was worried about the crowd watching George Floyd’s arrest. The defense has suggested that the crowd distracted Derek Chauvin, the former officer on trial for the killing of Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Peter Chang, a Minneapolis Park Police officer, said he was worried about the crowd watching George Floyd’s arrest. The defense has suggested that the crowd distracted Derek Chauvin, the former officer on trial for the killing of Mr. Floyd.

headline: At Chauvin Trial, Debating What George Floyd Said About Drugs
abstract: During the trial on Wednesday, expert witnesses were asked by defense and prosecution lawyers to decipher a muffled portion of audio in which George Floyd referred to drugs during his arrest.
lead_paragraph: During the trial on Wednesday, expert witnesses were asked by defense and prosecution lawyers to decipher a muffled portion of audio in which George Floyd referred to drugs during his arrest.

headline: From Rodney King to George Floyd: Reliving the Scars of Police Violence
abstract: The murder trial of Derek Chauvin is at the center of a national reckoning on race and policing. But cycles of protests over systemic racism and policing are not new. We watched the trial with the families of Rodney King, Oscar Grant and Stephon Clark to see this moment in history through their eyes.
lead_paragraph: The murder trial of Derek Chauvin is at the center of a national reckoning on race and policing. But cycles of protests over systemic racism and policing are not new. We watched the trial with the families of Rodney King, Oscar Grant and Stephon Clark to see this moment in history through their eyes.

headline: Fowler Says He Would Classify Floyd’s Death as ‘Undetermined’
abstract: Dr. David Fowler, former Maryland chief medical examiner, testified on Wednesday that he would classify George Floyd’s death as “undetermined,” with a primary cause of cardiac arrhythmia during police restraint.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Fowler, former Maryland chief medical examiner, testified on Wednesday that he would classify George Floyd’s death as “undetermined,” with a primary cause of cardiac arrhythmia during police restraint.

headline: Witness With George Floyd Before His Arrest Will Not Take the Stand
abstract: Morries Lester Hall, who was in a car with George Floyd before his arrest, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when he was called to testify on Wednesday in Derek Chauvin’s murder trial.
lead_paragraph: Morries Lester Hall, who was in a car with George Floyd before his arrest, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when he was called to testify on Wednesday in Derek Chauvin’s murder trial.

headline: Expert on Use of Force Testifies in Chauvin Trial
abstract: Seth Stoughton, a law professor and former police officer, told jurors on Monday that “no reasonable officer” should have acted the way Derek Chauvin did while arresting George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Seth Stoughton, a law professor and former police officer, told jurors on Monday that “no reasonable officer” should have acted the way Derek Chauvin did while arresting George Floyd.

headline: Pulmonologist Testifies Fentanyl Did Not Impact George Floyd’s Breathing
abstract: Dr. Martin Tobin, an expert pulmonologist, said that George Floyd’s breathing rate in the moments before he died indicated that the fentanyl in his system was not having any effect on his breathing, despite the argument by Derek Chauvin’s legal team.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Martin Tobin, an expert pulmonologist, said that George Floyd’s breathing rate in the moments before he died indicated that the fentanyl in his system was not having any effect on his breathing, despite the argument by Derek Chauvin’s legal team.

headline: Prosecutor in Derek Chauvin trial makes closing argument: ‘This wasn’t policing, this was murder.’
abstract: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer.
lead_paragraph: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer and should be convicted of murder in George Floyd’s death.

headline: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a pulmonologist, says shallow breathing led to George Floyd’s death.
abstract: During his testimony, Dr. Tobin said that several things — Mr. Floyd’s prone position, his being handcuffed, and having a knee on his neck and back — contributed to his shallow breathing.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Martin J. Tobin, a pulmonologist and critical care physician from the Chicago area, was the first witness prosecutors called to the stand in the Derek Chauvin trial on Thursday.

headline: Minneapolis steps up security for the Chauvin verdict. Here’s what you need to know.
abstract: The plan, which includes nine state and local agencies, called Operation Safety Net, is one of the biggest in the state’s history.
lead_paragraph: With a verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin set to come as early as next week, the city of Minneapolis is already preparing for protests and civil unrest. The plan, which includes nine state and local agencies, called Operation Safety Net, is one of the biggest in the state’s history, likely only trailing the response to the 2007 collapse of the Interstate 35 bridge and the protests after George Floyd died in May.

headline: David Fowler, former chief medical examiner of Maryland, says he believes George Floyd died from cardiac arrhythmia.
abstract: Dr. Fowler, who retired as the state’s chief medical examiner in 2019, has a history of involvement with high-profile police use-of-force cases.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin’s defense called on Dr. David Fowler, who retired as Maryland’s chief medical examiner in 2019 and has a history of involvement with high-profile police use-of-force cases, to testify on Wednesday as an expert witness.

headline: Morries Hall, a friend of George Floyd’s who was with him when he was arrested, is trying to avoid testifying.
abstract: A judge ordered Derek Chauvin’s lawyer to draft a list of questions that Mr. Hall might be able to answer without incriminating himself.
lead_paragraph: Morries Lester Hall, a friend of George Floyd’s who was in a car with him on May 25, moments before the police pulled Mr. Floyd out of the car and pinned him to the ground, is hoping to avoid testifying in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin.

headline: The officer who secured the crime scene after George Floyd’s death is the first witness on Day 5.
abstract: Sgt. Jon Edwards, who has worked for the Minneapolis Police Department for more than 10 years, took the stand on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Witness testimony resumed Friday morning in the Derek Chauvin trial with Sgt. Jon Edwards of the Minneapolis Police Department taking the stand. Sergeant Edwards was sent to Cup Foods to secure the crime scene after police officers pinned George Floyd to the ground outside of the convenience store.

headline: After the Pandemic and Protests, a British Rapper Spotlights Black Businesses
abstract: Black Pound Day was created to find a sustainable way to support Black-owned businesses after the Black Lives Matter street protests faded.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Aimée Felone, whose children’s bookstore in London stocks tales with ethnically diverse characters, the Black Lives Matter protests last summer were, in a word, overwhelming.

headline: Key Moments From Day 7 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: Lawyers for both the prosecution and the defense continued to argue over whether Mr. Chauvin violated police policy when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: Several members of the Minneapolis Police Department testified in the trial of former officer Derek Chauvin on Tuesday, providing key support for prosecutors’ arguments that his actions last May killed George Floyd.

headline: What are the charges against Derek Chauvin?
abstract: The former Minneapolis police officer faces three charges in the death of George Floyd: second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: The former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin, 45, faces three charges in the death of George Floyd: second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.

headline: Race and the Coming Liberal Crackup
abstract: Our racialized politics will produce a conservative resurgence.
lead_paragraph: Americans breathed a collective sigh of relief last week after Derek Chauvin was convicted of murdering George Floyd. The crime was heinous, the verdict just, the moral neat. If you think that systemic racism is the defining fact of race relations in 21st-century America, then Chauvin’s knee on Floyd’s neck is its defining image.

headline: Justin Fairfax Accuses Terry McAuliffe of Treating Him Like Emmett Till
abstract: At a debate for Virginia governor, Mr. Fairfax, the state’s lieutenant governor, denounced Mr. McAuliffe for urging him to resign after women accused Mr. Fairfax of sexual assault in 2019.
lead_paragraph: Terry McAuliffe, the leading candidate in this year’s Democratic primary for Virginia governor, faced a flurry of attacks from his rivals at a debate on Tuesday night as they aimed to diminish his broad support from Black voters. In the most extraordinary broadside, the state’s Black lieutenant governor, Justin Fairfax, accused Mr. McAuliffe of treating him like George Floyd or Emmett Till after Mr. Fairfax was accused of sexual assault by two women in 2019.

headline: Listening to Those Who Saw George Floyd Die
abstract: The witnesses who testified this week are still tormented by that day.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than 10 months since George Floyd was pinned to the Minneapolis pavement, a knee hard on his neck as the life drained senselessly out of him and he moaned, again and again, “I can’t breathe.” The small group of people who were there — along with countless others who watched the horrifying video — have had all that time to come to terms with it, or at least to try.

headline: George Floyd’s Girlfriend Says Opioid Addiction Was a Struggle They Shared
abstract: The testimony was partly an effort by the prosecution to show that Mr. Floyd had a high tolerance for fentanyl, which could undercut any argument that he died of a drug overdose.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — They met one evening four summers ago, and she was instantly drawn to his “great, deep, Southern voice.” She gave him her phone number that night, and they became close, exploring the city’s sculpture garden and its vibrant restaurant scene. Soon she was simply calling him “Floyd,” just like his friends did.

headline: Sports world celebrates Chauvin verdict amid controversy over Raiders’ ‘I can breathe’ tweet.
abstract: Davis said: “If I offended the family, then I’m deeply, deeply disappointed.”
lead_paragraph: The reverberations throughout the sports world came swiftly after a jury in Minnesota convicted Derek Chauvin on Tuesday of murdering George Floyd, as athletes, teams and leagues weighed in on the verdict in a case that had reignited fierce debate about racism and policing in the United States.

headline: ‘I Could Feel Their Pain’: A Juror on the Chauvin Trial Speaks Out
abstract: She was known as Juror 96 and sat through three weeks of testimony, but Lisa Christensen didn’t get to decide Derek Chauvin’s fate. She was selected as an alternate.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Lisa Christensen stood feet from the blue angel painted on a patch of pavement she had become intimately familiar with over the past month. Under the spittle of rain droplets, she clasped her hands in front of her chest and said a prayer to George Floyd.

headline: Biden’s Address, Ahmaud Arbery, Whiskey: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Can Policing Change?
abstract: As the Derek Chauvin trial heads to the jury, a look at attempts to improve policing.
lead_paragraph: Since George Floyd’s death last May, dozens of states and local governments have changed their laws about police behavior. And yet police officers continue to kill about three Americans each day on average, nearly identical to the rate of police killings for as long as statistics exist.

headline: On the Scene: Week 1 of the Trial of Derek Chauvin
abstract: Times photographers captured the events across Minneapolis as the trial over the death of George Floyd began.
lead_paragraph: Minneapolis was a city of protest and remembrance during the first days of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the white former police officer who is on trial in the death of George Floyd, the Black man whose neck he knelt on for more than nine minutes during an arrest last May.

headline: His Fence Says ‘Black Lives Matter.’ His City Says Paint Over It.
abstract: West St. Paul, Minn., says the nearly 75-foot message violates multiple portions of city code. The conflict is brewing as the Twin Cities region uneasily awaits a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial.
lead_paragraph: The colorful mural, adorned with hearts, a portrait of a local activist and the words “Black Lives Matter,” stands out at a busy intersection in West St. Paul, a community nestled against the Twin Cities. It is a cherished symbol for many Black residents, a site of reflection and pride.

headline: Takeaways from Day 8 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: A use-of-force expert called by prosecutors said Mr. Chauvin used “deadly force,” even though George Floyd posed no immediate threat.
lead_paragraph: A use-of-force expert called by prosecutors testified on Wednesday that , the police officer charged with murdering George Floyd, used “deadly force” when it was appropriate to use none.

headline: Floyd’s Cause of Death Was Homicide, Medical Examiner Says
abstract: Dr. Andrew Baker, the Hennepin County medical examiner who performed the initial autopsy of George Floyd, said that there were contributing factors to Mr. Floyd’s death but that ultimately it was homicide.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew Baker, the Hennepin County medical examiner who performed the initial autopsy of George Floyd, said that there were contributing factors to Mr. Floyd’s death but that ultimately it was homicide.

headline: Chauvin’s Use of Neck Restraint Was Unauthorized, Trainer Says
abstract: Lt. Johnny Mercil of the Minneapolis Police Department said Tuesday that neck restraints are sometimes allowed but that the former officer Derek Chauvin’s use of the technique on George Floyd was not appropriate.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Johnny Mercil of the Minneapolis Police Department said Tuesday that neck restraints are sometimes allowed but that the former officer Derek Chauvin’s use of the technique on George Floyd was not appropriate.

headline: Chauvin Trial: Day 4 Key Moments
abstract: As the murder trial of Derek Chauvin continued for a fourth day on Thursday, those who testified included George Floyd’s girlfriend and emergency responders who were on duty the day Mr. Floyd died.
lead_paragraph: As the murder trial of Derek Chauvin continued for a fourth day on Thursday, those who testified included George Floyd’s girlfriend and emergency responders who were on duty the day Mr. Floyd died.

headline: Retired Police Officer Is Questioned on George Floyd’s Prior Arrest
abstract: The defense questioned the former police officer Scott Creighton about a May 6, 2019, traffic stop during which a passenger, whom Mr. Creighton identified as Mr. Floyd, was not responsive to his commands. His testimony was limited to the physical effects of opioids on Mr. Floyd.
lead_paragraph: The defense questioned the former police officer Scott Creighton about a May 6, 2019, traffic stop during which a passenger, whom Mr. Creighton identified as Mr. Floyd, was not responsive to his commands. His testimony was limited to the physical effects of opioids on Mr. Floyd.

headline: George Floyd Died Before Medics Arrived, Paramedic Says
abstract: Derek Smith, one of the paramedics called to the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, testified in court on Thursday that when he arrived it appeared that Mr. Floyd was already dead.
lead_paragraph: Derek Smith, one of the paramedics called to the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, testified in court on Thursday that when he arrived it appeared that Mr. Floyd was already dead.

headline: Protests Erupt After Minnesota Officer Shoots Black Man
abstract: Hundreds of people took to the streets in Brooklyn Center, Minn., near where Derek Chauvin is on trial for the death of George Floyd, after a police officer fatally shot a 20-year-old Black driver during a traffic stop on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people took to the streets in Brooklyn Center, Minn., near where Derek Chauvin is on trial for the death of George Floyd, after a police officer fatally shot a 20-year-old Black driver during a traffic stop on Sunday.

headline: Inside the Chauvin Jury Room: 11 of 12 Jurors Were Ready to Convict Right Away
abstract: One juror described the seven hours of closed-door deliberations that led to Derek Chauvin’s murder conviction.
lead_paragraph: Seated at tables six feet apart in a hotel conference room, 12 jurors scribbled letters on slips of paper to indicate how they were leaning on a murder charge against Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer on trial for killing George Floyd.

headline: George Floyd, Johnson & Johnson, Philip Roth: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 6 Takeaways From the First Week of the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: It began with tears and shaky voices, and ended with a stunning condemnation by a senior police officer. The trial of Mr. Chauvin, charged in the death of George Floyd, will resume on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The first week of the murder trial of Derek Chauvin in Minneapolis was marked by emotional accounts from bystanders who watched Mr. Chauvin pin George Floyd to the ground for more than nine minutes in May.

headline: Barry Brodd, a former police officer and use-of-force expert, says Derek Chauvin’s actions were ‘justified.’
abstract: Mr. Brodd’s testimony countered that of prosecution witnesses who have argued the opposite.
lead_paragraph: Barry Brodd, a former police officer and use-of-force expert, testified for the defense that Derek Chauvin’s use of force against George Floyd was justified — countering two weeks of prosecution witnesses who argued the opposite.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Guilty on all counts.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, was found guilty on all counts in the death of George Floyd on Tuesday. The verdict capped one of the most-watched trials in the U.S. in recent memory. Follow live reaction.

headline: In his closing argument, Derek Chauvin’s lawyer urges jurors to ‘not let yourselves be misled.’
abstract: A lawyer for Mr. Chauvin argued that the former officer had acted reasonably when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes, imploring jurors to also consider the moments before officers took Mr. Floyd to the ground.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for Derek Chauvin argued on Monday that the former officer had acted reasonably when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes, imploring jurors to also consider the moments before officers took Mr. Floyd to the ground as they begin to debate whether to convict or acquit Mr. Chauvin.

headline: Burning of Police Station After George Floyd’s Death Draws 4-Year Sentence
abstract: A 23-year-old Brainerd, Minn., man was also ordered to pay $12 million for his role in the fire in Minneapolis, U.S. prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Three days after George Floyd was killed in police custody in Minneapolis last year, the city’s Third Precinct police building was set on fire. Thousands of protesters surrounded the building as it burned, sending giant orange flames and tall black clouds of smoke into the sky.

headline: In the Chauvin trial, an argument emerges over whether George Floyd said he ‘ate too many drugs’ or ‘ain’t do no drugs.’
abstract: Prosecutors have spent considerable time during their presentation dealing with the defense’s assertions that drugs played a role in Mr. Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: James D. Reyerson of the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension testified on Wednesday, offering a view of the death of George Floyd from an agent who was tasked with investigating it.

headline: What we know about Courteney Ross, George Floyd’s former girlfriend.
abstract: Ms. Ross was called on by the prosecution to testify on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Courteney Ross, a former girlfriend of George Floyd, was called on by the prosecution to testify on Thursday.

headline: Did the Music Industry Change? A Race ‘Report Card’ Is on the Way.
abstract: The Black Music Action Coalition, a group of managers, lawyers and others, was created last summer with a mission to hold the business to account. In June, it will report on the progress so far.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, as protests roiled over the death of George Floyd, the music industry began to take a hard look at itself with regard to race — how it treats Black artists, how Black employees fare at music companies, how equitably money flows throughout the business.

headline: Back to High School, After Missing So Much
abstract: Students missed homecoming, field trips and classes, while also handling anxiety and economic precarity. Now, they must leap into the future, with the school’s help.
lead_paragraph: WATERBURY, Conn. — This fall, there is a surreal swirl of newness and oldness in the hallways of John F. Kennedy High School: Black Lives Matter face masks and exhortations to pull them up — “Over your nose, please!” — but also ribbing and laughter, bells ringing, hall passes being checked and loudspeaker reminders about the dress code (collared black or navy shirts and khaki or black bottoms).

headline: Peter Williams, 69, Dies; His Art Evoked Black Lives, Including His
abstract: His colorful works could be quite personal, or they could be blunt responses to police brutality or other news of the day.
lead_paragraph: Peter Williams, whose colorful paintings — sometimes humorous, sometimes disturbing, often both — reflected his own history, Black history and contemporary issues like police brutality and mass incarceration, died on Aug. 19 in Wilmington, Del. He was 69.

headline: A Congresswoman’s Story: Raped at 17, ‘I Chose to Have an Abortion’
abstract: After a legal setback for abortion rights, three Democratic representatives and one Republican shared their personal stories with a House panel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Cori Bush, a Democrat from Missouri, is known on Capitol Hill as a nurse, a pastor, a Black Lives Matter activist and a member of a “squad” of progressive women lawmakers. On Thursday, she told a House panel that she is also a rape survivor who had an abortion after she was attacked on a church trip when she was 17.

headline: The Missing Piece in the Push for Boardroom Diversity
abstract: Private companies are lagging behind publicly traded firms, but don’t receive the same scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, major public companies across the country pledged to increase diversity in their boardrooms, one of the actions taken after the murder of George Floyd in police custody. Corporate directors set goals, and some have begun to make progress, with investors, activists and others tracking their commitments on racial equity.

headline: Former Prosecutor in Ahmaud Arbery’s Death Faces Criminal Charges
abstract: Jackie Johnson was indicted by a grand jury in Glynn County, Ga., on charges of “violation of oath of public officer” and “obstruction and hindering a law enforcement officer.”
lead_paragraph: A grand jury indicted a former prosecutor in Georgia on Thursday, accusing her of “showing favor and affection” to one of the men now charged with killing Ahmaud Arbery and for directing police officers not to arrest another suspect.

headline: Ozy Built a TV Show on a False Claim, Says Its Former Producer
abstract: Producers say they were led to believe they were making a talk show for A&E, which said no to the program. “You are playing a dangerous game with the truth,” the top producer wrote in his resignation email.
lead_paragraph: By the summer of 2020, Brad Bessey was winding down a long career in television, one that included two daytime Emmy Awards and stints as an executive producer at “Entertainment Tonight” and “The Talk.” He was also, like many Americans in the summer of Covid and George Floyd, eager to make a meaningful social contribution. So when his agent approached him about working for a talk show that would go deep on important social questions, and whose host wanted to bring the country together, he jumped at it.

headline: How a Publishing Executive Spends Her Sundays
abstract: It’s all about books for Sanyu Dillon, although instead of marketing them, she reads them.
lead_paragraph: “At the beginning of Covid, you could see the evolution of readers’ needs through what was selling,” said Sanyu Dillon, the chief marketing officer for Penguin Random House. It started with a rise in interactive workbooks for children, she said. Later last spring, “baking, cooking, dog training and interior design saw an increase,” she continued. Last summer “was a call for racial justice books after the murder of George Floyd” and last fall, political books were popular.

headline: Minnesota Troopers Deleted Texts and Emails After Floyd Protests, Major Testifies
abstract: According to a transcript released Friday, a member of the Minnesota State Patrol said there was “a purge of emails and text messages” after troopers responded to protests in Minneapolis last year.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota State Patrol troopers deleted text messages and emails shortly after responding to protests that erupted over the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, according to a major who testified in federal court in July.

headline: Books on Race Filled Best-Seller Lists Last Year. Publishers Took Notice.
abstract: In recent years, a strong interest in books on race and racism has accelerated. Authors, agents and editors are anxious to see how they do.
lead_paragraph: After George Floyd was murdered last May, and protests demanding racial justice swelled around the United States, bookstores had trouble keeping “So You Want to Talk About Race” by Ijeoma Oluo in stock. They couldn’t keep “White Fragility” by Robin DiAngelo or “The New Jim Crow,” a 2010 book by Michelle Alexander, on shelves either.

headline: N.F.L. Will Allow Six Social Justice Messages on Players’ Helmets
abstract: The decals, with messages such as “Stop Hate” and “Black Lives Matter,” are part of the league’s efforts to show solidarity with players who have protested against racism and police brutality.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. will allow players to display messages of social justice on their helmets and will stencil the slogans “It Takes All of Us” and “End Racism” on the end zones at every field as part of an effort to show solidarity with the protest movements against racism and police brutality, league officials said.

headline: The Black Recovery Stories Speaking to Individual and Collective Wellness
abstract: Long sidelined, these narratives are ascendant in the culture, and offer an elastic yet demanding view of what it might take for Americans — and their nation — to heal.
lead_paragraph: FOR ALL THAT was emotionally sobering about the last year, it was literally sobering, too. Many Americans, drinking more than ever during Covid-19 lockdowns and with plenty of time to reflect on it, began to wonder if alcohol was more hindrance than help. The question had been popularized by the sober-curious movement, based on a term coined by the British author Ruby Warrington, and supported by online recovery programs such as Tempest, founded in 2014. But it became especially acute as the incoherent national response to the Covid-19 pandemic conspired with a failing health care system to prove once again that the state could not be trusted to ensure its citizens’ wellness. This was particularly true, the reanimated Black Lives Matter movement announced, when those citizens were brown or Black.

headline: Virginia Supreme Court Clears Path for Removal of Robert E. Lee Statue
abstract: Two unanimous rulings allow Gov. Ralph Northam to remove the statue from its prominent spot on Monument Avenue in Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously affirmed the power of Gov. Ralph Northam to remove an imposing statue of Robert E. Lee in Richmond, a symbol that had become a target of demonstrators after the death of George Floyd last year.

headline: The World’s Wokest Sports League Bows to China
abstract: The N.B.A. apologizes on behalf of Daryl Morey, a general manager who voiced support for democracy.
lead_paragraph: The national editor of this newspaper last year asked the commissioner of the N.B.A. at a conference how it felt “to be the wokest professional sports league.” It was a fair description: While Colin Kaepernick has been unable to find a job in the N.F.L. after kneeling during the national anthem to protest police brutality, basketball stars like LeBron James, Derrick Rose and Kobe Bryant have freely expressed their support for the Black Lives Matter movement, even on the court.

headline: Slowing Down to See Black and Blue
abstract: Growing up alongside the development of the internet had a profound influence on the life and artwork of American Artist.
lead_paragraph: The sculptural works and multimedia installations of the Brooklyn-based artist who took the name American Artist explore the ways that structural bias permeates the development and use of technology. “My Blue Window,” on view at the Queens Museum through Feb. 16, focuses on predictive policing technology and the Blue and Black Lives Matter movements.

headline: California Has a High Rate of Police Shootings. Could a New Open-Records Law Change That?
abstract: Just as activists and state lawmakers have sought to bring records of decades-old cases to light, police unions have tried to jam the door shut.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After her son, Eric, was killed by the police in Los Angeles two years ago when officers mistook a water pistol he was holding for a real gun, Valerie Rivera channeled her grief into activism. She joined Black Lives Matter and lobbied the State Legislature to open to the public California’s records on police shootings, which have long been hidden.

headline: Kaepernick
abstract: What does it mean for Nike to align itself with Colin Kaepernick?
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Nike released a groundbreaking ad featuring the former N.F.L. quarterback Colin Kaepernick. His kneeling protest, which started in 2016 as a response to police brutality, was reinterpreted by social media, celebrities and Nike itself to mean something that doesn’t always match the intention of his original protest. So what does it say that a multinational corporation has aligned itself with a social movement? And are we O.K. with this form of “Kaepitalism”?

headline: Nicholas Heyward Sr., 61, Dies; Spoke Out Against Police Brutality
abstract: Mr. Heyward became an activist after his 13-year-old son, who was playing with a toy gun, was killed by a police officer in Brooklyn in 1994.
lead_paragraph: One September evening in 1994, Nicholas Heyward Jr., 13, was playing cops and robbers with friends on a rooftop at the Gowanus Houses, the Brooklyn housing project where he lived. The boys, carrying toy guns, decided to go back inside and rushed down the stairs, jostling one another.

headline: Aspiring Model Killed by Pakistani Police Is Cleared of Charges
abstract: The police claimed Naqeebullah Mehsud, a shopkeeper and aspiring model, had really been a dangerous militant. Now a court has cleared him posthumously.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani judge on Thursday formally dismissed terrorism charges against a man whose killing in a police encounter last year threw a spotlight on extrajudicial killings and police brutality in the country.

headline: Did the Police Spy on Black Lives Matter Protesters? The Answer May Soon Come Out
abstract: A judge rejected the argument used by the New York Police Department when it refused to turn over records about its surveillance methods.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: From the Civil Rights Movement to Black Lives Matter: Honoring Black Mothers Who Lost Their Sons
abstract: The making of Sheila Pree Bright’s photo-mural of black women who had lost their sons gave a group of mothers a chance to tell their stories.
lead_paragraph: The past informs the present in the work of Sheila Pree Bright, who has been photographing the Black Lives Matter movement since 2014. As an artist who draws connections between today’s young activists and their civil rights forebears, she seemed a natural choice to be among 11 socially conscious artists selected to create murals highlighting Atlanta’s past, present and future in time for the Super Bowl, when the city will be in the spotlight.

headline: When ‘Black Lives Matter’ Is Invoked in the Abortion Debate
abstract: For some black ministers, abortion is both wrong and understandable. “I cannot guilt her,” one pastor said of his discussions with black women considering ending their pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — As a pastor, Clinton Stancil counsels his black congregants that abortion is akin to the taking of innocent life. But as a civil rights activist, Mr. Stancil urges them to understand the social forces that prompt black women to have abortions at disproportionately high rates.

headline: Officer Pantaleo Should Be Fired for Eric Garner’s Death. A Judge Agrees.
abstract: The delay is frustrating, as his family grieves.
lead_paragraph: This editorial was updated on Aug. 2 to reflect news developments. It was originally published July 16.

headline: Hong Kong Protest: Clashes With Police Turn Downtown Into Tear Gas-Filled Battlefield
abstract: Riot officers also shot rubber bullets and charged protesters near Beijing’s liaison office, sending hundreds of bystanders scrambling for shelter.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For the second day in a row, thousands rallied on Sunday in Hong Kong to protest mob violence and what they say is police brutality against peaceful marchers. And for the second consecutive day, the police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at the throngs.

headline: ‘The D.O.J. Has Failed Us’: Eric Garner’s Family Assails Prosecutors
abstract: Elected officials and civil rights activists also expressed dismay at the decision not to pursue federal charges against a police officer.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: The Death of Eric Garner: Assessing Blame
abstract: The president of the Police Benevolent Association defends the police officer involved; another reader urges new police guidelines. Also: Afghanistan and Arizona.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the Eric Garner Decision Compares With Other Cases
abstract: Despite increased attention on deaths involving the police, most officers involved in them are not charged. Among the few who are, most are not convicted.
lead_paragraph: After the fatal chokehold of Eric Garner by a New York City police officer, a familiar pattern unfolded: Expressions of outrage, promises to investigate, a long wait for a resolution.

headline: Fire the Officer in the Eric Garner Case? De Blasio Falters
abstract: The mayor has come under rising criticism for declining to support demands by Mr. Garner’s family for the Police Department to dismiss the officer.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: ‘Evidence Does Not Support’ Charging Officer in Eric Garner’s Death, U.S. Attorney Says
abstract: United States Attorney Richard P. Donoghue explained the Department of Justice’s decision not to file federal charges against a New York City police officer in the death of Eric Garner.
lead_paragraph: United States Attorney Richard P. Donoghue explained the Department of Justice’s decision not to file federal charges against a New York City police officer in the death of Eric Garner.

headline: ‘Today, We Can’t Breathe,’ Says Eric Garner’s Mother
abstract: Gwen Carr, Eric Garner’s mother, spoke at a press conference on Tuesday after the Justice Department declined to pursue federal charges against a New York City police officer in his 2014 death.
lead_paragraph: Gwen Carr, Eric Garner’s mother, spoke at a press conference on Tuesday after the Justice Department declined to pursue federal charges against a New York City police officer in his 2014 death.
